SENTENCES AND THEIR PERPLEXITY


1. the fulton county grand jury said friday an investigation	of atlanta's recent primary election produced no evidence that	any irregularities took place	2173.423345031708
2. the jury further said in term-end	presentments that the city executive committee which had over-all	charge of the election deserves the praise and thanks of the	city of atlanta for the manner in which the election was conducted	6032.6606206396045
3. the september-october term jury had been charged by fulton	superior court judge durwood pye to investigate reports of possible	irregularities in the hard-fought primary which was won by	mayor-nominate ivan allen jr	3444.264450055181
4. only a relative handful	of such reports was received the jury said considering the	widespread interest in the election the number of voters and the size	of this city	4634.463426060604
5. the jury said it did find that many of georgia's	registration and election laws are outmoded or inadequate	and often ambiguous	2019.6490217435228
6. it recommended that fulton legislators	act to have these laws studied and revised to the end of modernizing	and improving them	3035.7772401368466
7. the grand jury commented on a number	of other topics among them the atlanta and fulton county purchasing	departments which it said are well operated and follow generally	accepted practices which inure to the best interest of both governments	4131.576347436537
8. however the jury said it believes these	two offices should be combined to achieve greater efficiency and reduce	the cost of administration	3274.720272434485
9. the city purchasing department	the jury said is lacking in experienced clerical personnel	as a result of city personnel policies	1881.830771997539
10. it urged that the city take	steps to remedy this problem	749.8910861717983
11. implementation of georgia's	automobile title law was also recommended by the outgoing jury	793.6412337535745
12. it urged that the next legislature provide enabling funds	and re-set the effective date so that an orderly implementation of	the law may be effected	3908.473877634852
13. the grand jury took a swipe at the	state welfare department's handling of federal funds granted for	child welfare services in foster homes	2329.771966562937
14. this is one of the	major items in the fulton county general assistance program the	jury said but the state welfare department has seen fit to distribute	these funds through the welfare departments of all the counties	in the state with the exception of fulton county which receives	none of this money	7644.225361234616
15. the jurors said they realize a proportionate	distribution of these funds might disable this program in our less	populous counties	1872.1028365223374
16. nevertheless we feel that in the	future fulton county should receive some portion of these available	funds the jurors said	2836.2542272039036
17. failure to do this will continue to place	a disproportionate burden on fulton taxpayers	940.1955579122019
18. the jury	also commented on the fulton ordinary's court which has been under	fire for its practices in the appointment of appraisers guardians and	administrators and the awarding of fees and compensation	5163.938799336769
19. the jury said it found the court has incorporated into	its operating procedures the recommendations of two previous grand	juries the atlanta bar association and an interim citizens committee	3117.1327085861594
20. these actions should serve to protect in fact and in effect the court's wards from undue costs and its appointed and elected servants from unmeritorious criticisms the jury said	4647.351860761148
21. regarding atlanta's new multi-million-dollar airport the jury recommended that when the new management takes charge jan 1 the airport be operated in a manner that will eliminate political influences	3115.44933730335
22. the jury did not elaborate but it added that there should be periodic surveillance of the pricing practices of the concessionaires for the purpose of keeping the prices reasonable	4622.429241716006
23. fulton legislators work with city officials to pass enabling legislation that will permit the establishment of a fair and equitable pension plan for city employes	2594.8731153274375
24. the jury praised the administration and operation of the atlanta police department the fulton tax commissioner's office the bellwood and alpharetta prison farms grady hospital and the fulton health department	4857.9580522087845

87. committee approval of gov price daniel's	abandoned property act seemed certain thursday despite the adamant	protests of texas bankers	2598.6886914856123
88. daniel personally led the fight	for the measure which he had watered down considerably since its	rejection by two previous legislatures in a public hearing before	the house committee on revenue and taxation	3566.6162824904545
89. under committee	rules it went automatically to a subcommittee for one week	960.9580142534154
90. but	questions with which committee members taunted bankers appearing as witnesses	left little doubt that they will recommend passage of it	2016.8990121023137
91. daniel termed extremely conservative his estimate that it would	produce 17 million dollars to help erase an anticipated deficit of	63 million dollars at the end of the current fiscal year next aug	31	5470.255196091743
92. he told the committee the measure would merely provide means	of enforcing the escheat law which has been on the books since	texas was a republic	2745.7011521731647
93. it permits the state to take over bank accounts	stocks and other personal property of persons missing for seven	years or more	3277.698992135808
94. the bill which daniel said he drafted personally	would force banks insurance firms pipeline companies and other	corporations to report such property to the state treasurer	2731.7032293352163
95. the escheat	law cannot be enforced now because it is almost impossible to locate	such property daniel declared	2350.179190669114
96. dewey lawrence a tyler	lawyer representing the texas bankers association sounded the opposition	keynote when he said it would force banks to violate their contractual	obligations with depositors and undermine the confidence of bank	customers	3759.4071582050733
97. if you destroy confidence in banks you do something	to the economy he said	1418.501730435632
98. you take out of circulation many	millions of dollars	260.90954262074047

2755. here's an idea for a child's room that is easy to execute	and is completely charming using puppets for lamp bases	3072.740088943362
2756. most children	love the animated puppet faces and their flexible bodies and	they prefer to see them as though the puppets were in action rather than	put away in boxes	3232.644482920514

2758. to create such a lamp order	a wired pedestal from any lamp shop	792.7907595334741
2759. measure the puppet to determine	the height of the light socket allowing three to four inches above the	puppet's head	2814.8214784843885
2760. make sure that the metal tube through which the wire	passes is in the shape of an inverted l the foot of the	l about three inches long so that the puppet can hang directly	under the light	4052.8736689490665
2761. using the strings that manipulate	the puppet suspend him from the light fixture by tying the	strings to the lamp base	3071.3157666314128
2762. in this way you can arrange his legs and arms	in any desired position with feet or one foot barely resting on	the pedestal	2464.2275655143594

3128. there are so my biologist friends tell me mechanisms of	adaptation and defense that are just too complete and too satisfactory	2040.4573837317457

3131. though this may	or may not be good biology it does aptly illustrate the strength and	the weakness of american catholic higher education	3473.9665419895964
3132. there can	be no doubt that the american catholic accomplishment in the field	of higher education is most impressive: our european brethren never	cease to marvel at the number and the size of our colleges and universities	3944.6449763718256
3133. the deeper wonder is how this miracle was accomplished in decades	rather than in centuries and by immigrant minorities at that	3025.567328507185
3134. by way of explanation we ourselves are prone to imagine that this achievement	stems from the same american catholic zeal and generosity which	brought the parochial school system into existence	3218.051498584497
3135. there	is however one curious discrepancy in this broad and flattering picture	960.7193814900705
3136. viewing the american catholic educational achievement in retrospect	we may indeed see it as a unified whole extending from grade school	to university	2328.9865652173003
3137. but the simple truth is that higher education has	never really been an official american catholic project; certainly	not in the same sense that the establishment of a parochial school	system has been a matter of official policy	6057.887732995174
3138. official encouragement	is one thing but the down-to-earth test is the allocation of diocesan	and parochial funds	1421.7694913138428
3139. american catholics have responded generously	to bishops' and pastors' appeals for the support necessary to	create parochial schools but they have not contributed in a similar	fashion to the establishment of institutions of higher learning	5630.780506782151
3140. they	have not done so for the simple reason that such appeals have hardly	ever been made	1409.4644318606672
3141. diocesan authorities generally have not regarded this	as their direct responsibility	753.0496172410902
3142. all of this may be understandable	enough: it is however in fact difficult to see how diocesan	authorities could have acted otherwise	2161.585185316123
3143. yet for better or for worse	the truth of the matter is that most american catholic colleges do	not owe their existence to general catholic support but rather to	the initiative resourcefulness and sacrifices of individual religious	communities	6061.653673490583
3144. community esprit de corps has been the protective	shell which has made the achievement possible	1108.324973136256
3145. to understand	the past history- and the future potential- of american catholic	higher education it is necessary to appreciate the special character	of the esprit d' corps of the religious community	4997.983633364417
3146. it is something	more than the arithmetical sum of individual totals of piety and	detachment	1100.6856753603088
3147. a religious community with a vital sense of mission achieves	a degree of group orientation and group identification seldom found	elsewhere	3057.8565676945777
3148. the fact that the group orientation and group identification	are founded on supernatural principles and nourished by the well-springs	of devotion simply give them a deeper and more satisfying dimension	3235.6100261519177
3149. the net result is a uniquely satisfying sense of comradeship	the kind of comradeship which sparks enthusiasm and blunts the cutting	edge of sacrifice and hardship	4085.149080191647
3150. american catholic colleges	and universities are in a very real sense the product of private	enterprise- the private enterprise of religious communities	2194.3223810489253
3151. had it not been for such private enterprise diocesan authorities	might of course have been goaded into establishing institutions subsidized	by diocesan funds and parish collections and staffed by religious	as paid employees	5325.700940379744
3152. there is however no point in speculating about such	a possibility: the fact of the matter is that our institutions of	higher learning owe their existence to a spirit not unlike that which	produces the family business	3938.190832181608
3153. this family-community spirit	is the real explanation of the marvel of our achievement	1186.4750108325106
3154. it is this spirit which explains some of the anomalies of american	catholic higher education in particular the wasteful duplication	apparent in some areas	2458.4255692966044

3156. this is not	an isolated example; this aspect of the total picture has been commented	upon often enough	1565.882355475906
3157. it would seem to represent esprit de corps	run riot	557.5753152335873
3158. apart however from the question of wasteful duplication	there is another aspect of the family business spirit	in american catholic higher education which deserves closer scrutiny	2716.139536009567
3159. for while the past needs of the church in this country may have	been adequately met by collegiate institutions which in temper and tone	closely resembled junior colleges and finishing schools it would	seem that today's need is for the college which more closely resembles	the university in its pursuit of excellence	7617.306795344625
3160. at the earlier	pre-academic excellence stage of catholic education the operation	could be conducted on an intra-mural community basis	1729.3385650212117
3161. but with today's	demand for professional qualifications and specialized training	the need for outsiders become more pressing	2133.845119516485
3162. the problem	is not merely that more outside teachers are needed but	that a different brand is called for	1720.9107393604831
3163. commenting on the earlier stage	the notre dame chapter of the american association of university	professors	noted that the term teacher-employee	was	a not inapt description	4095.197876915719
3164. today however the outsider is likely	to have professional qualifications of the highest order	and to be acclimatized	to the democratic processes of the secular or state university	2983.882419396751
3165. and	while no one expects total democracy on the academic scene the scholar	will be particularly sensitive to a line between first and second	class citizenship drawn on any basis other than that of academic rank	or professional achievement	6201.960876027978
3166. it is natural that he should	turn for his major support to a select and dedicated few from the organization	which actually owns the university and whose goals are in	their opinion identified with its highest good and	'the attainment of excellence'	6584.200959132179
3167. the pattern	here pictured is clearly not peculiar to notre dame: it is simply	that the paradox involved in this kind of control of the institution	by the organization which actually owns it becomes more obvious	where there is a larger and more distinguished outside faculty	4668.705012385822

3175. in	the academic world there is seldom anything so dramatic as a strike or	a boycott: all that happens is that the better qualified teacher declines	to gamble two or three years of his life on the chance that conditions	at the catholic institution will be as good as those elsewhere	5037.942505757552

6681. you will need a stereo music system	with speakers preferably placed at least seven or eight feet apart and	one or more of the new london phase 4 records	4669.103291408733
6682. there are 12	of these to choose from all of them of popular music except for the	star release	1721.4230843753762
6683. this features	the marching songs of several nations recorded as though the various	national bands were marching by your reviewing stand	3030.8532228406707
6684. complete with	crowd effects interruptions by jet planes and sundry other touches of	realism this disc displays london's new technique to the best effect	2453.8168623866186
6685. all of the jackets carry a fairly technical and detailed	explanation of this new recording program	1896.6484507708622
6686. no reference is made to the	possibility of recording other than popular music in this manner and	it would not seem to lend itself well to serious music	2967.2551209092035
6687. directionality	is greatly exaggerated most of the time; but when the sounds of	the two speakers are allowed to mix there is excellent depth and dimension	to the music	4665.070311999598
6688. you definitely hear some of the instruments close	up and others farther back with the difference in placement apparently	more distinct than would result from the nearer instruments merely	being louder than the ones farther back	3889.9999914837003
6689. this is a characteristic of	good stereo recording and one of its tremendous advantages over monaural	sound	2128.0325424308426
6690. london explains that the very distinct directional	effect in the phase 4 series is due in large part to their novel methods	of microphoning and recording the music on a number of separate tape	channels	3759.6260355742806
6691. these are then mixed by their sound engineers with the active	co-operation of the musical staff and combined into the final two	channels which are impressed on the record	4688.976644923128
6692. in some of the numbers	the instrumental parts have even been recorded at different times and	then later combined on the master tape to produce special effects	2853.7915423500845
6693. some clue to the character of london's approach in these discs	may be gained immediately from the fact that ten of the 12 titles include	the word percussion or percussive	4841.570275321397
6694. drums xylophones	castanets and other percussive instruments are reproduced remarkably	well	505.6078861502792
6695. only too often however you have the feeling that you are sitting	in a room with some of the instruments lined up on one wall to your	left and others facing them on the wall to your right	6085.4528391204085
6696. they are definitely	in the same room with you but your head starts to swing as	though you were sitting on the very edge of a tennis court watching a	spirited volley	3462.882367123995
6697. stirs pleasant memories with well-known songs of that day and johnny	keating's kombo gives forth with tingling jazz in percussive	moods	seemed one of the least attractive discs- the arrangements just	didn't have so much character as the others	6215.076111249846
6698. there is an extraordinary	sense of presence in all of these recordings apparently obtained	at least in part by emphasizing the middle and high frequencies	2601.015701466981
6699. the penalty for this is noticeable in the big bold brilliant	but brassy piano sounds in		1128.0399636788518
6700. all of the releases however are recorded at a	gratifyingly high level with resultant masking of any surface noise	1717.4148585997584

7356. the performances of the comedie francaise are the	most important recent events in the new york theater	2113.440284947061

7594. a tribe in ancient india believed the earth was a huge tea tray	resting on the backs of three giant elephants which in turn stood	on the shell of a great tortoise	3451.792875269206
7595. this theory eventually proved inexact	22.169144798673234

7598. these keys are the working principles of physics mathematics and astronomy	principles which are then extrapolated or projected to explain	phenomena of which we have little or no direct knowledge	3224.291238513708
7599. in	the autumn of 1959 the british broadcasting corporation presented	a series of talks by four scientists competent in cosmology	2827.5580467348204
7600. three	of these men discussed major theories of the universe while the other	acted as a moderator	1415.0196625786189
7601. the participants were professor h bondi	professor of mathematics at king's college london; dr w	b bonnor reader in mathematics at queen elizabeth college	london; dr r a lyttleton a lecturer at st john's	college cambridge and a reader in theoretical astronomy at the	university of cambridge; and dr g j whitrow reader	in applied mathematics at the imperial college of science and technology	london	8657.21519068597
7602. dr whitrow functioned as moderator	14.967658070875265
7603. the	programs were so well received by the british public that the arguments	have been published in a totally engrossing little book called rival	theories of cosmology	4293.256413746937
7604. dr bonnor begins with	a discussion of the relativistic theories of the universe based on	the general theory of relativity	1888.9323948609222
7605. first of all and this has been calculated	by observation the universe is expanding- that is the galaxies	are receding from each other at immense speeds	4108.684222190398
7606. because of this	dr bonnor holds that the universe is becoming more thinly populated	by stars and whatever else is there	2034.8733336148366
7607. this expansion has been going	on for an estimated eight billion years	962.1908590928031
7608. dr bonnor supports the idea that the universe both expands and contracts	that in several billion years the expansion will slow up and	reverse itself and that the contraction will set in	3440.6022258667194
7609. then after many	more billions of years when all the galaxies are whistling toward a	common center this movement will slow down and reverse itself again	4093.503317988211
7610. professor bondi disagrees with the expansion-contraction theory	94.83682837301055
7611. he supports the steady-state theory which holds that matter is continually	being created in space	1651.7411143409856
7612. for this reason he says the density	of the universe always remains the same even though the galaxies are	zooming away in all directions	2471.0213161859924
7613. new galaxies are forever being formed	to fill in the gaps left by the receding galaxies	1885.8919936864197
7614. if this	is true then the universe today looks just as it did millions of years	ago and as it will look millions of years hence even though the universe	is expanding	3461.9739087037533
7615. for new galaxies to be created professor bondi	declares it would only be necessary for a single hydrogen atom to be	created in an area the size of your living room once every few million	years	5790.112115523201
7616. he contends this idea doesn't conflict with experiments on	which the principle of conservation of matter and energy is based because	some slight error must be assumed in such experiments	3224.395272777266
7617. dr	lyttleton backs the theory that we live in an electric universe	and this theory starts with the behavior of protons and electrons	3498.5173087877533
7618. protons	and electrons bear opposite electrical charges which make them attract	each other and when they are joined they make up an atom of hydrogen-	the basic building block of matter	3322.566441574255
7619. the charges of the electron	and proton are believed to be exactly equal and opposite but dr	lyttleton is not so sure	3260.7836466725134
7620. suppose says dr lyttleton the proton	has a slightly greater charge than the electron		539.0738346690385
7621. this would give the hydrogen atom a slight	charge-excess	396.39568340615295
7622. now if one hydrogen atom were placed at the surface	of a large sphere of hydrogen atoms it would be subject both to the	gravitation of the sphere and the charge-excess of all those atoms	in the sphere	4034.1318355020862
7623. because electrical forces are far	more powerful than gravitation the surface hydrogen atoms would shoot	away from the sphere	2606.503358328161
7624. dr lyttleton then imagines the universe	as a large hydrogen sphere with surface atoms shooting away from	it	1574.0852856047854
7625. this he claims would reasonably account for the expansion of the	universe	960.2399518259479
7626. this slim book while giving the	reader only a fleeting glimpse of the scientific mind confronting the	universe has the appeal that informed conversation always has	2746.2756237393864
7627. several	photographs and charts of galaxies help the non-scientist keep up with	the discussion and the smooth language indicates the contributors	were determined to avoid the jargon that seems to work its way into almost	every field	5927.462396684918

8005. cholesterol	the cornerstone of dr keys's theory is a mysterious	yellowish	waxy substance chemically a crystalline alcohol	2128.1302995360415
8006. scientists	assume that cholesterol	is somehow necessary for the formation of	brain cells since it accounts for about 2% of the brain's total	solid weight	2605.9865437147264

8011. a remarkable substance says dr keys quite apart	from its tendency to be deposited in the walls of arteries	2564.951384292968

8031. as a result although we still make use of this distinction there is	much confusion as to the meaning of the basic terms employed	3664.6602900115117

8038. one of the most widespread features of contemporary thought is the	almost universal disbelief in the reality of spirit	1721.5540513749816
8039. just a few centuries	ago the world of spirits was as populous and real as the world of	material entities	2838.9576167209443

8045. in carrying out this	program science has undoubtedly performed a very considerable service	for which it can claim due credit	2819.726384993683
8046. the objectification of the world	of spirit in popular superstition had certainly gone far beyond what the	experience of spirit could justify or support	2463.070504867742
8047. science is fully competent	to deal with any element of experience which arises from an object	in space and time	2812.111675344641
8048. when therefore it turned its attention to the	concrete entities with which popular imagination had peopled the world	of spirit these entities soon lost whatever status they had enjoyed	as actual elements of external reality	3754.9996558176913
8049. in doing so science has unquestionably	cleared up widespread misconceptions removed extraneous	and illusory sources of fear and dispelled many undesirable popular	superstitions	3469.416175635107

8058. the situation in	which we find ourselves is brought out with dramatic force in arthur	miller's play the crucible which deals with the salem witch	trials	2728.869204895255

8110. if the content of faith is to be presented today in a form that can be	understanded of the people- and this it must not be forgotten	is one of the goals of the perennial theological task- there is	no other choice but to abandon completely a mythological manner of	representation	7502.308010439646

8142. if to be a christian means to say yes where i otherwise	say no or where i do not have the right to say anything at all then	my only choice is to refuse to be a christian	6083.980522433174
8143. expressed differently:	if the price for becoming a faithful follower of jesus christ	is some form of self-destruction whether of the body or of the mind-	sacrificium corporis sacrificium intellectus- then there is	no alternative but that the price remain unpaid	4294.300934006611
8144. this must be	stressed because it is absolutely essential to the argument of this concluding	chapter	1877.551111083838
8145. modern man as dietrich bonhoeffer has told us has	come of age; and though this process by no means represents	an unambiguous gain and is in fact marked by the estrangement from	the depths that seems to be the cost of human maturation it is still	a positive step forward; and those of us who so richly benefit from	it should be the last to despise it	5819.440509680756
8146. in any event it is an irreversible	step and if we are at all honest with ourselves we will know we	have no other alternative than to live in the world in which god has	seen fit to place us	6337.765049543502
8147. to say this of course is to take up a	position on one side of a controversy going on now for some two hundred	years or at any rate since the beginning of the distinctively modern	period in theological thought	4212.799433163779
8148. we have aligned ourselves with that	liberal tradition in protestant christianity that counts among	the great names in its history those of schleiermacher ritschl	herrmann harnack and troeltsch and more recently schweitzer and	the early barth and in part at least bultmann	6555.427974532419
8149. it is to this same	tradition that most of the creative figures in the last century and	a half of american theology also belong	2457.6929451293463
8150. for we must number here not	only the names of bushnell clarke and rauschenbusch not to mention	those of the chicago school and macintosh but those of	the brothers niebuhr and tillich as	well	5462.008955884631
8151. finally we may also mention the several members of the self-consciously	neoliberal movement that developed at the university	of chicago and is heavily indebted philosophically to the creative work	of alfred north whitehead	3543.6816245828363
8152. what makes this long and diverse	tradition essentially one is that those who have belonged to it	have been profoundly in earnest about being modern men in a distinctively	modern world	5004.150623451294
8153. although they have also been concerned to stand squarely	within the tradition of the apostolic church they have exhibited	no willingness whatever to sacrifice their modernity to their christianity	3104.648740969207
8154. they have insisted rather on living fully and completely	within modern culture and so far from considering this treason to god	have looked upon it as the only way they could be faithful to him	5658.926466316488
8155. when we say then that today in our situation the demand for	demythologization must be accepted without condition we are simply	saying that at least this much of the liberal tradition is an enduring	achievement	3736.6454976404516
8156. however much we may have to criticize liberal theology's	constructive formulations the theology we ourselves must strive	to formulate can only go beyond liberalism not behind it	4279.185170094038
8157. in affirming this we have already taken the decisive step in breaking	the deadlock into which bultmann's attempt to formulate such a	theology has led	2598.9535181699976
8158. for we have said in effect that of the two alternatives	to his position variously represented by the other participants	in the demythologizing discussion only one is really an alternative	4836.6219450566105
8159. if the demand for demythologization is unavoidable and so must be	accepted	by theology unconditionally the position of the right is	clearly untenable	2327.44919333267
8160. whereas bultmann's center position is structurally	inconsistent and is therefore indefensible on formal grounds	alone the general position of the right as represented say	by karl barth involves the rejection or at least qualification of	the demand for demythologization and so is invalidated on the material	grounds we have just considered	7553.155367409093
8161. it follows then provided	the possibilities have been exhausted that the only real alternative	is the general viewpoint of the left which has been represented	on the continent by fritz buri and to some extent at least	is found in much that is significant in american and english theology	4895.228240607854
8162. in order to make the implications of our position as clear	as possible we may develop this argument at greater length	3032.67645885566
8163. we	may show first that there cannot possibly be an alternative other	than the three typically represented by bultmann barth and buri	2177.3183762537374
8164. to do this it is sufficient to point out that if the principle in terms	of which alternatives are to be conceived is such as to exclude more	than two then the question of a third possibility is a meaningless	question	6427.3494691829155
8165. thus if what is at issue is whether all s	is p it is indifferent whether some s is not p	or no s is p since in either case the judgment in question	is false	3863.4898838991494
8166. hence if what is in question is whether in a given theology	myth is or is not completely rejected it is unimportant whether	only a little bit of myth or a considerable quantity is accepted;	for in either event the first possibility is excluded	6826.631678862048
8167. therefore	the only conceivable alternatives are those represented on the one hand	by the two at least apparently self-consistent but mutually exclusive	positions of buri and barth and on the other hand by the third	but really pseudo position of bultmann	4302.244318551042
8168. a second point requires more extended comment	141.61689369759705
8169. one hundred years ago there existed in england the association	for the promotion of the unity of christendom	2352.5186397799157
8170. representing	as it did the efforts of only unauthorized individuals of the roman	and anglican churches and urging a communion of prayer unacceptable	to rome this association produced little fruit and in fact was	condemned by the holy office in 1864	4298.009116607127
8171. now again in 1961 in	england there is perhaps nothing in the religious sphere so popularly	discussed as christian unity	2810.152624898768
8172. the church unity octave january	18-25 was enthusiastically devoted to prayer and discussion by the various	churches	1411.6640217314714
8173. many people seem hopeful yet it is difficult to predict	whether or not there will be any more real attainment of christian	unity in 1961 than there was in 1861	4786.915948907417
8174. but it must be readily seen	that the religious picture in england has so greatly changed during these	hundred years as to engender hope at least on the catholic side	3228.2646461206195
8175. for the tide is well on the turn as the london catholic weekly	universe has written	1890.7370093131917
8176. i came to england last summer to	do research on the unpublished letters of cardinal newman	1258.6312193358347
8177. as an	american catholic of irish ancestry i came with certain preconceptions	and expectations; being intellectually influenced by newman	and the general 19th-century literature of england i knew only a	protestant-dominated	country	5184.004051333257

8180. since the protestant clergy for the	most part wear gray or some variant from the wholly black suit my roman	collar and black garb usually identify me in england as a roman	catholic cleric	3665.6055789405473

8239. of course	the crowning event that has dramatically upset the traditional pattern	of english religious history was the friendly visit paid by dr	fisher then anglican archbishop of canterbury to the vatican	last december	5478.273274194153
8240. it was the first time an english primate has done	this since the 14th century	1103.7045193654535
8241. english catholics reacted to this event	with moderate but real hope	751.4488415190699
8242. the death of a man is unique and yet it is universal	959.6295750289688
8243. the straight	line would symbolize its uniqueness the circle its universality	502.2865001685909
8244. but	how can one figure symbolize both	141.65595541610895
8245. christianity declares that	in the life and death of jesus christ the unique and the universal	concur	1416.273327053348
8246. perhaps no church father saw this concurrence of the unique	and the universal as clearly or formulated it as precisely as irenaeus	3276.544943654603
8247. to be the savior and the lord jesus christ has to be a historical	individual with a biography all his own; he dare not be a cosmic	aeon that swoops to earth for a while but never identifies itself	with man's history	4388.352617163966
8248. yet this utterly individual historical person	must also contain within himself the common history of mankind	1879.3283177990809
8249. his	history is his alone yet each man must recognize his own history in	it	1092.7492487805955
8250. his death is his alone yet each man can see his own death in the	crucifixion of jesus	2352.174937476605
8251. each man can identify himself with the history	and the death of jesus christ because jesus christ has identified	himself with human history and human death coming as the head of a	new humanity	3658.5371400761605
8252. not a circle then nor a straight line but a spiral	represents the shape of death as irenaeus sees it; for a spiral has	motion as well as recurrence	4666.177987062306
8253. as represented by a spiral history may	in some sense be said to repeat itself; yet each historical event	remains unique	2030.0335823527107
8254. christ is both unique and universal	64.96625631648998
8255. the first	turn of the spiral is the primeval history of humanity in adam	935.3164947510406
8256. as	origen interprets the end of history on the basis of its beginning	so irenaeus portrays the story of adam on the basis of the story of	christ	4457.000227391275
8257. whence then comes the substance of the first man	260.30267894384207
8258. from	god's will and wisdom and from virgin earth	396.5580697676347
8259. for 'god had	not rained' says the scripture before man was made 'and there	was no man to till the earth'	2026.2260408543395
8260. from this earth then while it was	still virgin god took dust and fashioned the man the beginning of humanity	2813.203433760414
8261. irenaeus does not regard adam and eve merely as private	individuals but as universal human beings who were and are all of humanity	2309.7469404340673
8262. adam and eve were perfect not in the sense that they possessed	perfection but in the sense that they were capable of development	toward perfection	3878.0630688374695
8263. they were in fact children	14.831242381725946
8264. irenaeus does not	claim pre-existence for the human soul; therefore there is no need for	him as there is for origen to identify existence itself with the	fall	4478.3696438393035
8265. existence is created and willed by god and is not the consequence	of a pre-existent rebellion or of a cosmic descent from eternity	into history	2616.283366312227
8266. historical existence is a created good	65.41243395756398
8267. the biblical	symbol for this affirmation is expressed in the words: so	god created man in his own image; in the similitude of god he created	him	2873.088851284137
8268. thus the image of god is that which makes	a man a man and not an oyster; the similitude of god by contrast	is that which makes a man a child of god and not merely a rational creature	4138.026409939989
8269. recent research on irenaeus however makes it evident that	he does not consistently maintain this distinction	1871.4873413549935
8270. he does not mean	to say that adam lost the similitude of god and his immortality through	the fall; for he was created not exactly immortal nor yet exactly	mortal but capable of immortality as well as of mortality	4114.324006237393
8271. and he laid down for him certain	conditions: so that if he kept the command of god then he would	always remain as he was that is immortal; but if he did not he	would become mortal melting into earth whence his frame had been taken	4697.367030518825
8272. these conditions man did not keep and thus he became mortal;	yet he did not stop being human as a result	3037.8114838974734
8273. there is no justification	for systematizing the random statements of irenaeus about the image	of god beyond this nor for reading into his imprecise usage the	later theological distinction between the image of god and	the similitude of god	4135.931844740767
8274. man was created with the	capacity for immortality but the devil's promise of immortality	in exchange for disobedience cost adam his immortality	3265.715723052158
8275. he was in the	words of irenaeus beguiled by another under the pretext of immortality	1097.018797261335
8276. the true way to immortality lay through obedience but man	did not believe this	1396.7236747426664
8277. eve was disobedient; for she did	not obey when as yet she was a virgin	1094.7806731957203
8278. and even as she having indeed	a husband adam but being nevertheless as yet a virgin h having	become disobedient was made the cause of death both to herself and	to the entire human race; so also did mary having a man betrothed	to her and being nevertheless a virgin by yielding obedience become	the cause of salvation both to herself and the whole human race	8683.437312387765
8279. because he interprets the primitive state of man as one of mere	potentiality or capacity and believes that adam and eve were created	as children irenaeus often seems inclined to extenuate their disobedience	as being due no doubt to carelessness but still wicked	4458.630101106346
8280. his interpretation of the beginning on the basis of the end prompts	him to draw these parallels between the virgin eve and the virgin	mary	3930.089731544305
8281. that parallelism affects his picture of man's disobedience too;	for as it was christ the word of god who came to rescue man	so it was disobedience to the word of god in the beginning that brought	death into the world and all our woe	4613.378115339624
8282. with this act of disobedience	and not with the inception of his individual existence man	began the downward circuit on the spiral of history descending from	the created capacity for immortality to an inescapable mortality	5629.881658134024
8283. at	the nadir of that circuit is death	165.9452211709553
8284. along with the fruit they did	also fall under the power of death because they did eat in disobedience;	and disobedience to god entails death	3867.8601605462777
8285. wherefore as they became	forfeit to death from that moment they were handed over to it	1248.2066275673983
8286. this leads irenaeus to the somewhat startling notion that adam	and eve died on the same day that they disobeyed namely on a friday	as a parallel to the death of christ on good friday; he sees	a parallel also to the jewish day of preparation for the sabbath	7347.0275758338075
8287. in	any case though they had been promised immortality if they ate of	the tree they obtained mortality instead	1731.065920787696
8288. the wages of sin is death	65.55327290654336
8289. man's life originally shaped for immortality and for communion with	god must now be conformed to the shape of death	1879.511453753577
8290. nevertheless	even at the nadir of the circuit the spiral of history belongs	to god and he still rules	2584.3093045258547
8291. even death therefore has a providential	as well as a punitive function	646.9701221308701
8292. wherefore also he god	drove him man out of paradise and removed him far from the tree	of life not because he envied him the tree of life as some venture	to assert but because he pitied him and did not desire that	he should continue a sinner for ever nor that the sin which surrounded	him should be immortal and evil interminable and irremediable	8626.416021188483
8293. but	he set a bound to his state of sin by interposing death and thus	causing sin to cease putting an end to it by the dissolution of the	flesh which should take place in the earth so that man ceasing at	length to live in sin and dying to it might live to god	5253.239556699755
8294. this	idea which occurs in both tatian and cyprian fits especially well	into the scheme of irenaeus' theology; for it prepares the way for	the passage from life through death to life that is achieved in christ	5922.284768884495
8295. as man can live only by dying so it was only by his dying that	christ could bring many to life	2035.9860154657067
8296. it is probably fair to say	that the idea of death is more profound in irenaeus than the idea of	sin is	3250.64845258959
8297. this applies to his picture of adam	92.94119820972291
8298. it is borne out also	by the absence of any developed theory about how sin passes from one generation	to the next	3266.385332390912
8299. it becomes most evident in his description of	christ as the second adam who does indeed come to destroy sin but	whose work culminates in the achievement of immortality	3092.0512846989905
8300. this emphasis	upon death rather than sin as man's fundamental problem irenaeus	shares with many early theologians especially the greek-speaking ones	3050.840813845234
8301. they speak of the work of christ as the bestowal of incorruptibility	which can mean deliverance from	time and history	1884.8351142019687
8302. death reminds man of his sin but it reminds	him also of his transience	1404.9924248724265
8303. it represents a punishment that he knows	he deserves but it also symbolizes most dramatically that he lives	his life within the process of time	2592.766421608757
8304. these two aspects of death cannot	be successfully separated but they dare not be confused or identified	2115.893384437549
8305. the repeated efforts in christian history to describe death as	altogether the consequence of human sin show that these two aspects of	death cannot be separated	2723.0932401343816
8306. such efforts almost always find themselves	compelled to ask whether adam was created capable of growing old and	then older and then still older in short whether adam's life was	intended to be part of the process of time	6157.723569038874
8307. if it was then it must	have been god's intention to translate him at a certain point from	time to eternity	2030.6455513362675
8308. one night so some of these theories run adam would	have fallen asleep much as he fell asleep for the creation of eve;	and thus he would have been carried over into the life eternal	5662.405279088988
8309. the	embarrassment of these theories over the naturalness of death is an	illustration of the thesis that death cannot be only a punishment for	some termination seems necessary in a life that is lived within the	natural order of time and change	4387.218468832551
8310. on the other hand christian	faith knows that death is more than the natural termination of temporal	existence	2342.434486709625

8548. the	concept of the middle kingdom at peace strong and united under a	forceful ruler which had been only a longed-for ideal in the time of	the	warring states was finally realized by the establishment of a chinese	empire under the ch'in dynasty	6710.720055351419
8549. but this	was only accomplished by excessive cruelty and extremes of totalitarian	despotism	789.7424056892625
8550. among the many severe measures taken by the first emperor	shih huang-ti in his efforts to insure the continuation of	this hard-won national unity was the burning of the books in 213 bc	with the expressed intention of removing possible sources for	divergent thinking; but as he had a special fondness for magic and	divination he ordered that books on these subjects should be spared	8615.25863945853
8551. many of the latter were destroyed in their turn during the burning	of the vast ch'in palace some ten years later; yet some must have	survived because the old interest in number symbolism divination	and magic persisted on into the han dynasty which succeeded in reuniting	china and keeping it together for a longer period		4369.3350397888435
8552. in fact during	the first century bc an extensive literature sprang up devoted	to these subjects finding its typical expression in the so-called	wei books a number of which were specifically devoted to	the lo shu and related numerical diagrams especially in connection	with divination	6918.153280644229
8553. however the wei books were also destroyed	in a series of orthodox confucian purges which culminated in a final	proscription in 605	2162.0002774986883
8554. after all this destruction of old literature	it should be obvious why we have so little information about the	early history and development of the lo shu which was already	semisecret anyhow	5135.561510815543
8555. but in spite of all this enough evidence remains	to show that the magic square of three must indeed have been the object	of a rather extensive cult- or series of cults- reaching fullest	expression in the han period	4119.043273774471
8556. although modern scholars have	expressed surprise that the simple magic square of three a mere	mathematical puzzle was able to exert a considerable influence	on the minds and imaginations of the cultured chinese for so many centuries	they could have found most of the answers right within the square	itself	7448.5971164218845
8557. but up to now no one has attempted to analyze its inherent	mathematical properties or the numerical significance of its numbers-	singly or in combination- and then tried to consider these in	the light of old chinese cosmological concepts	4140.907930759797
8558. such an analysis	speedily reveals why the middle number of the lo shu 5	was so vitally significant for the chinese ever since the earliest hints	that they had a knowledge of this diagram	5468.98444915232
8559. the importance of this	5 can largely be explained by the natural mathematical properties of	the middle number and its special relationship to all the rest of the	numbers- quite apart from any numerological considerations which is	to say any symbolic meaning arbitrarily assigned to it	4683.8688323021015
8560. indeed mathematically	speaking it was both functionally and symbolically the most	important number in the entire diagram	2109.107084261294
8561. if one takes the middle	number 5 and multiplies it by 3	the result is 15 which is also the constant sum of	all the rows columns and two main diagonals	3337.9432080429447
8562. then if the middle number	is activated to its greatest potential in terms of this square through	multiplying it by the highest number 9	the result is 45; and the latter is the total sum	of all the numbers in the square by which all the other numbers are	overshadowed and in which they may be said to be absorbed	8236.684661663736
8563. furthermore	the middle number of the lo shu is not only the physical	mean between every opposing pair of the other numbers by reason of	its central position; it is also their mathematical mean since it	is equal to half the sum of every opposing pair all of which equal 10	5011.971419073993
8564. in fact the neat balance of these pairs and their subtle equilibrium	would have had special meaning in the minds of the old chinese	3703.1848026864
8565. for they considered the odd numbers as male and the even ones as female	equating the two groups with the yang and yin principles in nature;	and in this square the respective pairs made up of large and	small odd numbers and those composed of large and small even	numbers were all equal to each other	5311.18226538206
8566. thus all differences were	leveled and all contrasts erased in a realm of no distinction and	the harmonious balance of the lo shu square could effectively	symbolize the world in balanced harmony around a powerful central axis	5945.9859310351385
8567. the tremendous emphasis on the 5 in the lo shu square-	for purely mathematical reasons- and the fact that this number so	neatly symbolized the heart and center of the universe could well explain	why the old chinese seem to have so revered the number 5 and	why they put so much stress on the concept of centrality	5416.982026227584
8568. these twin	tendencies seem to have reached their height in the han dynasty	1183.1655735089703
8569. the existing reverence for centrality must have been still further	stimulated toward the close of the second century bc when	the han emperor wu ti ordered the dynastic color changed to yellow-	which symbolized the center among the traditional five directions-	and took 5 as the dynastic number believing that he would thus	place himself his imperial family and the nation under the most auspicious	influences	5822.027140888631
8570. his immediate motive for doing this may not have	been directly inspired by the lo shu but this measure must inevitably	have increased the existing beliefs in the latter's efficacy	4819.070923576245
8571. after this time inscriptions on the han bronze mirrors as well	as other writings emphasized the desirability of keeping one's	self at the center of the universe where cosmic forces were strongest	3469.540663304576
8572. later we shall see what happened when an emperor took this idea too	literally	1408.8685735186123
8573. all this emphasis on centrality and on the number	5 as a symbolic expression of the center which seems to have begun	as far back as 400 bc also may conceivably have led to the development	of the five-elements school and the subsequent efforts to	fit everything into numerical categories of five	5076.749030303409
8574. we find for example	such groupings as the five ancient rulers the five sacred mountains	the five directions the five metals five	colors five tastes five odors five musical notes five	bodily functions five viscera and many others	6104.300269460983
8575. this trend has	often been ascribed to the cult of the five elements itself as though	they had served as the base for all the rest; but why did the old	chinese postulate five elements when the ancient near east-	which may have initiated the idea that natural elements exerted influence	in human life and activities- recognized only four	5461.599742083634
8576. and why	did the chinese suddenly begin to talk about the five directions	when the animals they used as symbols of the directions designated only	the usual four	4500.017181325771
8577. obviously something suddenly caused them to start	thinking in terms of fives and that may have been the workings of	the lo shu	2316.3902306498803
8578. this whole tendency had an unfortunate effect	on chinese thinking	564.2404163600211
8579. whereas the primary meanings of the lo shu	diagram seemed to have been based on its inner mathematical properties-	and we shall see that even its secondary meanings rested on	some mathematical bases- the urgent desire to place everything into	categories of fives led to other groupings based on other numbers until	an exaggerated emphasis on mere numerology pervaded chinese thought	5553.143296624165
8580. scholars made numbered sets of as many things as possible in nature	or assigned arbitrary numbers to individual things in a fashion that	seems to the modern scientific mind as downright nonsensical and	philosophical ideas based upon all this tended to stifle speculative thought	in china for many centuries	7326.958112327598
8581. square	although the primary mathematical properties of the middle	number at the center of the lo shu and the interrelation	of all the other numbers to it might seem enough to account for the deep	fascination which the lo shu held for the old chinese philosophers	this was actually only a beginning of wonders	5199.752199326717
8582. for the lo	shu square was a remarkably complete compendium of most of the chief	religious and philosophical ideas of its time	3269.5777315080813
8583. as such one cannot	fully understand the thought of the pre-han and han periods without	knowing the meanings inherent in the lo shu; but conversely	one cannot begin to understand the lo shu without knowing something	about the world view of the old chinese which they felt they	saw expressed in it	5084.233117181706
8584. the chinese world view during the han dynasty	when the lo shu seems to have been at the height of its	popularity was based in large part on the teachings of the yin-yang	and five-elements school which was traditionally founded by tsou	yen	6653.068287646219
8585. according to this doctrine the universe was ruled by heaven	t'ien- as a natural force or in the personification of a supreme	sky-god- governing all things by means of a process called the	tao	which can be roughly interpreted as the order of the universe	or the universal way	4910.086851603401
8586. heaven acting through the tao	expressed itself by means of the workings of two basic principles	the yin and the yang	3060.8126765175575
8587. the yang or male principle was the source	of light heat and dynamic vitality associated with the sun; while	the yin or female principle flourished in darkness cold and quiet	inactivity and was associated with the moon	3953.225819091132
8588. together these two	principles influenced all things and in varying combinations they were	present in everything	1861.9544700638708
8589. we have already seen that odd numbers	were considered as being yang while the even numbers were yin so	that the eight outer numbers of the lo shu represented these two	principles in balanced equilibrium around the axial center	4138.998988099007
8590. during	the han dynasty another yin-yang conception was applied to the lo	shu considering the latter as a plan of ancient china	3280.026374905227
8591. instead	of linking the nine numbers of this diagram with the traditional nine	provinces as was usually	done this equated the odd yang numbers	with mountains and the even numbers	with rivers; taking the former	from the five sacred mountains of the han period and the latter from	the principal river systems of old china	5264.996832515156
8592. thus the middle	number 5 represented sung-shan in honan central china; the	3 t'ai-shan in shantung east china; the 7 hwa-shan in shensi	west china; the 1 heng-shan in hopei north china	; and the	9 huo-shan in anhwei which was then the south sacred mountain	5557.5047046041045
8593. for the rivers the 4 represented the huai to the southeast;	the 2 the san kiang southwest;	the 8 the chi in the northeast; and the 6 the yellow river	in the northwest	3581.5471382231312

8672. one	denomination had a membership of 1419833 at the beginning of the	period under study and twenty years later its membership stood at 1541991-	a net growth of only 122158	3220.4974844676562

8677. during	this period 7484268 members were received yet the net membership	now is only 9910741	1650.519130313232

8681. something is wrong when	these things happen	140.8713548735089
8682. the local family of god has failed its	new members through neglect and unconcern for their spiritual welfare	1574.1834458449391
8683. new members can become participating growing	members	140.16775287900833

8693. care must be taken neither	to confuse unity with uniformity nor god with our parochial ideas	about him but with these two qualifications the statement stands	4104.804818666656
8694. the statement also points to a classic paradox: the more men turn	toward god who is not only in himself the paradigm of all unity but	also the only ground on which human unity can ultimately be established	the more men splinter into groups and set themselves apart from one	another	5025.482977728416

8697. the words of cardinal newman come forcibly	to	mind: oh how we hate one another for the love of god!	the source of this paradox is not difficult to identify	4830.437131464124
8698. institutions require structure form and definition	and these in turn entail differentiation and exclusion	943.248281526355
8699. a completely	amorphous institution would be a contradiction in terms; to escape	this fate it must rule some things out	2802.7276735390183
8700. for every criterion which	defines what something is at the same time proclaims- implicitly if	not openly- what that something is not	2173.557182475453
8701. some persons are so sensitive	to this truth as to propose that we do away with institutions altogether;	in the present context this amounts to the advice that while	being religious may have a certain justification we ought to dispense	with churches	6546.915267059418
8702. man is at once a gregarious	animal and a form-creating being	506.0063446647222

8705. both eventualities	are possible logically but practically they are impossible	560.7936722870147

8708. is there any way out of the predicament	165.67758349835538

8712. it is the art	of relating the finite to the infinite of doing our best to insure that	the particularistic requirements of religious institutions will not	thwart god's intent of unity among men more than is minimally necessary	4032.8576356464
8713. in a certain sense interfaith communication parallels diplomatic	communication among the nation-states	973.588387798618

8718. such needs may rise	to pathological proportions	93.73148459956965
8719. modern psychology has shown that paralleling	the authoritarian personality is the bigoted personality	in which insecurity inferiority suspicion and distrust combine	to provide a target for antagonism so indispensable that it will be manufactured	if it does not exist naturally	6323.220096556708

8774. when they say that under no circumstances would it ever be right to permit	the termination of the human race by human action because	there could not possibly be any proportionate grave reason to justify	such a thing they know exactly what they mean	4507.149367622565
8775. of course in prudential	calculation in balancing the good directly intended and done against	the evil unintended and indirectly done no greater precision can	be forthcoming than the subject allows	4851.052999152311
8776. yet it seems clear that there	can be no good sufficiently great or evil repelled sufficiently grave	to warrant the destruction of mankind by man's own action	2855.1807515806936
8777. i mean however that the moral theologian knows what he means by permit	1179.5937473085366
8778. he is not talking in the main about probabilities risks	and danger in general	947.940928057947
8779. he is talking about an action which just as efficaciously	does an evil thing	as it efficaciously does some good	2849.6740395267198
8780. he	is talking about double effects of which the specific action causes	directly the one and indirectly the other but causes both;	of which one is deliberately willed or intended and the other not intended	or not directly intended but still both are done while the	evil effect is with equal consciousness on the part of the agent foreknown	to be among the consequences	5719.480704430615
8781. this is what in a technical sense	to only permit an evil result means	1420.3515579085415
8782. it means to do it	and to know one is doing it but as only a secondary if certain effect	of the good one primarily does and intends	3015.3013378676483
8783. of course grave guiltiness	may be imputed to the military action of any nation or to the action	of any leader or leaders which for any supposed good permits	in this sense the termination of the human race by human action	6408.631564316113
8784. certainly in analyzing an action which truly faced such alternatives	it is never possible that no world would be preferable to	some worlds and there are in truth no circumstances in which the	destruction of human life presents itself as a reasonable alternative	4468.896322810649
8785. naturally where one or the other of the effects of an action	is uncertain this has to be taken into account	3049.610615209233
8786. especially is this	true when because the good effect is remote and speculative while	the evil is certain and grave the action is prohibited	2474.3021264869185
8787. presumably	if the reverse is the case and the good effect is more certain than the	evil result that may be forthcoming not only must the good and the	evil be prudentially weighed and found proportionate but also calculation	of the probabilities and of the degree of certainty or uncertainty	in the good or evil effect must be taken into account	8346.383493435993
8788. there must	not only be greater good than evil objectively in view but also greater	probability of actually doing more good than harm	2316.503825834327
8789. if an evil which	is certain and extensive and immediate may rarely be compensated for	by a problematic speculative future good by the same token not every	present certain and immediate good that may have	to be done will be outweighed by a problematic speculative and future	evil	7218.923895791582
8790. nevertheless according to the traditional theory a man begins	in the midst of action and he analyzes its nature and immediate cosequences	before or while putting it forth and causing these consequences	3465.1789469811847
8791. he does not expect to be able to trammel up all the future consequences	of his action	2105.8898135436784

8794. mr philip toynbee	writes for example that in terms of probability it is surely as	likely as not that mutual fear will lead to accidental war in the near	future if the present situation continues	5605.856672556705

8844. this article presents our observations	of that session of the realtors as they saw themselves and as the	faculty and students saw them	2327.3074656271256

8846. within the membership of this group as has been found true	of men in other professional or trade associations the most ready	portrayal of oneself to the public is that of a neutral agent simply	serving the interests of a seller or buyer and mediating between	them	4762.373262537922
8847. professional responsibility is seen to consist largely in serving	the wishes of the client fairly and in an efficient manner	2822.9773107941737
8848. but as	conversation goes on particularly among the realtors themselves another	image emerges that of considerable power and influence in the community	2165.4665652429894
8849. obviously much more than customer expectation is determining	the realtor's role	750.2434885159146
8850. judgments are continually rendered regarding	the potential buyers' income educational level and above all racial	extraction; and whether these would qualify them for congenial	happy relations to other people in certain community areas	3559.0986328021054
8851. though the reference to race was stricken by the association	in 1950 being an agent of such detrimental influences	still appears as the cardinal sin realtors see themselves committed to	avoid	3332.916157070472
8852. the rationale for this avoidance was most frequently	expressed in economic terms; all feared the supposed stigma they believed	would inevitably attach to any realtor who openly introduced non-white	particularly negro peoples into all-white restricted areas	5755.772393500377
8853. they would become tagged as men not interested in being purely real	estate professionals but agitators for some kind of cause	or reform and this was no longer to be a pro	3450.346503486099
8854. obviously	what we are confronted with here is the identification of professional	with narrow skills and specialization the effective servicing	of a client rather than responsiveness to the wider and deeper	meaning and associations of one's work	5921.658093157321
8855. these men- for the most	part educated in our best new england colleges well established	financially and socially in the community- under kindly but insistent	probing reveal little or no objective or explicit criteria or data	for their generalizations about the interests and attitudes of the	people they claim to serve or about the public responses that actually	follow their occasional breach of a client-service relationship	5802.305996972326
8856. this narrow professionalism does not even fit the present	realities of their situation as the pressure of minorities and the	power and respectability of the realtors increase	4301.345288826703
8857. as our discussion	continued the inadequacy of the client relationship as an interpretation	of their way of operating became evident	1882.7562311339273
8858. realtors	live in their communities as specialists in a given area of work as	members of social and professional organizations as citizens and civic	leaders as church laymen as university alumni as newspaper readers	etc	5689.3644292626095
8859. from such communal roles the realtor finds the substance that	shapes his moral understanding	941.6187889318641
8860. it seems to us that choices exercised	by realtors in moral situations center in at least three areas:	the various ways in which they interpret a particular social	issue; their pattern of involvement in the regular legal and political	processes; and most pervasively their interpretation of	who is a real pro of what it means to be a professional man in	a technical fragmented society	8588.272223159194
8861. most of the realtors minimized	their own understanding of and role in the racial issue pleading	that they only reflect the attitudes and intentions of their society	2851.2218083382563
8862. there is some reality to this; the commission on race and housing	concluded that there is no reason to believe that real estate	men are either more or less racially prejudiced on the whole than any	other segment of the american population	6550.413478737564
8863. but such a reaction obscures	the powerful efforts made in the past by both nareb and	its local boards for the maintenance of restrictive clauses and practices	2861.726028513431
8864. also it does not recognize the elements of choice and judgment	continually employed	1182.6172000365825
8865. like business and university groups generally	these men had very limited knowledge of recent sociological and	psychological studies and findings that might illumine the decisions	they make	2866.3529871578276
8866. realtors both generally and in this group have invariably	equated residential integration with a decline in property values	a circumstance viewed with considerable apprehension	3699.0459928258665
8867. recent	studies by the commission on race and housing and others however	point to a vast complex of factors that often do not warrant this conclusion	2719.7577919481373
8868. there are increasing numbers of neighborhoods that are integrated	residentially without great loss of property values the white population	having taken the initiative in preparing the areas for an appreciation	of the negroes' desire for well-kept housing privacy etc	6181.667719885869
8869. data on the decline of property values in an area after a new racial	group enters it has to be assessed in terms of the trends in property	values before the group comes in	3644.457070754767
8870. often they are able to get in	only because the area is declining economically	1416.403154432274
8871. significantly	no realtor and few of the faculty present were familiar with any of	the six volumes	that present the commission's findings	2159.8650790924175
8872. no one anticipates any radical	shift in this situation but questions concerning reading habits	the availability of such data and the places where it is discussed must	surely be raised	4824.803438748645
8873. the role of both church and university as sources	of information and settings within which the implications of such information	may be explored needs consideration	2589.839527383234
8874. relevant facts	however	extend beyond considerations of property values and maintenance	of harmonious neighborhoods	1413.020077548119
8875. discussion of minority housing necessarily	involves such basic issues as the intensity of one's democratic	conviction and religious belief concerning equality of opportunity	the function and limitations of government in the securing of such	equality and the spotlight that world opinion plays upon local incidents	of racial agitation and strife	4952.450763732689
8876. realtors realize of course that they are involved in an	increasingly complex legal and political system that is opening up opportunities	for leverage on their relation to clients as well as opportunities	for evasion of their responsibility for racial discrimination	in housing	6535.079184728793
8877. on the positive side recent federal action has largely	undermined the legal sanction so long enjoyed by the segregationist position;	anti-discriminatory statutes in housing have now been adopted	by thirteen states and while specific provisions have varied the	tendency is clearly toward expanding coverage	4543.977496260411

8880. in 1957 the real estate boards of new york city	actively opposed the then pending private housing anti-discrimination	law	2584.960336761649
8881. official reasoning: the bill was a wanton invasion	there are sins of omission as	well as commission; the attitude adopted by realtors and their associations	either negative or positive plays a large part in the public	acceptance of such measures and the degree to which they may be effectively	enforced	4955.9846327658115

8885. but as yet no real estate board has been willing officially	to support such laws or to admit the permissibility of introducing minority	buyers into all-white neighborhoods	2867.163754869139
8886. one of the roles of	the social scientist ethicist or theologian in our discussions with	the realtors became that of encouraging greater awareness of the opportunities	offered by the legal and political processes for the exercise	of broad social responsibilities in their work	6676.626575600912
8887. but responsiveness to	these opportunities presumes that all of us judge the good as a human	good and not simply as a professional white american good	2727.8652398121344
8888. such	judgments are meaningful only	in so far as persons are members of a world	let us say a community that embraces scarsdale or yonkers but is	also infinitely richer since it is all-inclusive	5496.8935840084005
8889. that community	of all creation is then the ultimate object of our loyalty and	the concrete norm of all moral judgment	2020.5954961065945
8890. racial discrimination is wrong	then not because it goes against the grain of a faculty member trying	to converse with a few realtors but because it goes against the	grain of creation and against the will of the creator	6172.418444299654
8891. thus moral issues	concerning the nature of the legal and political processes take	on theological dimensions	1256.5006809441288
8892. over the years	individuals engaged in the sale of real estate have developed remarkable	unity in the methods and practices employed	3036.5717492727044
8893. most realtors and	real estate brokers talk of themselves as professional people	with the cultural and moral values held by the traditional professions	2323.7521821007626
8894. but what significance attaches to professional beyond the narrow	sense of skillfulness in meeting a client's stated needs as already	noted	3043.850264068711
8895. our faculty and students pressed this issue more than	any other	500.49197287573634
8896. as a theologian in the group pointed out a professional	was before the modern period of technical specialization one who	professed to be a bearer and critic of his culture in the use	of his particular skills	5912.659237712369
8897. if we look about the world today we can see clearly that there	are two especially significant factors shaping the future of our civilization:	science and religion	2870.1843302171724
8898. science is placing in our	hands the ultimate power of the universe the power of the atom	2123.7442179301147
8899. religion	or the lack of it will decide whether we use this power to build	a brave new world of peace and abundance for all mankind or whether	we misuse this power to leave a world utterly destroyed	4030.032332470398
8900. how can we	have the wisdom to meet such a new and difficult challenge	1413.890609479166
8901. we	may feel pessimistic at the outlook	93.96439889203143
8902. and yet there is a note of	hope	because this same science that is giving us the power of the atom is	also giving us atomic vision	4291.328828590521
8903. we are looking inside the atom and seeing	there a universe which is not material but something beyond the material	a universe that in a word is not matter but music	3339.6940654600485
8904. and it is	in this new vision of the atom that we find an affirmation and an invigoration	of our faith	3026.125188827088
8905. to see this vision in perspective	we need first of all a clear idea of the magnitude of this new	power from the atom	2457.234053541047
8906. you know that i could hold right here in my	hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb	that dropped on hiroshima	4453.912707671982
8907. it was only about the size of a baseball;	but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of	20000 tons of tnt	2593.1944788649985
8908. that is enough tnt to fill the tower	of the empire state building; and with the availability of bombs	of that size war became a new problem	4292.398504289173
8909. now we might have restricted	the use of uranium bombs by controlling the sources of uranium	because it is found in only a few places in the world	2984.549035329956
8910. but we had hardly	started to adjust our thinking to this new uranium weapon when we	were faced with the hydrogen bomb	3253.46352581163
8911. hydrogen is just as plentiful as	uranium is scarce	264.870242382748
8912. we know that we have hydrogen in water; water is	f and the h stands for hydrogen; there is also hydrogen in wood	and hydrogen in our bodies	4476.742485775258
8913. i have calculated that if i could snap	my fingers in one magic gesture to release the power of all the hydrogen	in my body i would explode with the force of a hundred bombs of	the kind that fell on hiroshima	4375.063285520213
8914. i won't try the experiment but	i think you can see that if we all knew the secret and we could all let	ourselves go there would be quite an explosion	5005.693562048524
8915. and then think how	little hydrogen we have in us compared with the hydrogen in delaware	bay or in the ocean beyond	2175.4964493751436
8916. salt water is still f the same hydrogen	is there	559.4808293306074
8917. and the size of the ocean shows us the magnitude of the	destructive power we hold in our hands today	1887.2072286796483
8918. of course there	is also an optimistic side to the picture	753.9197179794888
