8920. and think if we all knew	this secret and we could pool our power what a wonderful public utility	company we would make	3474.520725546759
8921. with just the hydrogen of our bodies we	could run the world for years	947.8616153711042
8922. then think of delaware bay and the	ocean and you see that we have a supply of power for millions of years	to come	3695.0545511334763
8923. it is power with which we can literally rebuild the world	provide adequate housing food education abundant living for everyone	everywhere	2035.8541744116355
8924. now let us see where this power	comes from	394.93939910808194
8925. to grasp our new view of the atom we have to appreciate	first of all how small the atom is	1877.8828516381964
8926. i have been trying to make this	clear to my own class in chemistry	1406.9623046297888
8927. one night there were some dried	peas lying on our kitchen table and these peas looked to me like a little	group of atoms; and i asked myself a question: suppose i	had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body how large an	area would they cover	5078.411388281155
8928. i calculated first that there are	about an octillion atoms in the average human body; that is a figure	one with 27 ciphers quite a large number	4283.04150221633
8929. then i calculated that a	million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator; a billion	peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic; a trillion peas	would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people;	and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia	5341.434169175751
8930. i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at	this rate so i decided to take another measure- the whole state of	pennsylvania	3876.965431801093
8931. imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania	but instead of snowing snow it snows peas; so we get the whole state	covered with peas about four feet deep	3115.2784528544694
8932. you can imagine what it would	look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against	the houses and covering the cars; pennsylvania thus blanketed would	contain about a quintillion peas	5504.638774673438
8933. but we still have a long	way to go	261.92453157144325
8934. next we imagine our blizzard raging over all the land areas	of the entire globe- north america south america europe asia	and africa all covered with peas four feet deep; then we have	sextillion peas	5637.90131054033
8935. next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole	earth with peas then we go out among the neighboring stars collect	250 planets each the size of the earth and also cover each of these	with peas four feet deep; and then we have septillion	4696.235355391125
8936. finally we	go into the farthest reaches of the milky way; we get 250000 planets;	we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last	we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body	6547.147714428181
8937. so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are	793.4979104589123
8938. speck- and space	now although an atom is small we can still in	imagination have a look at it	2591.706908751182
8939. let us focus on an atom of calcium from	the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow	a magic alice in wonderland growing pill	3337.798250949215
8940. i start growing rapidly	and this calcium atom grows along with me	959.9306673462054
8941. i shoot up through the	roof into the sky past the clouds through the stratosphere out beyond	the moon out among the planets until i am over a hundred and	fifty million miles long	3657.4243784038895
8942. then this atom of calcium will swell to something	like a great balloon a hundred yards across a balloon big enough	to put a football field inside	4302.278485045949
8943. and if you should step inside of such	a magnified atom according to the physics of forty years ago you	would see circulating over your head down at the sides and under your	feet some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs	4482.244492850051
8944. these	balls are moving in great circles and ellipses and are of course the	electrons the particles of negative electricity which by their action	create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring	atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone	7349.115674855222
8945. since these electrons are moving like planets you may wonder whether	there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom	2195.5001894524776
8946. so you look down	there and you see a tiny whirling point about the size of the head	of a pin	3063.619934832185
8947. this is the atomic sun the atomic nucleus	168.81862472550907
8948. even if the	atom were big enough to hold a football field this nucleus is still	only about the size of a pinhead	3498.1112757073047
8949. it is this atomic nucleus that contains	the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged	electrons in their orbits; it also contains nearly all the mass	and the atomic energy	3344.989434250901
8950. you may ask what else there is and the	answer is nothing- nothing but empty space	1883.0603708602362
8951. and since you are made	of atoms you are nothing much but empty space too	1102.6290662947954
8952. if i could put	your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down squeeze	these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge	you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole	was gone you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you	could see on this piece of paper	8650.354068561295
8953. someone has remarked that this is	certainly the ultimate in reducing	501.23904389723486
8954. at any rate it shows us how immaterial	we are	557.2947692346013
8955. now this 1920 view of the	atom was on the whole a discouraging picture	948.0589266077416
8956. for we believed that the	electrons	obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics; and therefore	the atom was really just a little machine; and in mechanics the	whole is no more than the sum of the parts	5964.282843842599
8957. so if you are made of	atoms you are just a big machine; and since the universe is also made	of atoms it is just a supermachine	2886.9609232207563
8958. and this would mean that we	live in a mechanistic universe governed by the laws of cause and effect	bound in chains of determinism that hold the universe on a completely	predetermined course in which there is not room for soul or spirit	or human freedom	7022.448355790019
8959. and this is why so many scientists a half a century	ago were agnostics or atheists	1268.8299602530928
8960. then came the scientific revolution	in the late 1920's	393.56355324279605
8961. a suggestion from louis de broglie a	physicist in france showed us that these electrons are not point particles	but waves	2035.399061797701
8962. and to see the meaning of this new picture imagine	that you can put on more powerful glasses and go back inside the atom	and have a look at it in the way we view it today	5947.801600883451
8963. now as you step	inside instead of seeing particles orbiting around like planets you	see waves and ripples very much like the ripples that you get on the surface	of a pond when you drop a stone into it	4156.12123056561
8964. these ripples spread	out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral	1646.0328428994962
8965. and as the waves flow back and forth and merge with the waves from	the neighboring atoms you can put on a magic hearing aid and you hear	music	3145.385013328015
8966. it is a music like the music from a great organ or a vast orchestra	playing a symphony	2389.678306386666
8967. harmony melody counterpoint symphonic structure	are there; and as this music ebbs and flows there is an antiphonal	chorus from all the atoms outside in fact from the atoms of	the entire universe	3552.9747507289417
8968. and so today when we examine the structure of our	knowledge of the atom and of the universe we are forced to conclude	that the best word to describe our universe is music	5329.749647099425
8969. the island of nantucket part of the state of massachusetts	lies about thirty-one miles southeast of its mother state	1731.605355833569

8975. to what extent and in what ways did christianity affect	the united states of america in the nineteenth century	1727.5280098987962

9007. thus america the most widely sung of the patriotic	songs was written by a new england baptist clergyman samuel francis	smith while a student in andover theological	seminary	2979.3590690532833

9021. a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or	remove social ills	939.1880665506256

9023. several of the movements were given a marked	impetus by revivalism	501.8181880229672
9024. quakers some from new england had a larger	share than their proportionate numerical strength would have warranted	2117.399939142505
9025. we do well to remind ourselves that from men and women of new england	ancestry also issued the church of jesus christ of latter	day saints the seventh day adventists christian science the	american board of commissioners for foreign missions the american	home missionary society the american bible society and new	england theology	5140.3426715273945
9026. the atmosphere was one of optimism of confidence	in human progress and of a determination to rid the world of its ills	3247.3265989550055
9027. the hopkinsian universal disinterested benevolence although holding	to original sin and the doctrine of election inspired its adherents	to heroic endeavours for others looked for the early coming of the	millennium and was paralleled by the confidence in man's ability	cherished by the unitarians emerson and the transcendentalists	4818.490058813854
9028. we should recall the number of movements for the service of mankind	which arose from the kindred evangelicalism of the british isles	and the pietism of the continent of europe- among them prison	reform anti-slavery measures legislation for the alleviation of conditions	of labour the inner mission and the red cross	7524.684193231585
9029. we	cannot take the space to record all the efforts for the removal or alleviation	of collective ills	1580.9398956609707
9030. a few of the more prominent must serve	as examples of what a complete listing and description would disclose	2613.2285851750557
9031. several were born in the early decades and persisted throughout the	century	649.3100222225542
9032. some disappeared with the attainment	of their purpose	248.161245600806
9033. still others sprang up late in the century to meet	conditions which arose from fresh stages of the revolutionary age	1893.4246921233785
9034. anti-slavery movement	the movement to end negro slavery began	before 1815 and mounted after that year until as a result of the civil	war emancipation was achieved	4297.241262396632
9035. long before 1815 the christian	conscience was leading some to declare slavery wrong and to act	accordingly	1422.5505449578495
9036. for example in 1693 the philadelphia yearly meeting	of friends declared that its members should emancipate their slaves	and in 1776 it determined to exclude from membership all who did not	comply	5145.16604786139
9037. in the latter year samuel hopkins from whom the hopkinsian	strain of new england theology took its name asked the continental	congress to abolish slavery	2602.469946974686
9038. as we have seen methodism early took	a stand against slavery	754.7922927700413
9039. beginning at least as far back as 1789 various	baptist bodies condemned slavery	795.9024688131374
9040. after 1815 anti-slavery	sentiment mounted chiefly among protestants and those of protestant	background of the older stock	2119.479641818179
9041. the nineteenth-century immigration	whether protestant or roman catholic was not so much concerned	for very few if any among them held slaves: they were mostly in the	northern states where slavery had disappeared or was on the way out	or were too poverty-stricken to own slaves	4692.876371692104
9042. the anti-slavery movement	took many forms	64.95410786757215
9043. benjamin lundy a quaker was	a pioneer in preparing the way for anti-slavery societies	943.3592431844532
9044. it was	he who turned the attention of william lloyd garrison	to the subject	1420.42570214961
9045. garrison massachusetts born of nova scotian parentage	was by temperament and conviction a reformer	936.6429928375886
9046. chiefly remembered	because of his incessant advocacy of immediate and unconditional	abolition he also espoused a great variety of other causes- among	them women's rights prohibition and justice to the indians	5009.069679040722
9047. incurably	optimistic dogmatic and utterly fearless in his youth a devout	baptist in spite of his friendship for the quaker poet john	greenleaf whittier he eventually attacked the orthodox	churches for what he deemed their cowardly compromising on the slavery	issue and in his invariably ardent manner was emphatically unorthodox	and denied the plenary inspiration of the bible	5423.691916698868
9048. a marked	impulse came to the anti-slavery movement through the finney revivals	968.1588745100574
9049. finney himself while opposed to slavery placed his chief emphasis	on evangelism but from his converts issued much of the leadership of	the anti-slavery campaign	2595.387060942624
9050. theodore dwight weld was	especially active	65.41987026606735
9051. weld was the son and grandson of new england congregational	ministers	498.77421240950025
9052. as a youth he became one of finney's band	of evangelists and gave himself to winning young men	2346.914346393828
9053. a strong temperance	advocate through the influence of a favorite teacher charles	stewart another finney convert he devoted himself to the anti-slavery	cause	2330.8162971479023
9054. a group of young men influenced by him enrolled in lane theological	seminary and had to leave because of their open anti-slavery	position	3476.11580409292
9055. the majority then went to the infant oberlin	166.21675979369147
9056. they and	others employed some of finney's techniques as they sought to win	adherents to the cause	2118.54654589142
9057. weld contributed to the anti-slavery convictions	of such men as joshua r giddings and edwin m stanton	enlisted john quincy adams and helped provide ideas which underlay	harriet beecher stowe's uncle tom's cabin	3579.0124411506126
9058. he shunned	publicity for himself and sought to avoid fame	560.1253981902048
9059. wendell phillips	from a prominent massachusetts family in his teens	was converted under the preaching of lyman beecher	1573.1531020866908
9060. although he	later broke with the churches because he believed that they were insufficiently	outspoken against social evils he remained a devout christian	3466.765119610421
9061. he was remembered chiefly for his fearless advocacy of abolition	but he also stood for equal rights for women for opportunity for the	freedmen and for prohibition	2853.2415384499573
9062. the anti-slavery movement and	other contemporary reforms and philanthropies were given leadership	and financial undergirding by arthur tappan and his younger	brother lewis tappan	3687.385875782832
9063. individuals possessing unusual gifts and great personal power	were transmuted at death into awesome spirits; they were almost immediately	worshipped for these newer even more terrible abilities	2860.418099232898
9064. their	direct descendants inherited not only their worldly fortunes but also	the mandate of their newfound power as spirits in the other half of	the universe	4093.786275331144
9065. royal lineages could be based on extraordinary worldly	achievements translated into eternal otherworldly power	941.1341677156128
9066. thus	the emperor could draw on sources not available to those with less	puissant ancestors	1634.7459259994462
9067. but this eminence was not without its weighty	responsibilities	259.26948692547
9068. since he possessed more power in an interdependent universe	of living beings and dead spirits the emperor had to use it for	the benefit of the living	4297.084954409209
9069. the royal ritual generated power into the	other world: it also provided the living with a way to control the	spirits and bring their powers directly to bear on the everyday affairs	of the world	3772.183315842159
9070. proper ritual observance at any level of society was	capable of generating power for use in the spirit world; but naturally	the royal ritual which provided unusual control over already supremely	powerful divine spirits was held responsible for regulating the	universe and insuring the welfare of the kingdom	7238.004863453107
9071. this is the	familiar system of cosmic government	167.4168662052721
9072. the chinese emperor by	proper observance of ritual manifested divine powers	745.2770785493445
9073. he regulated	the dualities of light and darkness yang and yin which are	locked in eternal struggle	1414.7673165081337
9074. by swaying the balance between them he	effected the alternation of the seasons	1182.1027134056933
9075. his power was so great that	he even promoted and demoted gods according to whether they had given	ear or been deaf to petitions	2466.575260725716
9076. in this system no man is exempt	from obligations	394.39934502520947
9077. failure in daily moral and ethical duties to one's	family outrages to community propriety any departure from rigid	standards of moral excellence were offenses against the dead	2849.6884732314684
9078. and to	offend the dead meant to incur their wrath and thus provoke the unleashing	of countrywide disasters	2363.522882366147
9079. the family home was in fact a temple;	and the daily duties of individuals were basically religious in	nature	1717.9668532882447
9080. the dead spirits occupied a prominent place in every hope and	in every fear	1427.736259841339
9081. the common belief was that there existed one	moral order which included everything	784.8126902684711
9082. the dead controlled the material	prosperity of the living and the living adhered to strict codes of	conduct in order not to weaken that control	3879.885433448252
9083. men believed they could	control nature by obeying a moral code	503.0999608865268
9084. if the moral code were flouted	the proper balance of the universe would be upset and the disastrous	result could be floods plague or famine	3896.526183057658
9085. modern westerners	have difficulty comprehending this fusion of moral and material	largely because in the west the historical trend has been to deny the	connection	2599.35595601016
9086. living in urban conditions away from the deadweight of	village constraint and the constrictions of a thatched-roof world view	the individual may find it possible say to commit adultery not only	without personal misgivings but also without suffering any adverse	effects in his worldly fortunes	6921.291901598255
9087. basing action on the empirical determination	of cause and effect provides a toughness and bravado that no	powerful otherworldly ancestor could ever impart- plus the added liberation	from the constraint of silent burial urns	3670.407836523006
9088. in china	the magical system par excellence was taoism	392.36952821392725
9089. the taoists were quietist	mystics who saw an unchanging unity- the tao- underlying	all phenomena	1094.755420634065
9090. it was this timeless unity that was all-important and	not its temporary manifestations in the world of reality	2344.8752135017326
9091. the taoists	believed the unity could be influenced by proper magical manipulation;	in other words they were actually an organization of magicians	2167.948346035274
9092. mahayana buddhism was no exception to these prevailing magical	concepts	563.222111867943
9093. after this form of indian buddhism had been introduced	into china it underwent extensive changes	1099.9915437323873
9094. during its flowering in	the sixth to the eighth centuries mahayana offered a supernatural package	to the chinese which bears no resemblance to the highly digested	philosophical zen morsels offered to the modern western reader	5654.701430959887
9095. mahayana	had gods and magic a pantheon heavens and hells and gorgeously	appareled priests monks and nuns all of whom wielded power over	souls in the other world	3001.709707285269
9096. the self-realized mahayana saint possessed	superhuman powers and magic	392.58333210701414
9097. the mahayana that developed in the	north was a religion of idolatry and coarse magic that made the world	into a huge magical garden	2481.3670817276784
9098. in its monastic form mahayana was merely	an organization of magic-practicing monks who catered	to the chinese faith in the supernatural	3034.782369850728
9099. nonmagical confucianism	was a secular rational philosophy but even with this different	orientation it could not escape from the ethos of a cosmic government	2468.320455595628
9100. confucianism had its own magic in the idea that virtue had power	962.5125717717816
9101. if a man lived a classical life he need not fear the spirits- for	only lack of virtue gave the spirits power over him	2472.733686016117
9102. but let us not be	mistaken about confucian virtue; this was not virtue as we	understand the word today and it did not mean an abandonment of the belief	in magic manipulation	5158.784517731181
9103. to the confucian virtue simply meant	mastery and correct observance of three hundred major rules of ritual	and three thousand minor ones	2172.8532928898035
9104. propriety was synonymous with ritual	observance the mark of a true gentleman	961.2628392682188
9105. to live correctly in an	interdependent moral and material universe of living and dead was decisive	for man's fate	1728.7551454146057
9106. this in brief was the historical background	out of which zen emerged	958.9897246093212
9107. promoters of zen to the west record	its ancestry and recognize that zen grew out of a combination of	taoism and indian mahayana buddhism	2467.100622682919
9108. but the marvelous person	that is supposed to result from zen exhibits more chinese practicality	than indian speculation- he possesses magical powers and can	use them to order nature and to redeem souls	5347.5601519273605
9109. proponents of zen to	the west emphasize disproportionately the amount of mahayana buddhism	in zen probably in order to dignify the indisputably magical taoist	ideas with more respectable buddhist metaphysic	3232.7316556191467
9110. but in the chinese	mind there was little difference between the two- the bonzes	were no more metaphysical than a magician has to be	3696.5171225927224
9111. actually	zen owes more to chinese quietism than it does to mahayana buddhism	790.2710330358784
9112. the ch'an sect may have derived its metaphysic from	mahayana but its psychology was pure early taoist	2126.523026050226
9113. this is well	evidenced	by the quietist doctrines carried over in zen: the idea of	the inward turning of thought the enjoinder to put aside desires and	perturbations so that a return to purity peace and stillness- a	union with the infinite with the tao- could be effected	4834.550475081853
9114. in fact	the antipathy to outward ceremonies hailed by modern exponents as so	uniquely characteristic of the direct thinking zennist was a feature	of taoism	3904.89393052667
9115. so too was the insistence on the relativity of the	external world and the ideas that language and things perceived by	consciousness were poor substitutes indeed for immediate perception by	pure indwelling spirit: the opposition of pure consciousness to ratiocinating	consciousness	4320.084313667186
9116. zen maintains that cognitive things	are only the surface of experience	754.1062266698206
9117. one of its features attractive	to the west is its irreverence for tradition and dogma and for sacred	texts	1739.4886509139747
9118. one patriarch is supposed to have relegated sacred scriptures	for use in an outhouse	1401.2761815100564
9119. but this is not the spirit of self-reliant freedom	of action for which the westerner mistakes it	1410.6481204006298
9120. it is simply that	in taoist tradition- as in all good mysticisms- books words	or any other manifestations that belong to the normal state of consciousness	are considered only the surface of experience	5341.671215510005
9121. the truth- the	eternal truth- is not transmittable by words	375.7338257809264
9122. reality is considered	not only irrelevant to the acquisition of higher knowledge but	a positive handicap	1882.9707898067554
9123. the technique of reality confusion- the use of	paradox and riddles to shake the mind's grip on reality- originated	with fourth and third century bc chinese quietism: the	koan is not basically a new device	3774.859839377403
9124. it is important for an	understanding of zen to realize that the esoteric preoccupations of	the select few cannot be the doctrine of the common man	4079.113067718635
9125. in the supernatural	atmosphere of cosmic government only the ruling elite was ever	concerned with a kingdom-wide ordering of nature: popular religion	aimed at more personal benefits from magical powers	3244.8701656733597
9126. and this is only	natural- witness the haste with which modern man gobbles the latest	wonder drug	2131.6138358889903
9127. early chinese anchoritism was theoretically aimed	at a mystic pantheist union with the divine personal salvation being	achieved when the mystical recluse united with divine essence	2749.6242678293256
9128. but	this esoteric doctrine was lost in the shuffle to acquire special powers	1176.867382304711
9129. the anchorite strove in fact to magically influence the world	of spirits in the same way that the divine emperor manifested his power	2320.238014628806
9130. thus the mahayana metaphysic of mystical union for salvation was	distilled down to a bare self-seeking and for this reason the mystic	in asia did not long remain in isolated contemplation	4988.853259606403
9131. as the zen	literature reveals as soon as an early zen master attained fame in	seclusion he was called out into the world to exercise his powers	2861.365670742728
9132. the early anchorite masters attracted disciples because of their presumed	ability to perform miracles	1401.8053495244396

9135. but	actually these accounts reveal the supernatural powers that the masters	were in fact supposed to possess as well as the extreme degree of	popular credulity: hwang pah one day going up mount	tien tai h which was believed to have been inhabited by arhats	with supernatural powers met with a monk whose eyes emitted strange light	5369.436944631721

9643. schnabel's emphasis	on structural clarity his innate rhythmic vibrancy and impetuous	intensity all tend to stamp his reading as a symphonic one	3284.3863543903926
9644. yet no	detail was too small to receive attention from this master and as a	result the playing here has humor delicacy and radiant humanity	2620.4817896936274
9645. this	is a serious-minded interpretation but it is never strait-laced	564.4711013525739
9646. and	although schnabel's pianism bristles with excitement it is meticulously	faithful to schubert's dynamic markings and phrase indications	1578.0858296834444
9647. the piano performance on this trout is one that really demands	a search for superlatives	1654.4231917713091
9648. about the pro arte's contribution	i am less happy	261.99088011741685
9649. i for one rather regret that schnabel didn't	collaborate with the budapest quartet whose rugged athletic	playing was a good deal closer to this pianist's interpretative outlook	than the style of the belgian group	5481.875285325694
9650. from a technical standpoint	the string playing is good but the pro arte people fail to enter	into the spirit of things here	2323.445313569676
9651. the violinist in particular is very	indulgent with swoops and slides and his tone is pinched and edgy	2371.9347040183375
9652. the twenty-five-year-old recording offers rather faded string tone	but the balance between the instruments is good and the transfer is very	quiet	2188.875944669219
9653. there is a break in continuity just before the fourth variation	in the forellen movement and i suspect that this is	due to imperfect splicing between sides of the original sps	4975.841688666851
9654. turning to the more modern versions curzon's offers	the most sophisticated keyboard work	793.7254559651223

9670. must records always sound like records	43.80310346652689
9671. from the beginning	of commercial recording new discs purported to be indistinguishable	from the real thing have regularly been put in circulation	3268.802196061889
9672. seen	in perspective many of these releases have a genuine claim to be milestones	944.3366652725365
9673. although lacking absolute verisimilitude they supply the	ear and the imagination with all necessary materials for re-creation	of the original	2824.7227778912884
9674. on the basis of what they give us we can know how the	young caruso sang appreciate the distinctive qualities of parsifal	under karl muck's baton or sense the type of ensemble toscanini	created in his years with the new york philharmonic	4381.421771125593
9675. since	the concept of high fidelity became important some dozen years ago	the claims of technical improvements have multiplied tenfold	2826.2078051625554
9676. in many	cases the revolutionary production has offered no more than sensational	effects: the first hearing was fascinating and the second disillusioning	as the gap between sound and substance became clearer	3346.5955046128415
9677. other	innovations with better claims to musical interest survived rehearing	to acquire in time the status of classics	2341.4223784977285
9678. if we return to them today	we have no difficulty spotting their weaknesses but we find them	still pleasing	1715.889979293211
9679. records sound like records because they provide	a different sort of experience than live music	1642.7592417281953
9680. this difference is	made up of many factors	167.50980988240715
9681. some of them are obvious such as the fact	that we associate recorded and live music with our reponses and behavior	in different types of environments and social settings	4625.713012101883
9682. sounds best to me when i can dress informally and sit in something	from the technical standpoint	records differ from live music to the degree that they fail to convey	the true color texture complexity range intensity pulse and pitch	of the original	4460.611198115482
9683. any alteration of one of these factors is distortion	although we generally use that word only for effects so pronounced	that they can be stated quantitatively on the basis of standard tests	5167.586645838923
9684. yet it is the accumulation of distortion the fitting together of	fractional bits until the total reaches the threshold of our awareness	that makes records sound like records	2979.277932152715
9685. the sound may be good;	but if you know the real thing you know that what you are hearing	is only a clever imitation	3727.2492029836785
9686. command's new brahms second is	a major effort to make a record that sounds like a real orchestra rather	than a copy of one	2476.7231677867367
9687. like the recent scheherazade from london	it is successful because emphasis	has been placed on good musical and engineering practices rather than	on creating sensational effects	4084.047509827149
9688. because of this only those with	truly fine equipment will be able to appreciate the exact degree of the	engineers' triumph	2036.215910787331
9689. the easiest way to describe this release	is to say that it reproduces an interesting and effective steinberg	performance with minimal alteration of its musical values	4084.5857980431365
9690. the engineering	as such never obtrudes upon your consciousness	260.8737099546964
9691. the effect of	the recording is very open and natural with the frequency emphasis	exactly what you would expect from a live performance	3517.2239750863323
9692. this absence of	peaky highs and beefed-up bass not only produces greater fidelity but	it eliminates listener fatigue	1570.5101564248562
9693. a contributing factor is the perspective	the uniform aesthetic distance which is maintained	1190.61895368317
9694. the orchestra	is far enough away from you that you miss the bow scrapes valve	clicks and other noises incidental to playing	2175.4982178657506
9695. yet you feel the orchestra	is near at hand and the individual instruments have the same firm	presence associated with listening from a good seat in an acoustically	perfect hall	4853.8480424273685
9696. command has achieved the ideal amount of reverberation	165.838583385949
9697. the music is always allowed the living space needed to attain its	full sonority; yet the hall never intrudes as a quasi-performer	3282.855731897815
9698. the	timbre remains that of the instruments unclouded by resonance	372.17671885001266
9699. all of this would be wasted of course if the performance lacked	authority and musical distinction	1891.0500090148369
9700. for me it has more of both elements	than the majority of its competitors	946.2493162247969
9701. steinberg seems to have gone	directly back to the score discounting tradition and has built his	performance on the intention to reproduce as faithfully as possible exactly	what brahms set down on paper	5359.537231981007
9702. those accustomed to broader	more romantic statements of the symphony can be expected to react	strongly when they hear this one	2028.017524795343
9703. without losing the distinctive undertow	of brahmsian rhythm the pacing is firm and the over-all performance	has a tightly knit quality that makes for maximum cumulative effect	4275.7846684582055
9704. the presto ma non assai of the first trio of the scherzo is	taken literally and may shock you as the real allegro con spirito	of the finale is likely to bring you to your feet	3856.294660322628
9705. in the end however	the thing about this performance that is most striking is the way	it sings	2355.9252361250965
9706. steinberg obviously has concluded that it is the lyric element	which must dominate in this score and he manages at times to create	the effect of the whole orchestra bursting into song	3438.752250061404
9707. the	engineering provides exactly the support needed for such a result	758.2750587606388
9708. too	many records seem to reduce a work of symphonic complexity to a melody	and its accompaniment	1417.9355492730813
9709. the command technique invites you to listen	to the depth of the orchestration	1185.4927873754664
9710. your ear takes you into the ensemble	and you may well become aware of instrumental details which previously	were apparent only in the score	2453.7258339775576
9711. it is this sort of experience	that makes the concept of high fidelity of real musical significance	for the home music listener	3255.401660971095
9712. the first substantially complete stereo giselle	of its scope since feyer's four-sided lp edition of 1958 for	this set is i'm afraid likely to provide more horrid fascination	than enjoyment	3221.7482613882066
9713. the already faded pastel charms of the nai^ve	music itself vanish entirely in fistoulari's melodramatic contrasts	between ultravehement brute power and chilly if suave sentimentality	3899.931884418072

9715. the home listener	is overpowered all right but the experience is a far from pleasant	one	1899.1693202902381

9887. the design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical	puzzle but once understood the principles can be applied to	any track and signal arrangement	2847.7918225086487
9888. in the frame are two sets of bars	which interact with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous	moves	3048.5167031287087
9889. the main set of bars are the tappets and one tappet	is connected to each lever	1259.4026572654047
9890. if the lever is pulled to clear a signal	or move a switch the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at	the same time	3706.882267260361
9891. close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking	bars	502.58891553804096
9892. these can also move a short distance but at right angles	to the tappets	1413.8043074994123
9893. the number of locking bars required depends on how many	false moves must be prevented	1096.5011249226504
9894. in the sides of the tappets	are notches with sloping sides and connection between the tappets and	locking bars consist of cams called dogs	3682.0075462732784
9895. two or more dogs are	mounted on each locking bar	376.87075476104616
9896. these slide into and out of the notches	in the tappets as the tappets are moved locking and unlocking them	2827.814569057956
9897. here's how the scheme works: suppose the operator pulls	the lever to clear a particular signal	1253.7612247865413
9898. this also pulls the tappet connected	to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches	to the side thus moving one or more locking bars	4495.69308387697
9899. the dogs on the	other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other	tappets	1574.362008417044
9900. by this scheme pulling one signal to clear locks all the	other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal	is again restored to normal	4472.325922945285
9901. interlocking signals are normally	at stop or red position and a lever must be pulled to clear	the signal	1725.9549705739246
9902. this is not necessarily to green however for in	some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it	into the plant	4097.283015843209
9903. there are other basic rules	14.802397091639824
9904. a turnout	may have two levers one to actually move the switch points the other	to lock the points	2604.1006871278173
9905. a signal cannot be cleared until all the related	turnouts are properly thrown and locked	1099.954730801489
9906. such locks are nearly	always used where the switch points face oncoming traffic	1187.2641600028023
9907. the	lock insures that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that	a wheel flange will snag on a partly thrown point	2603.0922251035126
9908. if the points aren't	thrown all the way the turnout cannot be locked and in turn	the signal cannot be cleared	3043.4691511249875
9909. generally these locks on turnouts are	called facing point locks	374.23461026547164
9910. figs 1-6 show typical arrangements	of track and signals	391.8602263785334
9911. each diagram is accompanied by a dog	chart a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular	lever will lock if pulled	2598.0113113324633
9912. the lines connecting the wedge-shaped	dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars	2121.658345226989
9913. by studying the track-signal diagrams you'll note several	other details	371.95913025180056
9914. derails- mechanical track devices that actually guide	the wheels off the rails if a train passes a stop signal- are	used in many instances	3702.5203700362363
9915. home signals have two blades	14.826252383390345
9916. the blacked-in	blades indicate a fixed aspect- the blade does not move	966.9091559854512
9917. as	an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal	is seen in advance when he passes the distant signal located	beyond the limits of the interlocking plant	3222.825180858475
9918. in some low-speed situations	the distant signal is fixed at caution	756.2575439297015
9919. in other instances where	there is no automatic block signaling the distant has only green	and yellow aspects	1577.4392788253883
9920. so much for the prototype	22.23219339190524
9921. the interlocking	frame we built at the model railroader workshop and then	installed on paul larson's railroad follows the fig 1 scheme	and is shown beginning in fig 7 page 65 and in the photos	3769.1820072889504
9922. here's	how it can be built	65.1241412303241
9923. the sizes of pieces needed	for the interlocking frame are shown in the notes within fig 7 most	of the bars being 18'' brass in 14'' and 12'' widths	3112.9998788334174
9924. you may change the dimensions to suit a frame for more or fewer levers	and locks as you wish	2610.2162000965313

9926. when cutting	the pieces dress the ends smooth and square with a smooth file or sanding	disk	2125.328163794601

9936. these will be drilled	and tapped later on	249.25210449170322
9937. now cut five f locking bar spacers		43.488065760399934
9938. position these using six intermediate temporary	f spacers and locate the upper 12'' bar a	1658.9338325755773

9941. cap with a f	bar and tack-solder in place	262.20971062289516
9942. cap the locking bar spacers with two	f directly under the first two b pieces	1658.2536769442595
9943. remove all the	loose spacing bars	43.45322459328453

9946. drill all no 50 and	counter-drill all except the a pieces size 43	1190.205838852168
9947. tap the a	pieces 2-56	14.898377577266325

9961. remove all other loose	pieces and file the edges of the basic frame smooth	940.6264424202916
9962. cut five pieces	of f brass bar stock 3-34'' long	556.635964860375
9963. these are supporting members	for the short locking bars	261.7485407179289
9964. locate their positions in fig 7 and	drill no 43 to match the corresponding holes in the frame	2355.7492007437427
9965. cut off	excess screw lengths and file flush with either frame or nut	786.8863445651584
9966. drill	four no 19 and four no 28 holes in the 12'' long a	pieces	1657.604227862616
9967. locate the position from fig 7	43.967223968723694
9968. bars	draw-file no 1 tappet to a smooth fit in its respective	slot and square the ends	2125.4653743940235
9969. break the end corners with a slight 45 degree	chamfer	377.6191525303732
9970. drill a no 50 hole 1-14'' from one end and tap	2-56	963.9177025582092
9971. put a 2-56 roundhead screw into the hole cut	off the excess threads and file flush with the underside of the bar	2186.7722483104494
9972. to find the other stop screw position insert the tappet into the frame	and hold the screw head tight against the frame edge	3492.5568193137274
9973. scribe a line	across the bar on the other end of the tappet 14'' plus half the	diameter of the 2-56 screw head away from the frame	edge	2987.7366806416385
9974. total distance is about 2164''	22.32987192286973
9975. tend to make this dimension	slightly undersize so you can file the screw head to get exactly	14'' tappet movement	1888.6165402186816
9976. drill a no 50 hole tap 2-56 and insert	a roundhead 2-56 screw as you did on the first end	2827.8615876588765

9980. these	will serve as lifting pads for the electrical contacts	566.2595554924592
9981. fitting	the locking bars and making the locking pieces is a rather tedious job	since stop screws tappets and locking bars must be removed and replaced	many times	2989.313786118648
9982. as the work progresses the frame and moving parts become	a sort of chinese puzzle where several pieces must be removed before	the part you are working on is accessible	4839.802327317962
9983. a little extra work	here will pay off with a smooth snug-fitting machine when you are finished	1428.1238539688338

9985. the order of fitting is not	too important	167.1750061155392

9988. figs 7 and 8 give all pertinent dimensions	249.27526236616782
9989. all the bars are cut from f brass	167.18131502311127
9990. the lengths of each piece are	listed at the bottom of fig 7	1182.6611813806287

9993. fig 8 gives	the dimensions for locating the dog-pin holes	377.189022230687

9997. file the bottom edge flush with the bar and the top 18''	above the bar	1101.006836596009

10001. see the drawings for the shape	of the notch	262.13335291988824

10015. scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on	mathematics	787.1836117661221
10016. without math the men who are continually seeking the causes	of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go 'round	would not have any means of analyzing standardizing and communicating	the things they discover and learn	6348.172620377951
10017. math and the formulas that	allow it to be applied to different problems are therefore essential	to any scientific endeavor	1869.7481799183638
10018. hot rodding is a science	22.366606018720947
10019. it's	not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth rotate	on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit	but it is nevertheless a science	3464.0360290939907
10020. but because science is based on mathematics	doesn't mean that a hot rodder must necessarily be a mathematician	2357.3513142910897
10021. a guy can be an active and successful hot rodder for years	without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems;	however he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and	the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few	formulas that apply to rodding	5045.2117102446255
10022. a mathematical formula is nothing	more than a pattern for solving a specific problem	1421.066113735858
10023. it places the	various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation	to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can	be computed	3229.107898463309
10024. the first step in using a formula is to insert the	numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions	in the formula	3687.80253730912
10025. this changes the formula to an equation	93.32490816505161
10026. the	equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem	965.6645093839376
10027. equations for rodding formulas are not complicated	93.73790146202636
10028. they involve	only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic	classes	1171.2089032775652
10029. however it is essential that the various mathematical symbols	used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes	can be done properly and in their correct order	3110.076417858107
10030. they indicate	simple division multiplication subtraction and addition	250.32019075115485
10031. the	symbol for division is a straight line that separates two numbers	placed one above the other	1417.0940130086212
10032. the lower number is always divided into the	upper number: f   the symbol for multiplication is 	1128.2590572312115
10033. it is used to separate two or more numbers in a row	646.496187810289
10034. for example:	f numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any	order	1395.2105606748084
10035. the result will be the same regardless of the order used	502.4137530769053
10036. the symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign	392.0418655589268
10037. this is	nothing more than a dash	94.67706778323256
10038. it separates two or more numbers	65.72104576548875
10039. the number	on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on	the left of the symbol	1889.3913596110706
10040. for example: f when more than two figures	are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried	out from the left to right if the result is to be correct	5006.699345950559
10041. for example	for the problem f 10 from 25 equals 15 then 6 from 15 equals	9	1431.7680731187675
10042. addition is indicated by the + symbol	30.25368184940753
10043. the symbol is	used to separate two or more numbers	377.22298133351234
10044. for example: f numbers separated	by addition symbols may be placed in any order	1397.359413477069
10045. when solving	an equation that involves division as well as other steps do all	the division steps first	to reduce those parts of the equation to their	numerical value	3106.172345792709
10046. multiplication subtraction and addition can then	be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left	end of the equation and working toward the right	4459.9676572503995
10047. completing the	division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication	subtraction or addition steps: f this would be reduced	by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12	3556.6925999939754
10048. this part	of the equation would then become 4	392.2354051980905
10049. for use in formulas fractions	should be converted to their decimal equivalents	643.3124655511107
10050. the easiest	way to do this is with a conversion chart	754.1351904621886
10051. charts for this purpose	are available from many sources	261.4015504304667
10052. they are included in all types of mathematical	handbooks and they are stamped on some types of precision	measuring instruments	2809.94430182638
10053. the various mathematical processes can	be simplified by carrying the results to only two or three decimal places	1580.7304845219492
10054. shortening the results in this manner will not have any detrimental	effect on the accuracy of the final result	2581.2851461888445
10055. a constant is a number that remains the same	regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant	equation	2176.9421954708855
10056. it is a number without which the equation cannot be solved	correctly	958.6529073501782
10057. rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport	261.51931629436456
10058. the answers they give can often pave the way to performance increases	and	quite often are necessary for completing entry blanks for different	events	3682.9061388085706
10059. when it is needed one formula is as important as another	504.10181493325643
10060. however some formulas are used more than others	252.00801921942676
10061. we'll take	them in the general order of their popularity	373.9055326885066
10062. a rodder should be able to compute the displacement of his engine	959.3815390060897
10063. displacement is sometimes referred to as swept volume	166.49462316630516
10064. most	entry blanks for competitive events require engine displacement information	because of class restrictions	1406.2352537961904
10065. it is good to be able to compute	displacement so that changes in it resulting from boring and stroking	can be computed	2175.0907510432494
10066. factors involved in the displacement formula	are the bore diameter of the engine's cylinders the length of the	piston stroke the number of cylinders in the engine and a constant	4825.319354428253
10067. 7854 which is one-quarter of 3	43.335383701709745
10068. 1416 another constant	known as pi	65.1582825872018
10069. pi is used in formulas concerned with the dimensions	of circles	500.99983025059555
10070. actually the engine displacement formula is	the standard formula for computing the volume of a cylinder of any type	with an added factor that represents the number of cylinders in the	engine	5155.222064646344
10071. the cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and	then the volume of the individual cylinders is computed by multiplying	the area by the stroke length which is the equivalent of the length	of the cylinders	3851.412939103324
10072. multiplying the result by the number of cylinders	in the engine gives the engine's total displacement	1874.8242408875103
10073. dimensions in inches and fractions of inches will give	the displacement in cubic inches	943.3944800902524
10074. dimensions in centimeters and fractions	of centimeters will give the displacement in cubic centimeters		808.0339338924875
10075. 54 centimeters: one cubic inch equals 16	94.11541177044211
10076. for example let's consider a standard	283 cubic inch chevy v8	756.0756309334691
10077. these engines have a cylinder diameter	of 3-78 inches and a stroke length of 3 inches	1253.410703862292
10078. the formula with	the fractions converted to decimals becomes f	559.3295683825588
10079. to arrive	at the answer multiply the numbers together by starting at the left of	the group and working to the right	2176.3476813021607
10080. the different steps will look like	this: f	a cylinder's compression ratio	is computed by comparing the cylinder's volume or its displacement	with the total volume of the cylinder and its combustion chamber	5344.878421078245
10081. cylinder volume can be determined mathematically but combustion chamber	volume must be measured with a liquid	1252.6181059981916
10082. cylinder volume is	determined in exactly the same manner as for the displacement formula:	f	1648.8244913933675
10083. to measure the volume of one of the combustion chambers	in the cylinder head install the valves and spark plug in the chamber	and support the head so that its gasket surface is level	3665.1399397448026
10084. then pour	water or light oil from a graduated beaker into the chamber to fill	the chamber to its gasket surface	3076.4895237277497
10085. do not overfill the chamber	14.874827599375285
10086. this	is possible with water and other liquids that have a high surface tension	1411.3310552948499
10087. such liquids will rise to a considerable height above the surface	around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber	2172.977553506706
10088. the amount of liquid poured into the chamber is determined by subtracting	the quantity still in the beaker when the chamber is full from	the original quantity	4301.144951269382
10089. most beakers are graduated in cubic centimeters	making it necessary to convert the result to cubic inches	1415.6382137070214
10090. however the displacement of the cylinder can be converted to cubic	centimeters	962.1142303724439
10091. the compression ratio arrived at with the formula will	be the same regardless of whether cubic inches or cubic centimeters are	used	2177.037650482719
10092. the only precaution is that all volumes used in the formula be	quoted in the same terms	2110.837291675643
10093. the volume of the cylinder opening	in the head gasket must be computed by multiplying its area in square	inches by the gasket's thickness in thousandths of an inch	3099.404585256724
10094. sometimes	it is necessary to roughly calculate the square inch area of the opening	but the calculation can usually be made with sufficient accuracy	that it won't affect the final computation	5017.476512013616
10095. the volume of the opening	is added to the combustion chamber volume	644.0704174144549
10096. another thing	that must be taken into consideration is the volume of the area between	the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder block when the piston	is in top dead center position	5777.219975871033
10097. compute this volume by measuring	the distance from the top of the block to the piston head as accurately	as possible with a depth micrometer or some other precision measuring	device and then multiply the area of the cylinder by the depth	4414.404748057219
10098. the	formula for this step is: f this volume is added to the total volume	of the combustion chamber and head gasket opening	3488.907162579101
10099. the total of	these three volumes is the final combustion chamber volume	642.1615284829147
10100. after the factors just described have been computed they are applied	to the following formula: f   for an example let's dream	up an engine that has a final combustion chamber volume of 5 cubic	inches and a cylinder volume of 45 cubic inches	6673.66374585841
10101. applying these figures	to the formula we get the equation: f the compression ratio is	10 to 1	1576.2598479423136
10102. this method of computing compression ratio cannot be	used accurately for engines that have pistons with either domed or irregularly	shaped heads	3278.044789190028
10103. any irregularity on the piston heads will make	it impossible with normal means to determine the final combustion	chamber volume because the volume displaced by the piston heads cannot	be readily computed	3445.0175369220037
10104. the only way to determine the final combustion	chamber volume when such pistons are used is by measuring it with liquid	while the cylinder head is bolted to the cylinder block and the piston	is in top dead center position	6321.779261763329
10105. there are four versions of the formula that involves the relationships	of car speed engine speed rear axle gear ratio and rear tire	size	2450.2020061102635
10106. by using the appropriate version any one of these factors can	be determined for any combination of the other three	2815.2694189783892
10107. to simplify	the formulas a representative symbol is substituted for each of	the factors	943.6674713555265
10108. these are   mph for car speed   rpm	for engine crankshaft speed   r for rear axle gear ratio	w for tire size   tire size can be determined in	several ways but the one that is the easiest and as accurate as any is	by measuring the effective radius of a wheel and tire assembly	7707.052970401642
10109. this	is done by measuring the distance from the surface on which the tire	is resting to the center of the rear axle shaft	2465.0664449186143

10338. livery stable- j vernon prop coaching had declined	considerably by 1905 but the sign was still there near the old	wells fargo building in san francisco creaking in the fog as it	had for thirty years	3848.104057429181
10339. john vernon had had all the patronage he cared	for- he had prospered but he could not retire from horsedom	2840.386004064713
10340. coaching	was in his blood	14.713310928864194
10341. he had two interests in life: the pleasures	of the table and driving	1181.6580615023124
10342. twice a week he drove his tallyho over the	santa cruz road upland and through the redwood forest with orchards	below him at one hand and glimpses of the pacific at the other	3572.9498547393027
10343. the	journey back he made along the coast road traveling hell-for-leather	every lantern of the tallyho ablaze	2130.246881254451
10344. the southward route	was the classic run in california and the most fashionable	794.413071948215
10345. his patronage	on this stretch was made up largely of san franciscans- regulars	most of them and trenchermen like himself	2809.7619536258753
10346. they did not complain	at the inhuman hour of starting nor of the	tariff which was reasonable since it covered everything but the tobacco	2457.4344761152183
10347. breakfast was at the palace hotel luncheon was somewhere in the	mountain forest and dinner was either at boulder creek or at santa	cruz	3681.8289301407726
10348. gazing too long at the scenery could be tiring so	halts were contrived between meals	1098.8436175751503
10349. then the chinese hostler who rode	with vernon on the box would break open a hamper and produce filets	of smoked bass or sturgeon sandwiches pickled eggs and a rum sangaree	to be heated over a spirit lamp	6081.478844394542
10350. in spring and in autumn	the run was made for a group of botanists which included an old friend	of mine	2031.518060137681
10351. they gathered roots bulbs odd ferns leaves and bits of	resin from the rare santa lucia fir which exists only on a forty-five	mile strip on the westerly side of these mountains	5166.049008125625
10352. in the spanish	days franciscan monks roamed here to collect the resin for incense	935.8568629229783
10353. it yields a fragrance as orphic as that of the pastilles of malabar	1182.3982476766244
10354. vernon was serviceable on the botanical field trips but he could	arrange no schedule with the cooks and he was glad when the trips dropped	off and the botanists began to motor out by themselves	3765.461602901041
10355. my friend often breakfasted with vernon on the morning of the regular	tallyho run	1405.2242308429381
10356. this was an honor like dining with a captain at his private	table	791.4261626780701
10357. vernon's office adjoined the stable and the walls were	adorned with brightly colored lithographs the folk art of the period	2806.6503069074706
10358. they advertised harness polish liniments ball's rubber boots	green river whiskey hood's sarsaparilla patent medicines	shoe blacking and chewing tobacco	1881.875365431067
10359. the hostler would have the	table ready and a pot of coffee hissing on the stove; then a porter	from manning's fish house would trot in with a tray on his head	5185.524664818903
10360. it was draped with snowy napkins that kept hot a platter of oyster	salt roast and a mound of corn fritters	2044.4629977547258
10361. vernon was consummately fond	of oysters and manning's had been famous for them since the civil	war	2119.3528925431306
10362. oyster salt roast- oysters on the half shell cooked on a bed	of coarse salt that kept them hot when served- was a standby at manning's	2738.490717352518
10363. its early morning patrons were coachmen who fortified themselves	for the day with that delicacy	1639.8830103743107
10364. in the 1890's the	palace hotel began serving an oyster dish named after its manager john	c kirkpatrick	1582.2408827703475
10365. this dish much resembles the oysters rockefeller	made famous by antoine's in new orleans though the palace	chef announced it as a variant of manning's roast oysters	4294.400801681642
10366. have long argued about which came first the palace's or antoine's	506.25763593544616
10367. antoine's held as mandatory a splash of absinthe or pernod	on the parsley or spinach which was used for the underbedding	3048.2797460791357
10368. the	vernon however	held out for plain oyster roast and plenty of it unadorned by herbs	or any seasoning but salt though he did fancy a bit of lemon	3089.6177805119414
10369. after the meal he and his guests went out to inspect the rig; this	was merely a ritual to please all hands concerned	3473.7958225110633
10370. the tallyho had	cost vernon $2300	43.61097930605207
10371. a replica of two coaches made in england for the	belmont club in the east and matchless west of the rockies it	was the despair of whips on the santa cruz run	5177.617628272207
10372. one could shave in	the reflection of its french-polished panels and its axles were greased	like those of roulette wheels	1873.4696630966653
10373. the horses were groomed to a high	gloss; departing they stepped solemnly with knees lifted to the jaw	for they had been trained to drag at important funerals	4466.784856116216
10374. but	for the start of the santa cruz run the whip fell	645.2579722822976
10375. the clients boarded	the tallyho at the palace promptly at seven	752.4640202769505
10376. they had been fed	a hunting breakfast so called because a kedgeree the dish identified	with fox hunting was on the bill	2183.9288513205397
10377. there are many ways of making a	kedgeree every one of which is right	1418.5859599916223
10378. here is an original kedgeree	recipe from the family club's kitchen:	flake	a cupful of cold boiled haddock mix with a cupful of cooked	rice two minced hard-boiled eggs some buttery white sauce done	with cream cayenne pepper salt a pinch of curry a tablespoonful of	minced onion fried and a bit of anchovy	5232.6711185821205
10379. heat and serve hot on toast	65.64919270762012
10380. the omelet named for ernest arbogast the palace's chef	was even more in demand	943.5745343889937
10381. for decades it was the most popular dish	served in the ladies' grill at breakfast and it is one of the few	old palace dishes that still survive	4468.797432058242
10382. native california oysters	salty and piquant as coppery as delawares and not much larger than a	five-cent piece went into it	2027.7287226215408
10383. the original formula goes thus:	arbogast	fry in butter a small minced onion rub with a tablespoonful	of flour add half a cup of cream six beaten eggs pepper	celery salt a teaspoonful of minced chives a dash of cayenne and a	pinch of nutmeg	6933.139297034548
10384. a jigger of dry sherry follows and as the mixture	stiffens in go a hundred of the little oysters	1737.99179792174
10385. louis sherry	once stayed a fortnight at the palace and he was so pleased with omelet	arbogast that he introduced it at his restaurant in new york	4280.213589722417

10409. there was wright's for one lost amongst trees its wide	verandas strewn with rockers	1409.8218101053626

10412. acorns	from the great oaks fed the small black pigs	whose carcass sweepstakes were renowned	1098.6849517241205
10413. their ham butts cured	in oak-log smoke were also esteemed when roasted or boiled and served	with this original sauce:	put into	a saucepan a cupful of the baked ham gravy or of the boiled ham liquor	with a half stick of butter three teaspoonfuls of made mustard	and two mashed garlic cloves	7716.336313433376
10414. contribute also an onion a peeled tomato	and two pickled gherkins and a mashed lime	1106.655611416682

10416. then simmer fifteen	minutes longer	14.751191572368697
10417. every winter a kegful of this sauce was made	and placed at the end of a row of four other kegs in the cellar so	that when its turn came it was properly mellowed	5477.408926293189
10418. vineyards	and orchards also grew around wright's and deer were rather a nuisance;	they leaped six-foot fences with the agility of panthers	2175.778731681244

10424. the merit of the pie vernon believed	was due more to its making than to the waning heat of the oven	2032.3973318014355
10425. the recipe	which he got from the baker and wrote down in his ledger is basically	this:	peel core and slice across	enough apples to make a dome in the pie tin and set aside	5648.643386994574
10426. in a	saucepan put sufficient water to cover them an equal amount of sugar	a sliced lemon a tablespoonful of apricot preserve or jam a pinch each	of clove and nutmeg and a large bay leaf	3854.263163709751
10427. let this boil gently for	twenty minutes then strain	392.0286188461186
10428. poach the apples in this syrup for twelve	minutes drain them and cool	785.5984973139668
10429. set the apples in the pastry-lined	tin spread over them three tablespoonfuls of softened butter	with as much brown sugar a sprinkling of nutmeg and a fresh bay leaf	then lay on a cover of pastry and gild it with beaten yolk of egg	6801.3212719478815

10481. exposure problems may occur in these forest areas where uneven lighting	results from shafts of sunlight filtering through the overhead branches	2042.9575990048397
10482. best solution is to find an area that is predominantly sunlight	or shade	1184.1578287346997
10483. in any instance you should determine the exposure according	to the type of light which falls on most of the subject area	2192.5765596185406
10484. try some closeups on southern blossoms to provide a welcome contrast	with the many long-view scenics you'll be making	2591.100104255318

10523. built upon seven hills istanbul like rome is one of	the most ancient cities in the world filled with splendor and contrast	2194.3819132633025
10524. it is an exotic place so different from the ordinary that the casual	tourist is likely to see at first only the contrast and the ugliness	of narrow streets lined with haphazard houses	5337.324616594345
10525. at the moment many	of these are being pulled down	375.7948533801148
10526. whole blocks are disappearing and more	are scheduled to vanish to make room for wide boulevards that will	show off its treasures to better advantage- the great domes and graceful	spires of its mosques the panorama of the bosphorus and the golden	horn	6712.562107146837
10527. even when they are finished however the contrast will	remain for istanbul is the only city in the world that is built upon	two continents	2604.966930803619
10528. for almost 3000 years europe and asia have rubbed	shoulders in its streets	1176.4586081480668
10529. founded in the ninth century bc	it was called byzantium 200 years later when byzas ruler of	the megarians expanded the settlement and named it after himself	2850.039408592172
10530. about	a thousand years after that when the roman empire was divided	it became capital of the eastern section	2588.822173386984
10531. on may 11 330 ad	its name was changed again this time to constantinople after its	emperor constantine	1568.5128546287883
10532. in 1453 when the last vestige of ancient roman	power fell to the turks the city officially shifted religions-	although the patriarch or pope of the orthodox church continued	to live there and still does- and became the capital of the ottoman	empire	6699.870268449403
10533. when that was broken up after the first world war	its name was changed once more	1260.8988603516564
10534. rich in christian and moslem art	istanbul is today a fascinating museum of east and west that	recently	became a seaside resort as well with the development of new beaches on	the bosphorus and the sea of marmara only a short distance from the	center of town	7161.22526302764
10535. easy to get to and becoming more popular every year	it is only fourteen hours from new york by pan american world	airways jet four hours from rome	2994.9924068113805
10536. most of the	sights lie in the old section across the golden horn from the modern	hotels	2120.792366601427
10537. i started my tour of them at the turkish government tourist	office next to pan american's office on the left as you enter	the driveway that leads to the hilton hotel	3343.7374111110903
10538. from there i turned	left along cumhuriyet cadesi past more hotels and a park on the left	republic gardens and came in a few moments to taksim square one	of the hubs of the city with the monument of the republic erected	in 1928 in its center	7147.572355026108
10539. directly across from the gardens i	found a bus stop sign for t 4 and rode it down to the bosphorus	with the sports center on my left just before i reached the water and	the entrance to dolmabahce palace immediately after that	4474.848917949559
10540. there	the bus turned right along the bosphorus past ocean liners at anchor	to galata bridge over the entrance to the golden horn a brown sweep	of water that empties into the bosphorus	5332.696098679573
10541. across the bridge on	the left i saw st sophia with its sturdy brown minarets and to the	right of them the slenderer spires of the blue mosque	2993.1150462451383
10542. on	the other side of the golden horn i rode through eminonu square	with yeni cami or the new mosque which dates from the seventeenth	century just across from the entrance to the bridge	5500.79085356145
10543. passing it	the bus climbed a hill with the covered spice bazaar on the right and	pandelli's a famous and excellent restaurant above it	2473.492675911968
10544. at the	top of the hill the buildings on the left gave way to a park	1881.312368285307
10545. i got	off there crossed the street walked ahead with st sophia on my	left the blue mosque on my right and in a moment came to the entrance	of st sophia	3450.514209878374
10546. erected on the site of pagan temples and	three previous st sophias the first of which was begun by constantine	this fourth church was started by justinian in 532 and completed	twenty years later	5464.339171747239
10547. on his first trip to the finished structure	he boasted that he had built a temple grander than solomon's in jerusalem	2037.9602261070395
10548. a few years later the dome fell in	248.1376482037885
10549. nevertheless it remained	one of the most splendid churches of the eastern empire where	the byzantine emperors were crowned	1729.5287412277273
10550. after the turks conquered the	city in 1453 they converted it to a mosque adding the stubby minarets	2360.538327107835
10551. in the second half of the sixteenth century sinan the great architect	who is the michelangelo of the east designed the massive buttresses	that now help support the dome	3109.250455724874
10552. with the birth of the turkish	republic after the first world war st sophia became a museum	and the ancient mosaics which were plastered over by the moslems	whose religion forbids pictures in holy places have been restored	6075.852714434557
10553. inside over the first door i saw one of these which shows	constantine offering the city to the virgin mary and justinian offering	the temple	2621.7408092446435
10554. on the columns around the immense dome are round plaques	with arabic writing	1175.8972180176459

10556. beneath the dome i saw the	spot where the byzantine emperors were crowned a bit of floor protected	now by a wooden fence	3480.0091705338136

10561. it was laid out in 196 for chariot	races and other public games	784.9746989241328
10562. statues and other monuments that stood	there were stolen mostly by the waves of crusaders	1642.8798868123224
10563. at	the beginning of the hippodrome i saw the kaiser's fountain an	ugly octagonal building with a glass dome built in 1895 by the german	emperor and on my left directly across from it the tomb of sultan	ahmet who constructed the blue mosque more properly known by	his name	4953.769682973163
10564. just before coming to the mosque entrance i crossed	the street entered the hippodrome and walked ahead to the obelisk	of theodosius originally erected in heliopolis in egypt about 1600	bc by thutmose who also built those now in new york	london and rome at the lateran	7128.964585875263

10594. taking the path behind	the throne room to the building directly beyond it the portrait gallery	i went right at the end of it through a garden to a small building	at the back- a sitting room furnished with low blue divans its	floor covered with carpets its ceiling painted with gold squares and	floral designs	5320.831697982867
10595. do start fires one or two hours ahead of time to obtain	a	lasting bed of glowing coals	2356.054551993423
10596. keep ashes from one barbecue to the next	to sprinkle over coals if they are too hot and to stop flames that	arise from melting grease	2734.3561432624597
10597. do line barbecue fire bowl	with	heavy foil to reflect heat	749.1185788452424
10598. don't forget to buy a plastic	pastry brush for basting with sauces	637.4582296627212
10599. clean it meticulously in boiling	water and detergent rinse thoroughly	558.854088325296
10600. do build a wall	of glowing coals six to eight inches in front of meat that is barbecued	on an electric spit	2171.679011507742
10601. make use of the back of the barbecue or of the	hood for heating vegetables sauces and such	2356.7670160546522
10602. don't	fail to shorten cooking time by the use of aluminum foil cut slightly	larger than the surface of steaks and chops	2174.7111959338527
10603. sear on both sides then	cover meat loosely with heat reflecting foil for juiciest results	1643.140934503984
10604. do avoid puncturing or cutting into meats to test them	376.4279727647104
10605. if doubtful	about a steak boldly cut it in half	557.9490283094531
10606. if necessary to replace	both halves on grill sear cuts and allot extra time	947.3379574887216
10607. for roasts insert	meat thermometer diagonally so it does not rest on bone	1176.2095899988165
10608. also make	sure thermometer does not touch the revolving spit or hit the coals	949.0621026541914
10609. don't practice a new recipe on guests	140.52292336393572
10610. have a test-run	on the family first to be sure timing and seasoning are right	1098.1795150103835
10611. do buy meat the day or the day before you intend to cook it	1419.433939288421
10612. keep	it no longer than 36 hours before cooking and keep it in the coldest	compartment of the refrigerator	1726.328186550479
10613. don't	plan meals that are too complicated	140.3587013976333
10614. limit yourself to good meat	and drink with bread salad corn or potatoes as accessories	1095.6525646204777
10615. keep	the desserts simple; fruit does nicely	140.89081924993792
10616. do whatever kitchen	work such as fixing a salad preparing garlic bread or making	a marinade sauce ahead of time	1881.9933466434504
10617. when you start the outdoor performance	you can stay outdoors without a dozen running trips into the kitchen	2381.63064610536
10618. don't	think you have to start with the most expensive equipment in the	world	940.4174193844838
10619. the simplest grill or inexpensive hibachi can make	you a chef	761.4697852291492
10620. you need tongs to handle meat; long forks for turning	potatoes and corn; heavy foil on hand at all times	1864.4009740177917
10621. and lots of hot	pads!   do keep the grill high enough above the fire so that	when fat from meat drips down and flares up flames cannot reach the	meat	4839.769499670989
10622. don't forget to have a supply of melamine plates	bowls cups saucers and platters for outdoor use	1409.3934329415251
10623. made of the world's	toughest unbreakable plastic melamine dinnerware comes in almost	400 different patterns and dozens of colors	2569.9778219331433
10624. there is even one	set that has barbecue written on it	501.39211360728257
10625. it's cheaper to buy wall-tex and cover your outdoor	table	561.0982504460646
10626. or buy half a dozen lengths of oilcloth and change patterns	for different kinds of barbecues	1250.05141575259
10627. oilcloth only costs about 79c a	yard for the very best	758.710243228422
10628. tougher than plastic it wears well	43.326656009232785
10629. don't forget- when you take to the hills or the beach- that	your cooler which you might have used for wine- or beer-cooling on your	terrace or back yard is indispensable for carrying liquid refreshments	5646.904181733107
10630. there are many varieties of coolers and they serve many purposes	500.9290762896808
10631. with them you can carry steaks and hamburgers at refrigerator temperatures	and also get your frozen food for stews and chowders to the	marina or picnic in a-1 condition	4659.1531993388
10632. do use paper napkins;	lots of them	93.31095419163282
10633. except when you prepare do it yourself shish	kebob or a lobster roast	1191.353476875491
10634. then you'll want terry cloth towels	for mopping up	262.6450180856802
10635. don't think barbecue cooking is just sometimes	or seasonal	396.0685190926538
10636. in the winter	hibachi in the kitchen or grill over the logs of the fireplace	1106.816490368044
10637. even	use your portable electric or gas grill in the winter inside	969.395208206646
10638. summertime	supper outside is a natural	44.03308825372535
10639. you'll find once your technique	is perfected that you can cook on a boat with a simple bernz-o-matic	2359.582113324142
10640. do buy all-purpose mugs or cups	43.471230713467
10641. get copper or	earthenware mugs that keep beer chilled or soup hot	958.3505219652264
10642. be sure to get	a few more than you need	375.1469727297256
10643. you will discover you keep the sauce for basting	meat in one use six for drinks serve soup or coffee in another	half-dozen- and need one more to mix the salad dressing	5162.323049181117
10644. don't	forget the joys of a meal on the road	374.70212359447817
10645. if you travel over the	vast usa you will no doubt discover that feeding is an	expensive business	2367.539942922822
10646. decide in the beginning to put your barbecue equipment	to work	501.0711983581385
10647. you can take it with you h a picnic bag a	grill	a cooler for soft drinks and beer and for frozen convenience foods	3720.908253487705
10648. eat	in a restaurant or motel mornings and evenings; or just evenings	643.7558327044949
10649. turn off at any one of the marked picnic areas	have touring service bureaus that issue booklets on national parks to	and- with soft drinks	cooled from morning loading up hamburger buns an array of relishes	and fresh fruit- your lunch is 75% cheaper than at a restaurant	and 100% more fun	7624.372815996506

10653. spice is a fact of	life in the usa	391.39342899753666
10654. you only have to think of franks and sausages	to know what i mean	938.3689248152989
