10656. threaded on a skewer with	new boiled potatoes a bit of green pepper a fresh white mushroom-	any one of these spiced meats makes a man a cook and a meal a feast	3564.8412634219458
10657. sure for the most of us a frankfurter is the favorite	755.3324554651592
10658. a	story goes that a certain herr feuchtwanger of st louis around	1883 served his sausages and mustard to his fancy customers	2189.8318192494053
10659. so that his customers should not soil their hands feuchtwanger issued	white gloves	1180.55554650194
10660. discovery that the gloves frequently left with the	customers made the wise peddler of spiced sausage-meat come upon a compromise	1877.6780380066707
10661. he had a bakery make buns sized to fit his franks	750.015014255806
10662. years later	franks-in-buns were accepted as the first to go at the new	york polo grounds	1262.0748342365882
10663. the nations's number one picnic treat	is the skinless frankfurter- toasted over a bonfire on the beach or	more sedately charcoal broiled on a portable grill	4133.5537248512965
10664. either way it's	hard to beat in flavor as well as ease of preparation	940.0723405853847
10665. to make the	picnic frank come close to perfection remember these tips:	-score each frankfurter in four or five places about a third of	the way through	4308.219271819044
10666. this permits the juices to permeate the meat during	cooking	371.8366954049515
10667. relishes are as vital to the success of the frank	as are buns	1183.824504417386
10668. bring along the conventional ones- catsup pickle relish	mustard mayonnaise- plus a few extras such as tangy barbecue	sauce chive cream cheese or horse-radish for the brave ones in the crowd	3363.6077811553114
10669. using a portable grill permits you to toast the buns	too	758.9063374144808
10670. watch closely while browning them as it doesn't take long	371.9041350203499
10671. an unusual flavor can be achieved by marinating the franks	in french dressing or a mixture of honey lemon juice and brown sugar	prior to the picnic	4297.398625962331

10874. start by laying out the six	frames and the transom on a level floor	1424.6441426906226

10880. the frames are notched only for the keelson	and the chines	760.7738190047684

10914. is five-ply 38-inch-thick weldwood royal marine plywood	141.87959015036483

10916. the 42-inch width	leaves very little waste	140.06490882345486
10917. plank the sides first	using glue and one-inch no 12 stronghold nails at all battens	the stem and the transom	1894.0131007857483

10925. the	next step is to remove it and spread glue where it has been marked at	the contact points	1734.8508891089587
10926. then it is replaced and fastened	65.29488840871988
10927. the bottom planking	is applied in the same manner	261.708162627969
10928. after planking the bottom	gets a layer of fiberglas	391.6855793056054
10929. the spray rails are first glued on the	outside and fastened from the inside with screws	1260.9122999474464
10930. then the chines are	rounded off and the bottom is rough-sanded in preparation	1189.7851282702293
10931. since the	sides are also covered up to the spray rails they are also rough-sanded	in that area	1563.5982835597842
10932. the cloth is laid on one half of the bottom at	a time	1183.351033252437
10933. a 50-inch width is used on each side and it laps the keel line	by about three inches	1571.4054978805225
10934. lay the cloth in place and trim it to size	560.6774169004642
10935. then remove it and give the whole bottom a coat of resin	641.63595149651
10936. when the resin	has hardened mix up another batch with a pigment added if you wish	1893.4442268242724
10937. i used bright red mixing the pigment in thoroughly before adding	the hardener	794.3243758445808
10938. using a cheap brush coat one side of the bottom with	the resin and then apply the cloth	2360.4516015647578
10939. when the cloth is smooth apply	another coat of resin spreading it with a paint roller	1252.9460684573223
10940. be sure it is	well saturated and then allow it to harden	959.3754007125684
10941. when the whole bottom	has hardened use a disk sander to feather the edges of the cloth	at the keel line and near the spray rail	2730.9707820662816
10942. then lay a three-inch-wide	strip of cloth along the keel line from the transom to the point of	the stem	2825.495803534156
10943. before the resin has hardened screw a one-inch mahogany keel	strip along the centerline	946.9937312516042
10944. this protects the bottom in beaching	64.95351968801721
10945. fiberglas materials are available from glass plastic supply co	1605 w elizabeth ave linden n j	1253.2851792501356
10946. they will also	supply literature on application	140.58039460920196
10947. is now turned	over and placed in a level well-braced	position	503.2944328083436
10948. i set it on the gator trailer	141.8923112110852
10949. i laid three layers	of glass cloth on the inside of the stem also installing a bow eye	at this time	2023.2380527276018
10950. for added strength i also fastened a small block on	each side of every frame and batten joint	2362.5896713982547
10951. again these blocks were	set in resin-saturated glass cloth and nailed	499.02852912285005
10952. after trimming	off the excess on the frames and transom which was used to fasten them	to the jig at a working height the top of the side planking is installed	5014.206029379531
10953. this is made up of scraps left over from the sides and bottom	787.7674449476856
10954. these flaring parts really help to keep the boat dry	564.7248412638266
10955. when they're	on the top edges are planed even with the sheer batten	790.9788034694369
10956. the	sides of the motor well run from the bottom battens to the top and from	frame six to the transom forming a real strong transom brace	4300.454987147119
10957. note	another piece of wood six inches wide is fastened to the transom between	these pieces	1257.5681884278952
10958. the decking is quarter-inch mahogany marine	plywood	141.18931173107643
10959. all the flooring and the storage bin is half-inch exterior	fir plywood	647.0155867018315
10960. most floor battens are glued and screwed to the flooring	562.330172681971
10961. the exception is where the flooring butts	95.03722739579267
10962. these battens are glued	and screwed to the frames	393.02106149333474
10963. with all deck battens in place the	bilge is cleaned and painted up to the floor line	1422.2534754463425
10964. use one coat of	firzite and one coat of marine paint	750.1764037816301
10965. bottoms of the floorboards are	also painted and the flooring is then screwed in place	1108.290569310051
10966. after	the decking is on the cabin sides are installed	561.795110559306
10967. they're followed	by the front and rear bulkheads as illustrated	376.8370537823026
10968. the windshield glass	is shatterproof and plexiglas is used in the cabin	967.8234211319732
10969. bunks are framed up and installed as indicated	166.53556341449686
10970. a head is a handy	thing to have and i installed one under a removable section of the	port bunk	2820.954308734844
10971. the sink in the hinged panel above the bunk drains into	the head and a five-gallon water tank is mounted on the bulkhead above	the sink	2753.8580409951023
10972. for padding the seats and bunks i used ensolite type	m	758.0669003897223
10973. lightweight non-absorbent fire resistant and dimensionally stable	it is easily bonded to the wood with contact cement	1409.3081858933106
10974. available	in f sheets it costs about a dollar a square foot	966.9577721938047
10975. you can build this vacation cottage yourself	93.96401312814106

11027. with modern techniques of woodworking and the multitude of cutting	tools fixtures and attachments available the drill press has become	a basic home workshop tool	2600.95258351135
11028. the drill press consists of a vertical	shaft which is tapered or threaded on one end to hold a	drill chuck a tubular housing in which the spindle is mounted	a head in which the quill is mounted a feed lever which moves the	quill up or down a power source and a movable table upon which the work	is placed	8411.093644617653
11029. there is often a means of locking the quill and on larger	presses the table can be tilted	1577.4999726449182
11030. the size of the press is	usually expressed in terms of chuck capacity	or distance between the spindle center and the	column	3271.817866143135
11031. a press with an 11 inch capacity lets you drill to the center	of a 22 inch board or circle	1892.1225190211208
11032. a new radial drill press with	a 16 inch capacity has a tilting head that allows drilling to be done	at any angle	3486.318516806231
11033. the head is mounted on a horizontal arm that swivels on	the supporting column to position the drill bit instead of the work	2324.8407010922992
11034. the drill press should be leveled and depending	on whether it is a bench or floor model bolted securely to a	sturdy bench or stand or screwed to the floor with lag or expansion screws	5657.5471798014605
11035. this will reduce vibration and increase accuracy	93.91288581622851
11036. a coat	of paste wax or a rubdown with a piece of wax paper will protect the	polished surface of the table; wiping with a slightly oiled cloth	will discourage rusting of the column and quill	5807.462270654649
11037. presses not fitted	with sealed spindle bearings will need a drop of oil now and then in	the lubrication holes in the quill	2331.0760066852176
11038. the rest of the press should be kept	clean by dusting with a clean rag or brush	2135.9052265711252
11039. be careful to	keep the drive belt free of oil and grease	646.9443293275721
11040. belt tension is adjusted	by manipulation of two locking bolts and a movable motor mount	1646.315016164588
11041. keep	the belt just tight enough so the pulleys won't slip when pulled by	hand; excess tension will only cause undue wear on the motor and spindle	bearings	2981.142316950593
11042. most drill presses have a quill return spring that raises	the spindle automatically when the feed lever is released and holds	the quill in the raised position	4283.981393388325
11043. the return spring tension may be	adjusted to suit individual requirements by gripping the spring housing	with a pair of pliers	loosening the lock nut or screw and rotating the housing	until the desired tension is achieved	3943.5400863151954
11044. turning the housing clockwise	will reduce tension counter-clockwise will increase it	744.5183604237134
11045. drill speeds are important if you want	a good job	560.8131751787696
11046. each cutting tool will operate best at a given speed	depending on the material worked	1110.0263294949186
11047. on most drill presses it is impossible	to get the exact speed but you can come close by adjusting the	drive belt on the step-cone pulleys	4116.777573414898
11048. you will find a chart giving the	various speed ratios available with your particular drill press somewhere	in the instruction booklet that came with the tool	2724.0590980970187
11049. see the table	on page 34 for exact recommended speeds	566.2029176169585
11050. generally the larger the	tool and the harder the material the slower the speed	956.6341981375347
11051. feed pressure	is also of major importance	139.9028188127824
11052. too much pressure will force the	tool beyond its cutting capacity and result in rough cuts and jammed	or broken tools	2031.3810082513155
11053. too light a feed particularly with metal or other hard	material causes overheating of the tool and burning of the cutting	edge	3265.7248405256023
11054. the best results will be obtained by matching the correct speed	with a steady feed pressure that lets the tool cut easily at an even	rate	2742.7694234819005
11055. there are numerous types and styles	of tools to drill holes	748.4425054489091
11056. the most common are the twist drill the	solid center shaft with interchangeable cutting blades the double spur	bit and the power wood bit	2456.1826563807476
11057. all will do a good job if sharp but the	twist drills don't cut quite as smoothly as the others since they	do not have the outlining spurs that sever the fibers before actual	boring starts	5793.320740852787
11058. the adjustable fly cutter is very useful for cutting	large diameter holes and can be used to cut exact-size discs by	reversing the cutter blade	2590.5660033897702
11059. since fly cutters are one sided and not	balanced they should be used at the slowest speed available and fed	very slowly to avoid binding	3907.9619689715446
11060. fly cutters can fool you into putting	your hand too close to the tool so if you want to avoid nicked fingers	keep your hands well out of the way	3209.3424746463547
11061. when drilling all the way through a workpiece always place a	piece of scrap wood underneath	1880.384754601356
11062. this will not only protect the work	table but also assure a clean breakthrough	950.6700995334068
11063. another method of assuring	a clean hole is to first drill a small pilot hole all the way through	then drill half way with the dimensional bit turn the piece over	and finish from the other side	5928.348151587795
11064. in soft woods with pronounced grain	there is sometimes a tendency for the hole to wander due to the varying	hardness of the wood	2453.986699742081
11065. in this case drilling a small pilot hole or	clamping the work will do much to improve accuracy	2375.1517188375374
11066. when a hole	is to be bored to a predetermined depth mark the depth on the side	of the stock then run the bit down so that it is even with the mark	3562.8307513268473
11067. the depth gauge rod can now be set and any number of holes bored to	exact and identical depth	2587.227533434209
11068. the old-time bridges over the merrimac river in massachusetts	are of unusual interest in many respects	1259.5458372226544
11069. for their length their	types of construction their picturesque settings and their literary	associations they should be known and remembered	2821.1186673578995
11070. in this sequence	i shall write about them in the order of their erection	938.9269436089878
11071. the	first bridge known to have been covered wholly or in part- and perhaps	the most interesting one connected newbury with	salisbury point	3483.055903289523
11072. this paper was signed by forty-five	persons subscribing a total of two hundred shares	932.8603053836812
11073. a month	later the general court served notice to the town of newbury that	the bridge was to be built	2811.14420963755
11074. the matter was considered and reconsidered	and finally opposed but in spite of many objections the court	granted a charter on january 9 1792	2462.6725296390505
11075. on november 26 of that year the	bridge was completed and opened	955.435412062021
11076. timothy palmer who invented	and later patented the arch type of construction for wooden bridges	was the genius who planned and supervised the building of the essex	or deer island bridge although the actual work was carried	out under the direction of william coombs who received  300 as	recompense	4887.311115099958
11077. this two-part bridge is best described by rev timothy	dwight president of yale college in his travels in new-england	and new-york published in new haven in 1821	4303.328265548386
11078. he says	of it:   it consists of two divisions separated by an island	at a small distance from the southern shore	2028.3244514228913
11079. the division between	the island and this shore consists principally of an arch; whose	chord is one hundred and sixty feet and whose vortex is forty feet	above the high-water mark	5001.145430154349
11080. in appearance and	construction it resembles the pascataqua bridge	260.64075234319955
11081. the whole length of	essex bridge is one thousand and thirty feet and its breadth thirty-four	1876.8782883376873
11082. i have already mentioned that mr timothy palmer of newburyport	was the inventor of the arched bridges in this country	1873.990772739838
11083. as mr	palmer was educated to house-building only and had never seen a	structure of this nature; he certainly deserves not a little credit	for the invention	4287.039558214399
11084. it is hardly necessary to remind students	of covered bridges that timothy palmer was born in 1751 in nearby	rowley; that he moved with his parents to west boxford when he was	sixteen years old; and was there apprenticed to a builder and architect	moody spofford	4677.2924824245565
11085. it was indeed a remarkable feat that a man	who had had no experience of bridge building should have applied the	principle of the arch which appears in his famous bridges at portsmouth	haverhill and philadelphia	5773.862255463213
11086. the essex merrimack bridge	when first built was not covered	370.8376146341667
11087. as far as we know no american	bridge had been thus protected in 1792	1411.0784601752157
11088. richard s allen is the	authority for the statement that the northern section was probably roofed	by 1810	1573.209183119149
11089. its original appearance is shown in an engraving published	in the massachusetts magazine in may 1793 which is reproduced	herewith	2828.2241022104786
11090. a brief description accompanying the picture	says that the bridge contained more than 6000 tons of timber	1414.2184527494142
11091. between	the abutments on the newbury shore and the south bank of deer island	there was one span or arch measuring 160 feet; between the north	shore of deer island and the salisbury side there was an arch of	113 feet and a series of piers with a draw forty feet long	7602.021858601818
11092. a	dinner and celebration in honor of this piece of engineering took place	july 4 1793 in a tavern erected by the corporation on the island	2727.440696451538
11093. it is said that the eccentric timothy dexter who was one of the	first share-holders stood on the table and made a speech worthy of the	occasion	4277.829314813361
11094. the essex journal says that he delivered an oration	on the bridge which for elegance of style propriety of speech	or force of argument was truly ciceronian	2849.7088546832656
11095. the reporter must have	written this with tongue in cheek because dexter's oration could	hardly be understood; and although he later explained that he was	talking french it seems rather more likely that he had succumbed to	the joys of the evening	6531.277967755562
11096. the north portion of the essex bridge	was well worth the cost of construction although it proved to be twice	what was estimated in the beginning	2716.0275134492613
11097. it stood in its original form	until 1882	250.71971353158264
11098. the southern half however on account of its underbracing	was considered by boat owners a menace to navigation	1557.1184511902225
11099. in 1810 it	was torn down and replaced by a chain suspension bridge	1181.8953024969887
11100. this was built	by john templeman from plans submitted by james finley of fayette	county pennsylvania	1263.6197007228823
11101. timothy palmer had general supervision	of the work	252.11156715734063
11102. an advertisement in the newburyport herald	december 21 1810 shows palmer in a new light as an expert on chain	bridges	2046.5728630161186
11103. it reads:    information	is hereby given that mr timothy palmer of newburyport mass	has agreed to take charge of the concerns of the patentees of the	chain bridge in the states of massachusetts new hampshire vermont	rhode island and connecticut so far as relates to the sale	of patent rights and the construction of chain bridges	7942.670343925832
11104. mr	palmer will attend to any applications relating to bridges and if	desired will view the proposed site and lay out and superintend the	work or recommend a suitable person to execute it	3559.3227364458426
11105. john	templeman	approved timothy palmer   this chain bridge proved	less durable than the wooden arch on the salisbury end	2572.928209651134
11106. it fell	february 6 1827 carrying with it a horse and wagon two men and four	oxen	1423.47879975676
11107. the horse and men were saved but the oxen drowned	561.7998549877915
11108. in spite	of this catastrophe the bridge was rebuilt on the same plan and opened	again on july 17 1827	1878.1175179887682
11109. this second chain bridge was 570 feet long	had two thirty-foot towers and a draw and a double roadway	2595.236664928822
11110. the essex bridge was a toll crossing until 1868 when the county	commissioners laid out all the merrimack bridges as highways	2031.968585036475
11111. sturdy and strong after more than a century of continuous	use the old covered wooden bridge that spans the tygartis valley river	at philippi will have a distinctive part in the week-long observance	of the first land battle of the civil war at its home site may	28th to june 3rd	7517.484411594849
11112. colonel frederick w lander impersonated	will again make his break-neck ride down the steep declivity of talbott's	hill and thunder across the bridge to join colonel	benjamin f kelley's virginia infantry then swarming	through the streets in pursuit of the retreating confederates	4376.459797369066
11113. he was closely followed by the ohio and indiana troops- thus the	old bridge has another distinction; that of being the first such structure	secured by force of arms in the war of the '60s	5643.66772732042
11114. the	bridge has survived the natural hazards of the elements war fire	and floods as well as injuries incident to heavy traffic for more than	a hundred years	2984.1344214573483
11115. twice during the civil war it was saved from destruction	by the opposing armies by the pleas and prayers of a local minister	3471.3289961453656
11116. it still stands as a monument to the engineering skills of the	last century and still serves in the gasoline age to carry heavy traffic	on us route 250- the old beverly and fairmont turnpike	3773.7347798686583
11117. it is one of the very few if not the only surviving bridge of	its type to serve a main artery of the us highway system thus	it is far more than a relic of the horse and buggy days	6319.295461228815
11118. this	covered wooden bridge is so closely identified with the first action	in the early morning of june 3 1861 and with subsequent troop movements	of both armies in the philippi area that it has become a part	and parcel of the war story	4553.112838278474
11119. so frequently has pictures of the bridge	appeared in books and in national publications that it vies with the	old john brown fort at harpers ferry as the two nationally best known	structures in west virginia	5782.90203759112
11120. completed and opened for traffic	in 1852 the bridge was designed and built by lemuel chenoweth	and his brother eli of beverly	2169.6221761717443
11121. the chenoweth brothers were experienced	bridge builders and against the competition of other and better	known bridge designers and builders they had constructed nine of	the covered wooden bridges on the parkersburg and staunton turnpike	a dozen years before as well as many other bridges for several counties	7245.335899023325
11122. the philippi bridge however was the chenoweth master piece	with its 139-foot dual lane span- and it stands today as a monument	to its builders	2606.76518664733
11123. never rebuilt the bridge was strengtened in 1938	by two extra piers a concrete floor and a walk-way along the upper	side in order to care for modern traffic	4653.917007724256
11124. during the war it	was in constant use by the wagon trains transporting supplies from the	railhead at grafton to the troops operating in the interior	2735.2492674784203
11125. union	soldiers at times used it for sleeping quarters to escape from the	rain or other inclement weather and some of them left momentoes of their	stay by carving their names and small tokens on its walls and beams	6159.486077145355
11126. but what the elements could not do was seriously threatened	when brigadier general william e jones reached philippi	while on the famous jones-imboden raid in may 1863	2857.218134735279
11127. general	jones was fresh from a long series of bridge burnings including the	long bridge at fairmont and after seeing a great drove of horses	and cattle he had collected safely across the bridge he sent his men	to work piling combustibles in and around it	7034.589161859825
11128. reverend joshual corder	a baptist minister gathered a few citizens of southern sympathies	to call on jones and plead with him to spare the structure; he	reasoned and argued pointing out that jones or other confederate	commanders would need it should troops pass that way in retreat	4759.483512827277

11348. these are inexpensive and available from the u	s geological society washington 25 d c	1103.3120023360693
11349. in recent	years many counties and the u s forest service have taken	aerial photos which show features in detail and are very good for planning	use	4282.12147476026
11350. most counties also have maps available from the county engineer	showing roads and other features and from the assessor's office	showing ownerships of land	2476.0289650756995
11351. inspect the site in the field during	the time of the year when the area will be most heavily used for	recreation	3265.858915883601
11352. this gives you a better opportunity to get the feel of the	climate conditions the exposure to the sun and wind the water interests	etcetera which vary greatly with the seasons	3361.2465148699093
11353. it is usually helpful	to make a sketch map in the field showing the size and location	of the features of interest and to take photographs at the site	4661.340558862287
11354. these	are a great aid for planning use back at the office	643.543862599951
11355. for	site planning work it is best to have a qualified and experienced	park planner to carry through the study	2825.664083923326
11356. however there is also much	to be gained by making use of the abilities of the local people who are	available and interested in recreation	2584.819872253217
11357. county judges commissioners	engineers assessors and others who have lived in the area for a	long time may have valuable knowledge regarding the site or opinions	to offer from their varied professional experiences	5337.773661064391
11358. a visit to the site	by a group of several persons can usually bring out new ideas or verify	opinions most helpful to the planning study of any recreation area	3215.7652432234827
11359. how much study is required	22.227073396595436
11360. this of course depends on	the character of the site itself the previous experience of the investigator	and the number of factors needed to arrive at a good decision	3116.7490731695716
11361. it is too easy for the inexperienced person to make a quick	judgment	of a few values of the area and base a decision on these alone	4290.760066613074
11362. usually	there are more factors to good site planning than first impressions	641.4710788789422
11363. a site may be a rundown slum or a desolate piece of desert in appearance	today but have excellent potentials for the future with a little	development or water	4651.661565473992
11364. the same is true of areas which at first look	good because of a few existing recreation features but may actually	be poor areas to develop for general public use	3202.5849427818307
11365. in looking for	the best sites available that meet the requirements you need information	to compare the site with others	2830.597424731938
11366. you need answers to four important	questions	93.31883626567905
11367. what are the existing recreation features	65.84087269220623
11368. how well can the site be developed	94.10200861838557
11369. how useful	will it be to the public	250.42512923506916
11370. is this site available	2.9363008152599663
11371. check the quantity and quality of all of the recreation interests	already existing at the site	1884.4356442810144
11372. naturally a park site with scenic	views a good lake trees and sand dunes will attract more people	than a nearby area with only trees and dunes	2876.6378910516587
11373. frontage on a body of clear clean water will be vastly different	from the same amount of frontage on polluted water	3034.723421710717
11374. some recreation	features such as scenic values and water interest also have greater	overall value than other interests	1574.4680435857636
11375. one of the most desirable	features for a park are beautiful views or scenery	1414.2519646026274
11376. it may be distant	views of a valley or the mountains or natural features such as a	small lake colorful rock formations or unusual trees	2616.076027957956
11377. a site which	overlooks a harbor or river may offer interest in the activities of boating	traffic	2113.3283894710585
11378. an area on the coast may have relaxing views of the surf	rolling in on a beach	1415.185110971504
11379. a site may also be attractive just through	the beauty of its trees and shrubs	1653.9095260510185
11380. note extent of these interests and	how available they will be for the public to enjoy	1261.2052165273294
11381. water interest	is one of the most valuable factors you can find for a recreation	site	1900.8474002155792
11382. most park planners look to water frontage for basic park areas	499.4005915542228
11383. this follows naturally since frontage on an ocean stream or lake	provides scenic values and opportunities for the very popular recreation	activities of bathing fishing boating and other water sports	4823.7266580547575
11384. a body of water is usually the center of interest at parks which attract	the greatest picnic and camping use	1885.4665460470212
11385. it also cools the air in summer	and nourishes the trees and wild life	1414.1015219909484
11386. the amount of water	frontage the quantity and quality of the water and the recreation	afforded by it are important	1879.0157568567054
11387. a restricted frontage may be too crowded	an area for public use	958.710961256279
11388. the quantity of water flow may be critical;	a stream or pond which is attractive in the springtime may become stagnant	or dry in late summer	2736.309682497641
11389. if the site is on a reservoir the level	of the water at various seasons as it affects recreation should be	studied	3271.83720646928
11390. check the quality of the water	43.42157546541595
11391. a stream which has all of	its watershed within a national forest or other lands under good conservation	practices is less likely to be affected by pollution than one	passing through unrestricted logging or past an industrial area	6048.64389303792
11392. other	factors such as water temperature depth of water the fish life it	supports wave action flooding etcetera will affect its recreation	value	2323.3045610077047
11393. other natural features which can be of high interest	are the forests canyons mountains deserts seacoast beaches sand	dunes waterfalls springs etcetera with which the area is blessed	4489.572111187613
11394. just as the national and state parks place emphasis on features which	are of national or state significance counties should seek out these	features which are distinctive of their area	3230.8920029918895
11395. although the site may	not contain the features themselves there are often opportunities	to include them as additional interest to the site	3269.7230038215794
11396. the route to the	park may lead people past them or display views of them	1095.2612083342378
11397. a group of	native trees or plants which are outstanding in a particular county can	be featured at the site	2841.7009627292005
11398. the fish animals and birds which	may be found at the site are another interest	1097.5229175284894
11399. fishing interest calls	for a check of the species found quantity and size the season they	are available and the stocking program of the fish commission	4107.313037065945
11400. animals	may be present at the site or provide hunting in nearby areas	790.0131180926776
11401. the	site may be on one of the major flyways of migratory birds or have its	own resident bird life	2830.0347691675934
11402. clams crabs and other marine life may add	interest at coastal areas	641.5578239984791
11403. each area has its own historical	interests with which much can be done	1187.0765909593867
11404. park visitors are always	eager to learn more about the area they are in	943.2236640113049
11405. the historical sign	tells its story but nothing gets interest across as well as some of the	original historical items or places themselves which still have the	character of the period covered	5174.836633085613
11406. notice should be taken of unusual rock	formations deposits or shapes of the earth's crust in your region	1559.5639646162922
11407. those which tell a story of the earth's formation in each area	can add geological interest to the recreation sites	2824.9788792485783
11408. an old shipwreck	a high dam an old covered bridge a place to find agates or other	semi-precious stones or a place to pan gold etcetera may be of interest	3230.8691036015093
11409. some areas may provide archeological values such as ancient indian	village sites or hunting areas caves artifacts etcetera	2366.0420747999033
11410. how well can the site be developed	94.10200861838557
11411. look at the physical features	of the land to determine how desirable it is for use what can be done	to correct the faults and what it will cost to make the area meet your	needs in comparison to other sites	6434.228956217026
11412. many things need to be checked:	- the size of the area alone can be a determining	factor	865.1868883701815
11413. an area may be too small for the needs of the project	961.3589511216969
11414. areas should be large enough to include the attractions have ample	space for the use of facilities needed and have room around the edges	to protect the values of the area from encroachment by private developments	3857.6270720111847
11415. acreage in excess of the minimum is good practice as recreation	areas are never too large for the future and it is often more economical	to operate one large area than several small ones	5489.712047227938
11416. shape	of the area is also related to the use attractions and needs of the	development	1254.387021728081
11417. a large picnic area or camping development is most efficient	in shape as a square or rectangle several hundred feet in width	in preference to a long narrow area less than one hundred feet wide	5617.166034747844
11418. this	is true because of savings in utility lines and the fact that your	buildings have a useful radius equal in all directions	2305.5869681185663
11419. however a	narrow strip may be very practical for small developments or to provide	additional stream frontage for a fisherman's trail or include	scenic strips within the park unit	4678.0329336173945
11420. the values	of the site may be affected by the appearance of the adjoining lands	ownership and use of the land and the utilities available there	2723.1594807123356
11421. for	instance a site adjoining other publicly owned lands such as a national	forest or a public road may be desirable whereas a site next	to an industrial plant might not	5029.818456776782
11422. the utilities available nearby may	provide a savings in the cost of extending electricity or water to the	site	1730.8952641047276
11423. check the	elevation of the ground degree and direction of slopes drainage rock	outcrops topsoil types and quality as well as subsoil	3271.1114862917216
11424. nearly level	areas are required for parking areas beaches camp areas ballfields	etcetera	790.2409167502507
11425. determine how much topography limits useful area or what	the costs of earth moving or grading might be	2360.9596562421225
11426. in addition	to its recreation interests water is needed for drinking sanitation	and irrigation	947.5013610686171
11427. the quantity and quality of water sources is	often a big factor in site selection	1644.235972533649
11428. the area may provide good springs	or opportunities for a well or be near to municipal water lines	1572.8426742148808
11429. figure	the cost of providing water to the use areas	559.6976072434511
11430. the	existing plant growth calls for thorough checking	166.44181133160006
11431. look at the trees	as to size and interest the amount of shade they provide how healthy	they are the problems of maintenance fire hazards wind throw	etcetera	4469.720284943588
11432. an area may have been partially logged and requires	removal of stumps or clean up	1105.5343040676287
11433. some shrubs may be of good landscaping	value other areas of brush may need to be cleared	2099.5183748337486
11434. the extent and location	of open areas is noted	260.43653539926066
11435. how much will wind	rain sun and temperature affect the use	751.2692540415144
11436. an area sheltered from	strong winds may be highly desirable for recreation use	787.6934434109709
11437. the direction	velocity and season of these winds should be noted as to just how	they will affect the recreation use and your maintenance and operation	of the area	4669.889267034914
11438. lack of rainfall and extreme temperatures may call for	the development of shade and irrigation of a site to make it useable	2168.7529050769617
11439. sometimes you have a choice of exposure for sites where the topography	or trees of the area will provide afternoon shade morning sun or	whatever may be most desirable for the use intended	5339.589418482145
11440. some areas may already have been improved and contain buildings	roads utilities cleared land etcetera which may raise the cost of	the site	2322.375474313038
11441. your invitation to write about serge prokofieff to honor his	70th anniversary for the april issue of sovietskaya muzyka is	accepted with pleasure because i admire the music of prokofieff;	and with sober purpose because the development of prokofieff personifies	in many ways the course of music in the union of soviet socialist	republics	7779.834981614878
11442. the serge prokofieff whom we knew in the	united states of america was gay witty mercurial full of pranks	and bonheur- and very capable as a professional musician	2986.499963745512
11443. these	qualities endeared him to both the musicians and the social-economic	haute monde which supported the concert world of the post-world	war 1 era	3705.517044881481
11444. prokofieff's outlook as a composer-pianist-conductor	in america was indeed brilliant	374.81979323778796
11445. prokofieff's classical	symphony was hailed as an ingenious work from a naturally gifted	and well-trained musician still in his twenties	2828.9636450779226
11446. to the traditionalists	it was a brilliant satire on modernism; to the neo-classicists	it was a challenge to the pre-war world	2031.6080013330513
11447. what was it to prokofieff	22.07850432856547
11448. a tongue-in-cheek stylization of 18th-century ideas; a trial	balloon to test the aesthetic climate of the times; a brilliant piece	de resistance	2185.998475459413
11449. certainly its composer was an ascending star	on a new world horizon	965.4205953294659
11450. i heard the classical symphony	for the first time when koussevitzky conducted it in paris in 1927	1412.4723210911247
11451. all musical paris was there	22.065856604995023
11452. some musicians were enthusiastic some	skeptical	43.99720502919254
11453. i myself was one of the skeptics	141.55746909310068
11454. i remember	ernest bloch in the foyer shouting in his high-pitched voice:	h it may be a tour de force mais mon dieu can anyone take	this music seriously	3100.5893219191007
11455. the answer is yes! certainly	america took prokofieff and his classical symphony seriously	and with a good deal of pleasure	2828.426843973367
11456. his life-long friend serge	koussevitzky gave unreservedly of his praise and brilliant performances	in boston new york and washington d c to which	he added broadcastings and recordings for the whole nation	3456.289291158274
11457. chicago was	also a welcome host: there in 1921 prokofieff conducted the world	premiere of the love for three oranges and played the first	performance of his third piano concerto	4840.177539174459
11458. uncle sam was indeed	a rich uncle to prokofieff in those opulent post-war victory	years of peace and prosperity bold speculations and extravaganzas enjoyment	and pleasure: the golden twenties	3115.704428297021
11459. we attended the	premieres of his concertos symphonies and suites; we studied taught	and performed his piano sonatas chamber music gavottes and marches;	we bought his records and played them in our schools and universities	5630.101328336817
11460. we unanimously agreed that prokofieff had won his rights as	a world citizen to the first ranks of twentieth-century composers	1888.0373201499356
11461. so young prokofieff was the darling of success: in his motherland;	in the spacious hunting grounds of uncle sam; in the exciting	salons of his lovely brilliant paris- mistress of gaiety-	excess and abandon- world theatre of new-found freedoms in tone color	dance design and thought	4674.7248425296875
11462. meanwhile three great terrible	forces were coagulating and crystallizing	393.8911801299309
11463. in this world-wide conscription	of men minds and machines prokofieff was recalled to his	native land	1254.206378614987
11464. the world exploded when fascism challenged all concepts	of peace and liberty and the outraged freedom-loving peoples of the	capitalist and socialist worlds combined forces to stamp fascist	tyranny into cringing submission	5176.968540811131
11465. after this holocaust a changing world	occupied the minds of men; a world beset with new boundaries new	treaties and governments new goals and methods and the age-old fears	of aggression	and subjugation- hunger and exposure	3874.9020830059985
11466. in this	changed world prokofieff settled to find himself and to create	for	large national purpose	1875.6835272386609
11467. here this happy roving son of good fortune	proved that he could accept the disciplines of a new social-economic	order fighting for its very existence and ideals in a truculent world	3341.548659959076
11468. here prokofieff became a workman in the vineyards of socialism-	producing music for the masses	1650.2661586523093
11469. it is at this point in his life	that the mature prokofieff emerges	781.3265863305551
11470. one might have expected that	such a violent epoch of transition would have destroyed the creative	flair of a composer especially one whose works were so fluent and spontaneous	4663.828834979768
11471. he accepted the environment	of his destiny- took root and grew to fulfill the stature of his	early promise	1724.5206267948117
11472. by 1937 he had clarified his intentions to serve his	people: i have striven for clarity and melodious idiom but at	the same time i have by no means attempted to restrict myself to the	accepted methods of harmony and melody	6437.894016650216
11473. this is precisely what makes	lucid straightforward music so difficult to compose- the clarity must	be new not old	1725.5125538028249
11474. how right he was; how clearly he saw the cultural	defection of experimentation as an escape for those who dare not	or prefer not to face the discipline of modern traditionalism	4990.693165200751
11475. and	with what resource did prokofieff back up his credo of words- with	torrents of powerful music	1411.7055531216688
11476. compare the vast difference in scope and	beauty between his neat and witty little classical symphony and	his big muscular passionate and eloquent fifth symphony; or the	love for three oranges with the wonderful imaginative	colorful and subtle tenderness of the magnificent ballet	the stone flower	7033.363621267052
11477. this masterpiece has gaiety too but it is	the gaiety of dancing people: earthy salty and humorous	1405.07054071429
11478. of	course these works are not comparable even though the same brain conceived	them	1410.87628155695
11479. the early works were conceived for a sophisticated international	audience; the later works were conceived to affirm a way	of life for fellow citizens	2448.4200127630797
11480. however in all of prokofieff's music	young or mature we find his profile- his signature- his	craftsman's attitude	2353.583925297168
11481. prokofieff never forsakes his medium for the	cause of experimentation per se	640.1821613583313
11482. in orchestration he stretches	the limits of instrumentation with good judgment and a fine imagination	for color	2120.9250626660787
11483. his sense for rhythmic variety and timing is impeccable	262.34051982333096
11484. his creative development of melodic designs of slavic dance tunes and	love songs is captivating: witty clever adroit and subtle	2830.9292008788207
11485. his	counterpoint is pertinent skillful and rarely thick	167.23668318381667
11486. also	it should be noted that the polytonal freedom of his melodies and harmonic	modulations the brilliant orchestrations the adroitness for evading	the heaviness of figured bass the skill in florid counterpoint	were not lost in his mature output even in the spectacular historical	dramas of the stage and cinema where a large dramatic canvas of sound	was required	8200.044340276705
11487. that prokofieff's harmonies and forms sometimes	seem professionally routine to our ears may or may not indicate that	he was less of an original than we prefer to believe	3091.4720021194844
11488. need for	novelty may be a symptom of cultural fatigue and instability	961.5066815080236
11489. prokofieff might well emerge as a cultural hero who by the force of	his creative life helped preserve the main stream of tradition to which	the surviving idioms of current experimentalism may be eventually	added and integrated	3946.4800384794216
11490. at this date it seems probable that the	name of serge prokofieff will appear in the archives of history	as an effective traditionalist who was fully aware of the lure and danger	of experimentation and used it as it served his purpose; yet	was never caught up in it- never a slave to its academic dialectics	7955.971866268168
11491. certainly it is the traditional clarity of his music which has endeared	him to the western world- not his experimentations	1887.4411076915844
11492. so	prokofieff was able to cultivate his musical talents and harvest a	rich reward from them	1885.718292262207
11493. nor can anyone be certain that prokofieff would	have done better or even as well under different circumstances	1581.4702943586276
11494. his fellow-countryman igor stravinsky certainly did not	139.58471653829776
11495. why did	prokofieff expand in stature and fecundity while stravinsky	dwindled in stature and fruitfulness	1098.197526865927
11496. i think the answer is to be found in prokofieff's own words:	the clarity must be new not old	2586.8639370100777
11497. when prokofieff forged his	new clarity of lucid straightforward music so difficult to compose	he shaped his talents to his purpose	2023.0708128620554
11498. when stravinsky	shaped his purpose to the shifting scenes of many cultures many salons	many dialectics many personalities he tried to refashion himself	into a stylist of many styles determined by many disparate cultures	5485.455379019119
11499. prokofieff was guided in a consistent direction by the life of his own	people- by the compass of their national ideas	2036.83546260488
11500. but stravinsky	was swayed by the attitudes of whatever culture he was reflecting	1181.3525891399179
11501. in	all his miscalculations stravinsky made the fatal historical blunder	of presuming that he could transform other composers' inspirations-	representing many peoples time periods and styles- into his own	music by warping the harmony melody or form to verify his own experiments	4398.367684434489
11502. because of the authentic homogeneity of his early nationalistic	materials and his flair for orchestrations- his brilliant petruchka	his savage sacre du printemps his incisive les noces-	the world kept hoping that he could recapture the historical	direction for which his native talents were predisposed	6931.0203205133585
11503. but	time is running out and many of stravinsky's admirers begin to fear	that he will never find terra firma	1871.7801064645523
11504. how differently prokofieff's life unfolded	14.786017578318683
11505. prokofieff	was able to adjust his creative personality to a swiftly changing	world without losing his particular force and direction	2818.068189515937
11506. in the process	his native endowments were stretched strengthened and disciplined	to serve their human purpose	1250.4312626026092
11507. with a large and circumspect	20th-century technique he wove the materials of national heroes and	events national folklore and children's fairy tales- slavic dances	and love songs- into a solid musical literature which served his	people well and is providing much enjoyment to the world at large	7138.253122008884
11508. of course it must not be forgotten that in achieving this historical	feat prokofieff had the vast resources of his people behind	him; time and economic security; symphony orchestras opera and ballet	companies; choruses chamber music ensembles; soloists; recordings;	broadcastings; television; large and eager audiences	4609.282765125819
11509. it	must be conceded that his native land provided prokofieff with many	of the necessary conditions for great creative incentive: economic	security and cultural opportunities incisive idioms social fermentations	for a new national ideology- a sympathetic public and a large	body of performers especially trained to fulfill his purpose	7353.220060056157
11510. thus	in prokofieff the union of soviet socialist republics produced	one of the great composers of the twentieth century	1730.855787611014
11511. that his moods	even in his early years are those of his people does him honor	as his music honors those who inspired it	3678.6020874291657
11512. that he mastered every aspect	of his medium according to his own great talents and contemporary	judgments is a good and solid symbol of his people under the tremendous	pressures of proclaiming and practising the rigors of a new culture;	and perhaps of even greater significance- his music is strong 20th-century	evidence of the effectiveness of evolution based on a broad	traditionalism for the creative art of music	5881.375312852391
11513. april 10 marked a memorable date in new york's musical history-	indeed in the musical history of the entire eastern united states	3248.7107771422884
11514. on that date the musicians emergency fund organized to furnish	employment for musicians unable to obtain engagements during the	depression and to provide relief for older musicians who lost their fortunes	in the stock market crash observed its 30th anniversary	4195.191738040079
11515. roy mason is essentially a landscape painter whose style and direction	has a kinship with the english watercolorists of the early nineteenth	century especially the beautifully patterned art of john sell	cotman	5189.398714432114
11516. and like this english master mason realizes his subjects	in large simplified masses which though they seem effortless are	in reality the result of skilled design born of hard work and a thorough	distillation of the natural form that inspired them	4298.8732691714085
11517. as a	boy roy mason began the long process of extracting the goodness of the	out-of-doors its tang of weather its change of seasons its variable	moods	4268.595690649065
11518. his father a professional engraver and an amateur landscape	painter took his sons on numerous hunting expeditions and imparted	to them his knowledge and love of nature	2869.111992962865
11519. out of this background of	hunting and fishing it was only natural that roy first painted subjects	he knew best: hunters in the field fishermen in the stream ducks	and geese on the wing- almost always against a vast backdrop of	weather landscape	6711.684096811839
11520. it is this subject matter that has brought mason	a large and enthusiastic following among sportsmen but it is his exceptional	performance with this motif that commends him to artists and	discerning collectors	3550.4160110271323
11521. mason had to earn the privilege of devoting	himself exclusively to painting	957.2882440615656
11522. like many others he had to work	hard long hours in a struggling family business which though it was	allied to art of a kind- the design and production of engraved seals-	bore no relation to the painting of pictures	4225.546574599764
11523. but it did teach	roy the basic techniques of commercial art and later for twelve years	he and his sister nina conducted an advertising art studio in philadelphia	4476.1257104392425
11524. on the death of their father they returned to their home	in batavia new york	1089.5375012668258
11525. after more years of concentrated effort roy	and his brother max finally established a thriving family business	at the old stand	3049.4053721712517
11526. during all this time roy continued to paint	first only on weekends and then as the family business permitted	for longer periods	2187.7404632214857
11527. gradually he withdrew from the shop altogether	and for the past thirty years he has worked independently as a painter	except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions	4512.571203982703
11528. but even	on these the palette often takes over while the shotgun cools off!	except for a rich friendship with the painter chauncey ryder	who gave him the only professional instruction he ever had- and	this was limited to a few lessons though the two artists often went on	painting trips together- roy developed his art by himself	5423.520999148801
11529. in the	best tradition he first taught himself to see then to draw with accuracy	and assurance and then to paint	3043.803966325525
11530. he worked in oil for years before	beginning his work in watercolor and his first public recognition	and early honors including his election to the academy were for	his essays in the heavier medium	3660.977246642355
11531. gradually watercolor claimed his greater	affection until today it has become his major if not exclusive	technique	2113.4102420270106
11532. it has been my privilege to paint with roy mason	on numerous occasions mostly in the vicinity of batavia	1726.935946614977
11533. more often	than not i have found easy excuse to leave my own work and stand at	a respectable distance where i could watch this man transform raw nature	into a composed not imitative painting	5660.811707125064
11534. what i have observed	time and time again is a process of integration integration that begins	as abstract design and gradually takes on recognizable form; color	patterns that are made to weave throughout the whole composition;	and that over-all amazing control of large washes which is the mason	stylemark	4899.9371863783235
11535. finally come those little flicks of a rigger brush and the	job is done	1416.5287304359265
11536. inspiring- yes; instructive- maybe; duplicable-	no!   but for the technical fact we have the artist's	own testimony:   of late years i find that i like best to	work out-of-doors	3120.2884252578287
11537. first i make preliminary watercolor sketches in	quarter scale in which i pay particular attention	to the design principles of three simple values- the lightest	light the middle tone and the darkest dark- by reducing the forms	of my subject to these large patterns	6783.008716006092
11538. if a human figure or wild life	are to be part of the projected final picture i try to place them	in the initial sketch	2595.017892239416
11539. for me these will belong more completely to	their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage though	i freely admit that i do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on	the full sheet when it serves my final purpose	6558.502563889653
11540. i am thoroughly	convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects	nature will do his composing for him; as a result such pictures are	only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before	him	4162.902627462559
11541. just because a tree or other object appears in a certain spot	is absolutely no reason to place it in the same position in the painting	unless the position serves the design of the whole composition	5786.808897557263
11542. if the artist would study his work more thoroughly and move certain	units in his design often only slightly finer pictures would result	2341.358140261517
11543. out of long experience i have found that incidental figures and other	objects like trees logs and bushes can be traced from the original	sketch and moved about in the major areas on the final sheet until they	occupy the right position which i call 'clicking'	7040.807397179376
11544. speed	in painting a picture is valid only when it imparts spontaneity	and crispness but unless the artist has lots of experience so that	he can control rapid execution he would do well to take these first sketches	and soberly reorder their design to achieve a unified composition	4831.009777398516
11545. if i have seemed to emphasize the structure of the composition	i mean to project equal concern for color	2586.268434076551
11546. often in working	out-of-doors under all conditions of light and atmosphere a particular	passage that looked favorable in relation to the subject will be	too bright too dull or too light or too dark when viewed indoors in	a mat	4246.550544919629
11547. when this occurs i make the change on the sketch or on the	final watercolor- if i have been working on a full sheet in the field	4302.688723150621
11548. when working from one of my sketches i square it up and	project its linear form freehand to the watercolor sheet with charcoal	2324.633344835673
11549. when this linear draft is completed i dust it down to a faint	image	1419.5052057409853
11550. from this point i paint in as direct a manner as possible by	flowing on the washes with as pure a color mixture as i can manage	2881.9054761282596
11551. however first	i thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and	design along the lines i have described	2593.037244716653
11552. then i plan my attack:	the parts i will finish first the range of values the accenting of	minor details- all in all mechanics of producing the finished job	with a maximum of crispness	3636.118047702503
11553. the longer i work the more i am sure	that for me at least a workmanlike method is important	2590.1192338683168
11554. trial and	error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles	in the final painting	1731.8332901185652
11555. as for materials i use the	best available	250.69539512712268
11556. i work on a watercolor easel in the field and frequently	resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue	strain	2484.413269941535

11558. i have	used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers but prefer an english	make rough surface in 400-pound weight	1723.1627543332083
11559. after selecting a sheet	and inspecting it for flaws	i sponge it thoroughly on both sides with	clean cold water	2815.0175452643625

11562. the great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that	it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the	watercolorist	2730.8879750611095

11712. three different wavelengths of ultraviolet	radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the	three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources	4301.873540556647

11714. instead	of the observer's eye the image orthicon in the tv camera	does the looking	1653.2824307787462

11716. the video signal is amplified and then	switched in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which	are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of	a second only one wavelength corresponding to red green or blue is	seen	6468.732107562822
11717. to another the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated	by a synchronous motor	1099.2841783675954
11718. this assembly also supplies a 20-cps	this is the same system	as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded	the present simultaneous system	3896.914763413946
11719. three separate amplifiers then	drive a 21-inch tricolor tube	262.3458182949461
11720. the result is a color picture of the	specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet	wavelengths	2828.339269418447

11741. a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining	the effective power of the heart itself	1412.9455987616273
11742. it uses both an ultrasonic	dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor	inserted into the bloodstream	2832.9800315580533
11743. the latter measures the heat carried	away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood	flow	1883.9029663004953
11744. it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer mounted	at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart's left	ventricle to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself	5332.647913746133
11745. this pressure	measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning	measurement is made	1414.3100874745858
11746. a simplified version of the instrumentation	for this procedure is shown in fig 2	1413.2790795627272
11747. outputs of the two	systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge	followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder	2730.095874863706
11748. from this doctors can read heart rate change in diameter pressure	and effective heart power	1639.9356398874875
11749. several	years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule	which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal	pressure data to external receivers	3225.1813991860413
11750. this original capsule contained	a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm in	diameter	2140.112590135087
11751. battery life limited the use of this pill to about 8	to 30 hours maximum	1094.424680625634
11752. a refinement of this technique has been described	by drs zworykin and farrar and mr berkely of the medical	electronics center of the rockefeller institute	3888.706272817254
11753. in this	novel arrangement the pill is much smaller and contains only a resonant	circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing	transducer	2596.159330827888
11754. as shown in fig 4 an external antenna is placed over	or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc	bursts	3913.1935457253944
11755. the energy received by the pill causes the resonant	circuit to ring on after the burst and this ringing takes	place at the resonant frequency of the pill	2994.88046004865
11756. these frequencies	are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst	of transmitted energy and after the pill has been calibrated	precise internal pressure indications can be obtained	4861.792753664166
11757. one of	the advantages of this method is that the pill can remain in the	patient for several days permitting observation under natural conditions	2460.116309009696
11758. applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are	planned for future experiments	1181.2408936387885
11759. one	of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine	detection is in the exploration of the human body	2019.2374692065314
11760. our readers	are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent	out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects	3693.918136662143
11761. various	methods of pulsing scanning and displaying these sound waves are used	to detect submarines map ocean floors and even communicate under water	2323.577646988805
11762. in medicine the frequencies are much higher transducers and the	sonar beams themselves are much smaller and different scanning techniques	may be used but the principles involved are the same as in sonar	5308.480211479318
11763. because the body contains so much liquid transmission of	ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels	1710.9310486447728
11764. bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic	signals	952.8275445172458
11765. based on this phenomenon a number of investigators have used	this method to look through human organs	1410.3243794819616
11766. a good example of	the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers	presented by dr g baum who has explored the human eye	3884.26180437978
11767. he	can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate	blindness due to glaucoma	1105.5151692447218
11768. the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically	is illustrated in fig 6	1188.1450053146214
11769. the transducer is coupled to the	body through a water bath not shown	790.9336803627054
11770. for display dr baum uses	a portion of an f an airborne radar indicator and then photographs	the screen to obtain a permanent record	3706.7807365360723
11771. a typical sonogram	of a human eye together with a description of the anatomical	parts is shown in fig 5	1880.187115208988
11772. the frequency used for these experiments	is 15 mc and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy	lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter	4858.582395914853
11773. the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan just like	a radar antenna while the entire transducer structure is moved over a	90-degree arc in front of the eye to look into all corners	3873.0469360527845
11774. the total	picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector	scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period	3067.8635512989413
11775. drs	howry	and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied	the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have	obtained extremely good results	3092.672150019084
11776. by submerging the patient in a tub	and rotating the transducer while the scanning goes on they have been	able to get cross-section views of the neck as shown in fig 7 as	well as many other hitherto impossible insights	6315.013361897878
11777. as mentioned before	bone reflects the sound energy and in fig 7 the portion of the	spine shows as the black area in the center	2621.23758482237
11778. arteries and veins are apparent	by their black blood-filled centers and the surrounding white	walls	1643.7739906520935

11780. oersted's boyhood represented a minimal chance of either	attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a	span of life	3694.6902431949666
11781. he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on	the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august	14 1777	2596.297793568075
11782. his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender	income made it difficult to feed his family let alone educate	them in a town without even a school	4475.878179434269
11783. the two older boys hans and anders	his junior by a year therefore went daily to the home of a	warm	and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german; his wife	taught the two boys to read and write danish	4210.91442580262
11784. other brothers later joined	them for instruction with oldenburg the wigmaker and also arithmetic	was added to bible reading german and danish in the informal	curriculum	4096.193607662275
11785. oldenburg's contributions were soon exhausted and the	boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town's learned such as	the pastor to supplement the simple teaching	2993.2240185193887
11786. from the town surveyor	hans learned drawing and mathematics and from a university student	some academic subjects	2137.1850971867198
11787. the mayor of the town taught them english	and french	374.8565560348047
11788. whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed	on to each other; they read every book that they could borrow in the	village	3471.821796808209
11789. at 12 hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in	the apothecary shop which helped stimulate his interest in medicine	and science	2318.327045265278
11790. his earlier love for literature and history remained with	him for his entire life	1405.6835177149828
11791. in 1793 the brothers decided to enter	the university of copenhagen and the following	spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the	autumn session	2860.433961180216
11792. while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine	physics and astronomy his brother studied law	1879.9229294255506
11793. the brothers continued	to help each other during their studies sharing a joint purse	lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of	their aunt	2978.2268388629645
11794. they supplemented their income by small government assistance	by tutoring and economizing wherever they could	1637.0716815340124
11795. so impressive	were those serious years of study at the university that hans later	wrote to be perfectly free the young man must revel in the great	kingdom of thought and imagination; there is a struggle there in which	if he falls it is easy for him to rise again there is freedom	of utterance there which draws after it no irreparable consequences on	society h	5792.717939898749
11796. i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day	overcame a new difficulty gained a new truth or banished a previous	error	3276.4804330217908
11797. he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing	about science	503.90800981445307
11798. in this third year at the university hans in 1797	was awarded the first important token of recognition a gold medal for	his essay on limits of poetry and prose	4819.47014600419
11799. he completed his training	in pharmacy also taking his degree with high honors in 1797	and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with	a prize for an essay in medicine	3761.904126660903
11800. he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis	which later was accepted in chemical practices	1406.4050854616607
11801. activity	han's student days were at a time when europe	was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america	and in france germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms	and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the	continent	4427.257310002962
11802. the new century opened with oersted beginning	his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen	and as lecturer at the university	3704.84306192571
11803. he was stirred by the announcement	of volta's	discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied	the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis	2597.1826803805493
11804. the following	year he devoted to the customary wanderjahr traveling in	germany france and the netherlands meeting the philosophers schelling	fichte and tieck	3480.3169479072617
11805. he also met count rumford	who was then serving the elector	of bavaria and the physicist ritter; these were oersted's main	contacts in science	2464.059677577151
11806. from go^ttingen where he stayed	for 10 days he wrote the first question asked everywhere is	about galvanism	2365.8454650239755
11807. as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass	tubes i have invented i have had quite a small one made here of	four glass	tubes and intend to carry it with me	3661.3786005339307
11808. oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks continuing	their correspondence after he left	2352.114387591625
11809. with ritter he was exposed	to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host's	fertile but disorganized mind	1869.8809544565454
11810. oersted remodeled ritter's notes	into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france	for its annual prize of 3000 francs	3674.815698952618
11811. the sound discoveries of	this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize	was never awarded to him	2157.555242426845
11812. in may 1803 ritter in another flight	of fancy wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy	2595.040795806554
11813. he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and	indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided	with the years of important electrical discoveries	2978.6364615473467
11814. thus 1745 corresponded	to the invention of the leiden jar by kleist 1764	that of the electrophorus by wilcke 1782 produced the condenser of	volta and 1801 the voltaic pile	4828.363016946284

11816. this we might well witness	22.193892941876705
11817. ritter died in 1810 and	oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of	it	1878.0547762089554
11818. in 1803 oersted returned to copenhagen and applied for	the university's chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably	considered more a philosopher than a physicist	4477.429615856263
11819. however he continued	experimenting and lecturing publishing the results of his experiments	in german and danish periodicals	1421.0101835644618
11820. in 1806 his ambition was	realized and he became professor of physics at the copenhagen university	though not realizing full professorship until 1817	3477.779016654492
11821. during oersted's attendance at the university it was poorly	equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences	1567.9331049417003
11822. he was however fortunate in his contact with prof j g	l manthey teacher of chemistry who in addition to	his academic chair was	also proprietor of the lion pharmacy in	copenhagen where oersted assisted him	5789.439067828428
11823. manthey maintained a valuable	collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at oersted's	disposal during and after his graduation	1887.3619902505652
11824. in 1800 manthey went	abroad and oersted was appointed manager of the lion pharmacy	1404.1879187242998
11825. in	february 1801 oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus	and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates	of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates	of zinc and lead	4221.307819533754
11826. in the following year 1803 oersted simultaneously	with davy discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic	battery more than did salts	3477.6861053840375
11827. eager as he was to pursue this promising	line he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy	and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university	that he could devote only sunday afternoons to galvanizing	4223.929240472292
11828. he assumed his academic career with the same intensity and	thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood	3058.9419407239143
11829. the	university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor	represented the upper social level	1588.5401854007805
11830. his broad interest in literary political	and philosophical movements opened many doors to him	1416.4589967613745
11831. his friends	were numerous and their ties to him were strong	498.1356105361726
11832. the years	1812 and 1813 saw him in germany and france again but on this	visit to berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his	first journey	5153.268805802451
11833. in berlin he published his views of the chemical laws	of nature in german and this was issued in french translation	under the title recherches sur l'identite des forces chimiques	et electriques a work held in very high esteem by the new	generation	of research chemists	4690.412801872856
11834. his interest in finding a relationship between	voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated	1648.0312525052275
11835. chapter	8 is entitled on magnetism and in it are included such	remarks as one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces	with the electrical forces	2985.679847864042
11836. the great resemblance between electrical	and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their	laws necessarily would bring about this comparison	3264.4642621392127
11837. it is true that	nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication;	but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those	depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest	difference h	4057.895762645515
11838. the form of galvanic activity is halfway between	the magnetic form and the electrical form	1660.2152093836307
11839. there forces are more latent	than in electricity and less than in magnetism h	940.1793630368957
11840. but in such	an important question we would be satisfied if the judgment were that	the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity	and magnetism were only a difficulty and not a thing which is	contrary to it h	6583.418493824605
11841. one could also add to these analogies that steel	loses its magnetism by heat which proves that steel becomes a better	conductor through a rise in temperature just as electrical bodies do	3445.8927083310364
11842. it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature as	proven by bruckmann and coulomb	2361.9459396919947
11843. by that one feels that magnetic	forces are as general as electrical forces	795.1885464845891
11844. an attempt should be made	to see if electricity in its most latent stage has any action on the	magnet as such	3273.5884214385337
11845. his plan and intent were clearly charted	93.66790476114983
11846. oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and	political discussions	1415.3203235250587

11849. he devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was	caused to glow by an electric current	1566.5734582789923

11854. of electromagnetism	the association between electric	forces and magnetic forces had been	recognized by investigators for many decades	2359.981886933917
11855. electrical literature	contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and	had altered the polarity of compass needles	1727.9731364907007
11856. in the late 1700's	beccaria and van marum among others had magnetized iron by sending	an electrostatic charge through it	2827.119706201358
11857. beccaria had almost stumbled on	a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge	from a leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece	of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic	3657.537578953653
11858. the resulting magnetic	effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise	1180.1126280641317
11859. the experiments of romagnosi and others have already been noted but	no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these	two primary forces	2332.7936026512552
11860. oersted's own earlier experiments were unimpressive	possibly because he had like other experimenters laid the conducting	wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it	4084.9165998718026
11861. the sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains	ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the	university related that the first direct event that led to the publication	of oersted's discovery occurred during a private lecture made	before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820	5281.427520481291
11862. at	this lecture oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel	to a magnetic needle	2122.0366877330403
