12603. out of many factors which	might be cited five are most important:  plastics combine	such properties as built-in color light weight optional transparency	or translucency resistance to corrosion as well as the ease of fabrication	3769.6216279837986
12604. according to one	major producer materials for a typical plastic sign are approximately	25% less costly than for a comparable neon unit	3256.4785338018287
12605. shipping cost is	also reduced; a 3-by- 6-ft plastic sign weighs about 120 lb	compared to 275-300 lb for neon	1874.046074597672
12606. the weight advantage plus greater	durability of the plastic unit yields a saving of about one-fifth	in shipping	2353.54598044396
12607. the lighter weight also means less costly supports and mountings	are needed	639.9269578580596
12608. finally maintenance costs on plastic signs are	much lower than on fragile neon signs	1396.0240115959773
12609. they offer exceptional	design freedom making it	possible to incorporate contours and details	which give free range to the talents of the designer	2314.5450389869757
12610. vacuum- and pressure-formed	sheet plastics fill the gap between cardboard and molded	plastics	1182.3947332254384
12611. pre-decoration	low-cost molds and the freedom to form large	and small thick and thin materials make plastics tailor-made for the	industry	2030.438511577433
12612. plastics signs work around the clock	65.39929273486523
12613. internal	illumination protected from the elements gives them powerful visual	appeal at night; during daylight hours their brilliant colors command	attention and interest	2332.2596778493794
12614. advances in equipment and fabrication	techniques give the sign or display manufacturer an extremely wide	choice of production techniques ranging from injection molding for	intricate smaller-size mass-production signs	to vacuum and pressure forming for larger signs of limited	runs	6222.512395853785
12615. among the newest fabrication methods to enter the display field	what plastics	to use	938.8562104857871
12616. with its outstanding	optical characteristics weather resistance and formability strongly	dominates the picture	1189.4239441262284
12617. at present both the familiar cast acrylic	and the newer extruded sheets are being used by sign manufacturers	with extruded now representing an estimated 10% of the total	2990.145733234721
12618. of interest is a recent	announcement by du pont's	polychemicals dept of a new methyl methacrylate	monomer designated as monocite h 100 which was developed	specifically for production of cast acrylic sheets for the sign and	lighting industry	6069.048217234783
12619. sheeting cast from this material reportedly weighs	only one-third as much as glass is impervious to all kinds of weather	and will not yellow	2460.5607294459232
12620. its high impact strength even at low temperatures	resists chipping cracking and crazing according to du pont	2128.4611122987176
12621. cellulose acetate butyrate is used extensively for vacuum-formed	signs background panels and molded or formed letters because of its	exceptional toughness ease of forming and excellent weathering properties	2989.3493692807665
12622. its clarity and good optical properties are other important	factors	562.5517856309478
12623. new to the field is a duplex type butyrate laminate in which	the two sheets of the laminate are of different color	2182.8702977308385
12624. thermoforming	the laminate and then sanding away the top layer is a quick and economical	way to produce a two-color sign	3046.0310918851856
12625. for specialized types of displays such as large three-dimensional	units reproducing a product package human or animal figures	etc reinforced plastics and rotationally molded vinyl plastisols	are other materials frequently used	3332.356869247566
12626. a relative newcomer	in	outdoor signs is mylar polyester film now used as a printed overlay	for trans-illuminated signs	2601.398611722313
12627. for outdoor signs and	displays where the problem of weathering resistance is no longer a	factor the choice of plastics is almost unlimited	2326.3413810161755
12628. here may be found	regular and impact styrene cellulose acetate cellulose butyrate and	cellulose propionate acrylic vinyl expandable styrene foam and polyethylene	3293.0022028893204
12629. the final choice of material depends upon such factors as	costs method of fabrication degree of complexity number of units	required time available for tooling and projected life expectancy of	the unit	3439.505182773949
12630. often the finished sign or display incorporates several types	of plastics and two or more fabricating techniques	2134.740451084475
12631. billboards	one of the most significant advancements in design	of plastics signs is the so-called trans-illuminated billboard now	being produced by several large sign manufacturers such as advance	neon sign co los angeles and industrial electric inc	new orleans la	4203.091633363312
12632. the essential difference between the new	trans-illuminated boards and existing billboards is that the former	constructed of translucent plastic panels are lighted from within	3686.280300259339
12633. with the source of light behind the copy there is no loss of lumen output	as with conventional boards illuminated by means of reflected light	2604.280847867814
12634. also the light sources are shielded from dirt and weather exposure	and cannot obstruct the view of the sign	2602.770202475712
12635. the copy itself	including any text or illustrations is reproduced in full color directly	on a thin mylar polyester film by a photo screen process	2601.904896531009
12636. the	film has an adhesive on the back which permits it to be stripped onto	the acrylic panels forming the sign and also to be stripped off for	replacement by new copy as required	5499.6347063362955
12637. spare sets of face panels simplify	the change from one copy or message to another; new panels are exchanged	for the old right in the field on a single trip	3247.3736360899566
12638. panels with	outdated copy are returned to the sign shop so a new message can be applied	2114.0610075659315
12639. signs of this type have already made their appearance	in several larger cities and others are on the way	1731.154459309871
12640. it is believed that	these boards will within the next few years replace many of the	conventional flood-lighted boards now in use	3265.080105053047
12641. trans-illuminated	signs also show versatility in other directions	167.45333055539325

12676. from	the inside out	don't insert your components into fixed openings	they may or may not fit; position your components before you close	them in	3883.45572177371

13824. why and when should	tooth-straightening be undertaken	140.91245424810216

13826. occlusion is the dentist's expression	for the way teeth fit together when the jaws are closed	1889.5854175657648
13827. malocclusion	or a bad fit is what parents need to look out for	787.5633630534692
13828. one main type	of malocclusion is characterized by a receding chin and protruding upper	front teeth	1895.247480395309
13829. a chin too prominent in relation to the rest of the	face a thrusting forward of the lower front teeth an overdeveloped lower	jawbone and an underdeveloped upper jaw indicate the opposite type	of malocclusion	3762.5219517737705
13830. these two basic malformations have of course	many variations	393.11945453642704
13831. a child probably requires some form of treatment	if he has any of the following conditions:  a noticeable	protrusion of the upper or lower jaw	2602.5606925431916
13832. crooked overlapping	twisted or widely spaced teeth	141.84313404818025
13833. front teeth not meeting	when the back teeth close	263.6290139044865
13834. upper teeth completely covering	the lowers when the back teeth close	762.3362595156333
13835. the eyeteeth	beginning	to protrude like fangs	94.22505064298973
13836. second teeth that have come in before	the first ones have fallen out making a double row	2125.345276083838
13837. contrary	to the thinking of 30 to 40 years ago when all malocclusion was	blamed on some unfortunate habit recent studies show that most tooth	irregularity has at least its beginning in hereditary predisposition	3659.174436738397
13838. however this does not mean that a child's teeth or jaws must	necessarily resemble those of someone in his family	2812.417882966612
13839. tooth deformity	may be the result of excessive thumb- or finger-sucking tongue-thrusting	or lip-sucking- but it's important to remember that	there's a difference between normal and excessive sucking	habits	3101.4755309947495
13840. it's perfectly normal for babies to suck their thumbs and	no mother need worry if a child continues this habit until he is two	or three years old	4493.5898474753685
13841. occasional sucking up to the fifth year may not affect	a youngster's teeth; but after that if thumb-sucking pressure	is frequent it will have an effect	2730.237523306981
13842. malocclusion can also	result if baby teeth are lost too soon or retained too long	1650.0616583123215
13843. if a child	loses a molar at the age of two the adjoining teeth may shift toward	the empty space thus narrowing the place intended for the permanent	ones and producing a jumble	3583.19446147868

13845. every orthodontist sees children who are embarrassed by	their malformed teeth	504.2508389278696

13848. yet from the dentist's	point of view bad-fitting teeth should be corrected for physical reasons	1648.00402570218
13849. bad alignment may result in early loss of teeth through	a breakdown of the bony structure that supports their roots	1874.904462049606
13850. this serious	condition popularly known as pyorrhea is one of the chief causes	of tooth loss in adults	2365.5021961393477
13851. then too misplaced or jammed-together	teeth are prone to trapping food particles increasing the	likelihood of rapid decay	1576.832308156952
13852. for these and other reasons says dr	brodie orthodontics can prolong the life of teeth	1648.2698727494212
13853. the failure of teeth to fit together when closed interferes with normal	chewing so that a child may swallow food whole and put a burden	on his digestive system	3100.135393687361

13856. how of straightening	most orthodontic work is done on children	between the ages of 10 and 14 though there have been patients	as young as two and as old as 55 says dr brodie	5517.448145300981
13857. in	the period from 10 to 14 the permanent set of teeth is usually completed	yet the continuing growth of bony tissue makes moving badly placed	teeth comparatively easy	3111.2756841399123
13858. orthodontic work is possible because teeth	are held firmly but not rigidly by a system of peridontal membrane with	an involved nerve network to the bone in the jaw; they are not	anchored directly to the bone	5925.935332595642
13859. abnormal pressure applied over a period	of time produces a change in the bony deposit so a tooth functions	normally in the new position into which it has been guided	3228.099847005516
13860. what	can 10-year-old susan expect when she enters the orthodontist's	office	751.0090919135307
13861. on her first visit the orthodontist will take x rays	photographs tooth measurements and tooth prints- an impression	of the mouth that permits him to study her teeth and jaws	3237.396962244501
13862. if he decides to proceed he will custom-make for susie an appliance	consisting of bands plastic plates fine wires and tiny springs	3264.767141792569
13863. this	appliance will exert a gentle and continuous or intermittent pressure	on the bone	953.2337301759435
13864. as the tooth moves bone cells on the pressure side	of it will dissolve and new ones will form on the side from which the	tooth has moved	4507.797297893894
13865. this must be done at the rate at which new bony tissue	grows and no faster	1252.8449204548062

14220. it is because each side has	sought to implement its distinctive theological belief through legislation	and thus indirectly force its belief or at least the practical	consequences thereof upon others	4851.380749887773
14221. it is always a temptation	for a religious organization especially a powerful or dominant	one to impose through the clenched fist of the law its creedal viewpoint	upon others	3105.4764596400237
14222. both roman catholics and protestants have succumbed	to this temptation in the past	1176.5148773063713
14223. consider what happened during	world war 1 when the protestant churches united to push the	prohibition law through congress	1729.5222801933348
14224. many of them sincerely believe	that the use of liquor in any form or in any degree is intrinsically	evil and sinful	3266.837901770733
14225. with over four million american men away at war protestants	forced their distinctive theological belief upon the general	public	1727.082714945204
14226. with the return of our soldiers it soon became apparent that	the belief was not shared by the great majority of citizens	3239.1571785682595
14227. the attempt	to enforce that belief ushered in a reign of bootleggers racketeers	hijackers and gangsters that led to a breakdown of law unparalleled	in our history	2831.5668357416716
14228. the so-called noble experiment came to an	inglorious end	392.5900431623034
14229. that tumultuous painful and costly experience	shows clearly that a law expressing a moral judgment cannot be enforced	when it has little correspondence with the general view of society	3118.4753786547167
14230. that experience holds a lesson for us all in regard to birth control	today	1404.8527730966362
14231. up to the turn of the century contraception was condemned	by all christian churches as immoral unnatural and contrary	to divine law	2173.9393104710284
14232. this was generally reflected in the civil laws of christian	countries	749.7346228858663
14233. today the roman catholic and orthodox churches	stand virtually alone in holding that conviction	933.3879614282245
14234. the various lambeth	conferences expressing the anglican viewpoint mirror the gradual	change that has taken place among protestants generally	2604.9949027491593
14235. in 1920 the lambeth conference repeated its 1908 condemnation of contraception	and issued an emphatic warning against the use of unnatural	means for the avoidance of conception together with the grave dangers-	physical moral and religious- thereby incurred and against	the evils which the extension of such use threaten the race	5015.136583871253
14236. denouncing	the view that the sexual union is an end in itself the conference	declared: we steadfastly uphold what must always be regarded	as the governing considerations of christian marriage	4837.76733108056
14237. one is the	primary purpose for which marriage exists namely the continuance	of the race through the gift and heritage of children; the other is	the paramount importance in married life of deliberate and thoughtful	self-control	3854.4791063968996
14238. the conference called for a vigorous campaign against	the open or secret sale of contraceptives	1651.6163954500432
14239. in 1930 the lambeth	conference again affirmed the primary purpose of marriage to be	the procreation of children but conceded that in certain limited circumstances	contraception might be morally legitimate	3214.475248614067
14240. in 1958	the conference endorsed birth control as the responsibility laid by	god on parents everywhere	1888.1344591357822
14241. many other protestant denominations	preceded the anglicans in such action	376.0206250001414
14242. in march 1931 22 out	of 28 members of a committee of the federal council of churches ratified	artificial methods of birth control	3463.9691919295437
14243. as to the necessity	the committee declared for some form of effective control of the	size of the family and the spacing of children and consequently of control	of conception there can be no question h	3853.2034441342175
14244. there is general agreement	also that sex union between husbands and wives as an expression	of mutual affection without relation to procreation is right	3683.1786766615173
14245. since then many protestant denominations have made separate	pronouncements in which they not only approved birth control but declared	it at times to be a religious duty	2844.5633485329417
14246. what determines the morality	they state is not the means used but the motive	1419.9162142179796
14247. in	general the means that prove most effective are	considered the most ethical	789.9862902924981
14248. this development is reflected in	the action taken in february 1961 by the general board of the	national	council of churches the largest protestant organization in the	us	4472.223622926757
14249. the board approved and commended the use of birth-control	devices as a part of christian responsibility in family planning	1725.8313213811264
14250. it	called for opposition to laws and institutional practices restricting	the information or availability of contraceptives	1883.8073890236028
14251. the general	board declared: most of the protestant churches hold contraception	and periodic continence to be morally right when the motives are	right h	2466.609292813412
14252. the general protestant conviction is that motives rather	than methods form the primary moral issue provided the methods are	limited to the prevention of conception	3903.054492313839
14253. an action once universally	condemned by all christian churches and forbidden by the civil	law is now not only approved by the overwhelming majority of protestant	denominations but also deemed at certain times to be a positive	religious duty	4135.952846642785
14254. this viewpoint has now been translated into	action by the majority of people in this country	1886.0800591572356
14255. repeated polls have	disclosed that most married couples are now using contraceptives in the	practice of birth control	1571.6370535331575
14256. for all concerned with social-welfare	legislation the significance of this radical and revolutionary	change in the thought and habits of the vast majority of the american	people is clear profound and far-reaching	5167.602296357387
14257. to try to oppose the general	religious and moral conviction of such a majority by a legislative	fiat would be to invite the same breakdown of law and order that was	occasioned by the ill-starred prohibition experiment	3942.836010764762
14258. this brings	us to the fact that the realities we are dealing with lie not in	the field of civil legislation but in the realm of conscience and religion:	they are moral judgments and matters of theological belief	6051.337016869198
14259. conscience and religion are concerned with private sin: the civil	law is concerned with public crimes	1268.0882810864161
14260. only confusion failure	and anarchy result when the effort is made to impose upon the civil authority	the impossible task of policing private homes to preclude the	possibility of sin	4839.1035727413955
14261. among the chief victims of such an ill-conceived	imposition would be religion itself	789.69003874471
14262. on april 17 1610 the sturdy little three-masted bark discovery	weighed anchor in st katherine's pool london and	floated down the thames toward the sea	3902.337991872976
14263. she carried besides her captain	a crew of twenty-one and provisions for a voyage of exploration	of the arctic waters of north america	2313.3532641649035
14264. seventeen months later	on september 6 1611 an irish fishing boat sighted the discovery	limping eastward outside galway bay	2605.2111843642697
14265. when she reached port	she was found to have on board only eight men all near starvation	1417.5701907588473
14266. the	captain was gone and the mate was gone	389.92771514205907
14267. the man who now commanded	her had started the voyage as an ordinary seaman	946.9258368906494
14268. what disaster	struck the discovery during those seventeen months	389.32195888132594
14269. what happened	to the fourteen missing men	94.41908559676368
14270. these questions have remained	one of the great sea mysteries of all time	1177.1441422641017
14271. for hundreds of years the	evidence available consisted of the captain's fragmentary journal	a highly prejudiced account by one of the survivors a note	found in a dead man's desk on board and several second-hand	reports	3858.219918509225
14272. all told they offered a highly confused picture	252.56933535072676
14273. but	since 1927 researchers digging into ancient court records and legal	files have been able to find illuminating pieces of information	2022.3909614196061
14274. not	enough to do away with all doubts but sufficient to give a fairly accurate	picture of the events of the voyage	3254.4865335611203
14275. historians have had	two reasons for persisting so long in their investigations	641.5692177935439
14276. first	they wanted to clarify a tantalizing bizarre enigma	395.68437988830254
14277. second they believed	it important to determine the fate of the captain- a man whose	name is permanently stamped on our maps on american towns and counties	on a great american river and on half a million square miles	of arctic seas	4394.400501499375
14278. this	is the story of his last tragic voyage as nearly as we are able- or	ever probably will be able- to determine:   the sailing in	the spring of 1610 was hudson's fourth in four years	5773.262507609432
14279. each time	his objective had been the same- a direct water passage from western	europe to the far east	1735.3132180693403
14280. in 1607 and 1608 the english muscovy	company had sent him northward to look for a route over the north pole	or across the top of russia	4284.488083950311
14281. twice he had failed and the muscovy	company indicated it would not back him again	1096.8550578641411
14282. in 1609 the	dutch east india company hired hudson gave him two learned geographers	fitted him out with a ship called the half moon and supplied	him with dutch sailors	4833.971294166542
14283. this time he turned westward to the	middle atlantic coast of north america	791.8220192329785
14284. his chief discovery was important-	the great north river- but it produced	no northwest passage	1634.038739474941
14285. when the half moon put in at	dartmouth england in the fall of 1609 word of hudson's findings	leaked out and english interest in him revived	2720.232063103142
14286. the government	forbade hudson to return to amsterdam with his ship	746.9211727258289
14287. he thereupon went	to london and spent the winter talking to men of wealth	941.0807671127592
14288. by springtime	he was supported by a rich merchant syndicate under the patronage	of henry prince of wales	2349.15776874435
14289. he had obtained and provisioned a veteran	ship called the discovery and had recruited a crew of twenty-one	the largest he had ever commanded	2464.437456592541
14290. the purpose of this	fourth voyage was clear	248.85030149707342
14291. a century of exploration had established that	a great land mass north and south america lay between europe	and	the indies	2040.8905082304416
14292. one by one the openings in the coast that promised a	passage through had been explored and discarded	2364.3503321913963
14293. in fact hudson's	sail up the great north river had disposed of one of the last hopes	1415.760290300525
14294. but there remained one mysterious unexplored gap far to	the north	752.2397555502406
14295. nearly twenty-five years before captain john davis had	noted as he sailed near the arctic circle a very great gulf the	water whirling and roaring as it were the meeting of tides	3464.8220078376207
14296. he	named this opening between baffin island and labrador the furious	overfall	963.4371425510257
14297. in 1602 george waymouth in the same little discovery that	hudson now commanded had sailed 300 miles up the strait before his	frightened men turned the ship back	2989.1566483171473
14298. hudson now proposed to sail all	the	way through and test the seas beyond for the long-sought waterway	2358.723041100483
14299. even hudson experienced in arctic sailing and determined as he	was must have had qualms as he slid down the thames	2038.096372353331
14300. ahead were perilous	ice-filled waters	22.43865982371079
14301. on previous voyages it had been in precisely	such dangerous situations that he had failed as a leader and captain	1884.424231416258
14302. on the second voyage he had turned back at the frozen island of	novaya zemlya and meekly given the crew a certificate stating that	he did so of his own free will- which was obviously not the case	6077.231388551211
14303. on	the third voyage a near-mutiny rising from a quarrel between dutch	and english crew members on the half moon had almost forced him	to head the ship back to amsterdam in mid-atlantic	3548.2431288247667
14304. worse	his present crew included five men who had sailed with him before	1179.7829635470969

14306. the	mate robert juet who had kept the journal on the half moon	was experienced- but he was a bitter old man ready to complain or	desert at any opportunity	4814.126065793385
14307. philip staffe the ship's carpenter was	a good worker but perversely independent	636.7247966802863
14308. arnold lodley and michael	perse were like the rest- lukewarm ready to swing against hudson	in a crisis	2366.3386860700657
14309. but men willing to sail at all into waters where	wooden ships could be crushed like eggs were hard to find	2024.4237590768134
14310. hudson	knew he had to use these men as long as he remained an explorer	1652.6406572519013
14311. and	he refused to be anything else	93.32781861451221
14312. it is believed that hudson	was related to other seafaring men of the muscovy company and was	trained	on company ships	3033.771603974155
14313. he was a londoner married with three sons	166.38858934768368
14314. in 1610	hudson was probably in his early forties a good navigator a stubborn	voyager but otherwise fatally unsuited to his chosen profession	3479.0188063735486
14315. hudson's first error of the fourth voyage occurred only a	few miles down the thames	1104.1001646655573
14316. there at the river's edge waited one henry	greene whom hudson listed as a clerk	1664.6018301143354
14317. greene was in actuality	a young ruffian from kent who had broken with his parents in	order to keep the company he preferred- pimps panders and whores	2867.1448082544293
14318. he was not the sort of sailor hudson wanted his backers to see on board	and he had greene wait at gravesend where the discovery picked	him up	4502.815753384106
14319. for the first three weeks the ship skirted up the	east coast of great britain then turned westward	1571.5744299938447
14320. on may 11 she	reached iceland	64.93773979012352
14321. poor winds and fog locked her up in a harbor the	crew called lousie bay	1099.5317293960165
14322. the subsequent two-weeks wait made the	crew quarrelsome	251.177927310706

14326. early in june the discovery passed desolation	and in mid-june entered the furious overfall	1405.7015066746455
14327. floating ice bore down from the north and west	263.7222469930208
14328. fog hung	over the route constantly	65.38042549721771
14329. turbulent tides rose as much as fifty feet	167.70766029818049
14330. the ship's compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic	north pole	1405.8368725208834
14331. as the bergs grew larger hudson was	forced to turn south into what is now ungava bay an inlet of the	great strait	2322.016096426843

14333. the trouble	was at least partly juet's doing	168.4313059420362

14335. the great	crushing ice masses coming into view made him sound like the voice	of pure reason	1425.7794950649436
14336. a group of sailors announced to hudson that they would	sail no farther	1185.7962751733573
14337. instead of quelling the dissension as many	captains of the era would have done	hudson decided to be reasonable	1747.201985125909
14338. he went to his cabin and emerged carrying a large chart which	he set up in view of the crew	2810.8832001849773
14339. patiently he explained what he knew	about their course and their objectives	642.6357944875429
14340. when hudson had finished	the town meeting broke down into a general wordy	argument	1423.8003079384346
14341. one man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds he would give ninety	of them to be back in england	2035.625031342221
14342. up spoke carpenter staffe who	said he wouldn't give ten pounds to be home	1406.6514039673211
14343. the meeting broke up	2.9487302515177216
14344. hudson was free to sail on	65.28459020622059
14345. all through july the discovery picked her way along the 450-mile-long	strait avoiding ice and rocky islands	1416.1634865843378
14346. on august 3 two massive	headlands reared out of the mists- great gateways never before	so far as hudson knew seen by europeans	3482.516928276937
14347. to starboard was a cape	a thousand feet high patched with ice and snow populated by thousands	of screaming sea birds	2038.2640451307009

14349. hudson named the capes digges and	wolstenholme for two of his backers	639.0550440316849
14350. hudson pointed the discovery	down the east coast of the newly discovered sea	confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the	pacific	4077.5178965774803

14355. this was the bitter end and hudson seemed to	know he was destined to failure	1099.7866738910436

14357. north and south east and west back and forth	he sailed in the land-locked bay plowing furiously forward until land	appeared then turning to repeat the process day after day week after	week	3564.572855120846
14358. hundreds of miles to the north the route back to england	through the furious overfall was again filling with ice	2812.02660397452
14359. the men were at first puzzled then angered by the aimless tacking	641.4193188519625
14360. once more juet's complaints were the loudest	140.88240363566467

14365. juet had made plentiful enemies several men	stepped forward	261.98673596848494

14369. hudson deposed juet and cut his pay	93.4596335057152
14370. the new	mate was robert bylot talented but inexperienced	391.0941948049955
14371. there were other	shifts and pay cuts according to the way individuals had conducted themselves	1099.889361140538

14378. thomas douglas fifth earl of selkirk a noble humanitarian	scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native highlands	conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the red river	of the north	5916.798413659545

14381. the grant which stretched	southward to lake traverse- the headwaters of the red- was	made in may 1811 and by october of that year a small group of scots	was settling for the winter at york factory on hudson bay	4212.0163926297155

14386. the latter members of two regiments of swiss mercenaries transported	by great britain to canada to fight the americans in the	war of 1812 had settled in montreal and kingston at the close of	the war in 1815	6054.252953670929
14387. selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go	to red river where they were to serve as a military force to protect	his settlers from the hostile northwest company which resented the	intrusion of farmers into the fur traders' empire	4309.024436062563

14390. when late in the summer the full extent of the damage was	assessed all but fifty of the scots swiss and metis moved up	the red to the mouth of the pembina river	5311.253522901782

14401. it was dickson	who suggested to lord selkirk that he return to the atlantic coast	by way of the united states	2018.4662968723646

14411. this	epic effort to secure seed for the colony cost selkirk 1040	642.1143586860659
14412. nevertheless so short was the supply of seed that the settlers were	forced to retreat to fort daer for food	2798.4826345956258
14413. thereafter seed and food became	more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round	1421.4877842741148

14417. hercules	l dousman fur trader and merchant at prairie du chien contracted	to supply selkirk's people with some 300 head of cattle and	alexis bailly and francois labothe were hired as drovers	3439.352004279181
14418. bailly	after leaving fort snelling in august 1821 was forced to leave	some of the cattle at the hudson's bay company's post on lake	traverse in the sieux country and reached fort garry as the	selkirk hudson's bay company center was now called late in the	fall	7141.8278218356645

14430. at fort garry some of the swiss also decided	to cast their lot with the united states and in 1823 several families	paid guides to take them to fort snelling	4837.336740683297
14431. the disasters of 1825-1826	caused more to leave	165.9374043953059

14436. in 1837 157 red river people with more than 200 cattle were	living on the reservation at fort snelling	2588.6467848648435
14437. below the fort	high bluffs extended uninterruptedly for six miles along the mississippi	river	945.9971218528914

14440. the resultant town platted in 1847 and named for the patron of father	galtier's mission st paul was to become an important center	of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those selkirkers	who remained at red river	6666.139282673712
14441. while population at fort	garry increased rapidly from 2417 in 1831 to 4369 in 1840 economic	opportunities did not increase at a similar rate	2450.8865003070705
14442. accordingly though	the practice violated the no-trading provision of the selkirk charter	which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the	hudson's bay company some settlers went into trade	5006.120534177903
14443. the company	maintained a store at which products of england could be purchased	and brought in goods for the new merchants on the understanding that they	refrain from trading in furs	3334.5313615308187
14444. despite this prohibiton by 1844 some	of the fort garry merchants were trading with the indians for furs	2354.5596743114484

14452. the letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor	560.8668206114847

14455. a confederate	observed that the yankees were: thicker than lise on a hen	and a dam site ornraier	1576.5224907037364

14469. william r stillwell	an admirable georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved	in the georgia department of archives and history liked	to	tease his wife in his letters	2867.6633779820104

14485. the letters	which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances	787.7329696574853

14533. the attitudes which the rebs and yanks took toward	each other were very much the same and ranged over the same gamut	of feeling from friendliness to extreme hatred	3119.372204893051

14537. in a similar vein but writing	from the opposite side thomas taylor a private in the 6th alabama	volunteers in a letter to his wife stated: you know that	my heart is with you but i never could have been satisfied to have staid	at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe by a set of	cowardly skunks whose motto is booty h	5801.900443755346
14538. the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion	to the popularity of nationalism in america	2109.3446486903567
14539. and the emphasis on nationalism	in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence	across the world	1723.4000081464994
14540. thus if we are to observe american folklore	in the twentieth century we will do well to establish the relationships	between folklore nationalism and imperialism at the outset	4456.550788762307
14541. historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism	every age rewrites the events	of its history in terms of what should have been creating legends	about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary	actions	3942.420036932895
14542. what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important	as a country	superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others it searches	its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness	4993.372191634851
14543. its folklore	and legend usually disguised as history are allowed to account	for group actions to provide a focal point for group loyalty and to	become a cohesive force for national identification	3451.212597707271
14544. one can apply	these facts to britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries	as she spread her dominion over palm and pine and they can be	applied again to the united states in more recent years	5947.789928118479
14545. the popularity	of local color literature before the spanish-american war the	steady currency of the lincoln myth the increased emphasis on the	frontier west in our mass media are cases in point	3432.071119385079
14546. nor is it an accident	that baseball growing into the national game in the last 75 years	has become a microcosm of american life that learned societies such	as the american folklore society and the american historical	association were founded in the 1880s or that courses in american literature	american civilization american anything have swept our school	and college curricula	8273.356907793084
14547. of course nationalism has really	outlived its usefulness in a country as world-oriented as ours and its	continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the	twentieth-century	united states	3349.9172088878463
14548. yet nationalism has lost few of its	charms for the historian writer or man in the street	2113.6708368075947
14549. it is an understandable	paradox that most american history and most american literature	is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic	point of view at the very time america is spreading her dominion	over palm and pine	4051.7852407639534
14550. after all the average american as he lies and	waits for the enemy in korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain	hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or	her plight is the result of a complex of personal economic and governmental	actions far beyond the normal citizen's comprehension and control	8144.04672406819
14551. anyone's identification with an international struggle whether	warlike or peaceful requires absurd oversimplification and intense	emotional involvement	1424.9733449218695
14552. such identification comes for each group in each	crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate	national heroes	2587.8115565643952
14553. in america such self-deception has served	a particularly useful purpose	375.9293207478111
14554. a heterogeneous people have needed it	to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and	ever-changing	land	3049.7534427890623
14555. but we must never forget most of the appropriate	heroes and their legends were created overnight to answer immediate needs	almost always with conscious aims and ends	2837.179168654222
14556. parson weems's george	washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of	the uniting states	2119.228726688473
14557. abraham lincoln emerged as an incarnation of	the national constitution	375.75342473012876
14558. robert e lee represented the dignity	needed by a rebelling confederacy	755.4786110625073
14559. and their roles are paralleled by	those of patrick henry nathan hale andrew jackson davy crockett	theodore roosevelt and many many more	2181.520468044786
14560. therefore the	scholar as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years	most of the legends that are created	to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are	the concept that an american national	folklore exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend	7133.590198831417
14561. folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group	of people preserve vary and recreate through oral transmission	1571.214111138407
14562. it	has come to mean myths legends tales songs proverbs riddles superstitions	rhymes and such literary forms of expression	2587.587388581908
14563. related to	written literature and often remaining temporarily frozen in written	form it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral	existence	2463.3431468424983
14564. though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies	it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter	3259.666582303754
14565. in its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our	folk heritage the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as	this	2029.715217423221
14566. enthusiastically americans have swept subliterary and bogus	materials like paul bunyan tales abe lincoln anecdotes and labor	union songs up as true products of our american oral tradition	4482.579225729488
14567. nor	have we remembered that in the melting pot of america the hundreds of	isolated and semi-isolated ethnic regional and occupational groups did	not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education	and industrialization	had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as	a means of carrying culturally significant material	5099.7135716236135
14568. naturally	such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make	money or fan patriotism by means of folklore	3247.072656342556
14569. that much of what he	calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people	with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction	to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant	4037.914996571323
14570. as long	as his material is americana can in some way be ascribed to the masses	and appears democratic to his audience he remains satisfied	3903.120132342739
14571. from all this we can now see that two streams of development	run through the history of twentieth-century american folklore	1875.282826609005
14572. on	the one side we have the university professors and their students trained	in teutonic methods of research who have sought out collected	and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic	regional and occupational groups that make up this nation	6789.814735773036
14573. on the other	we have the flag-wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been	willing to use any patriotic frontier western or colonial material	willy-nilly	2594.6553451941722
14574. unfortunately few of the artists	who have used american folklore	since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams	even in the most general of ways	4467.665790324096
14575. after all the field is large difficult	to define and seldom taught properly to american undergraduates	1251.2358004352293
14576. in addition this country has been settled by many peoples of many	heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly in an age of	print and easy communication within an ever-expanding and changing society	5511.572310995797
14577. the problems confuse even the experts	43.79754380838313
14578. for that matter	the experts themselves are a mixed breed	566.1573660491596
14579. anthropologists housewives	historians and such by profession they approach their discipline	as amateurs collectors commercial propagandists analysts or some combination	of the four	2324.666135083566
14580. they have widely varying backgrounds and aims	140.55031637908246
14581. they have little esprit de corps	43.55979543254074
14582. the outlook for the	amateur for instance is usually dependent on his fondness for local	history or for the picturesque	2830.3910513000474
14583. his love of folklore has romanticism	in it and he doesn't care much about the dollar-sign or the footnote	1730.2012836630406
14584. folklore is his hobby and he all too rightly wishes it to remain	as such	1640.21916191036
14585. the amateur is closely related to the collector who is	actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field	2183.4085327338225
14586. the collector	enjoys the contact with rural life; he hunts folklore for the	very field and stream reasons that many persons hunt game; and	only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has	located	6077.684624915426
14587. fundamentally both these types the amateur and the collector	are uncritical and many of them don't distinguish well between	real folklore and bogus material	2464.7245993463507
14588. but there are also the commercial	propagandists and the analysts- one dominated by money the other	by nineteenth-century german scholarship	2832.376438705008
14589. both are primarily concerned	with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector	has found	1736.79546367805
14590. both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond	the sewage system and the electric light lines	2363.4451198033094
14591. the commercial propagandist	who can't afford to be critical gets along well with the	amateur from whom he feeds but he frequently steps on the analyst's	toes by refusing to keep his material genuine	3675.29430295713
14592. his standards are	of course completely foreign to those of the analyst	960.1079610497909
14593. to both the amateur	and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul lacks appreciation	with his endless probings and classifications	2043.5754872887173
14594. dominated by	the vicious circle of the university promotion system the analyst looks	down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups although	he cannot deny his debt to the collector	5347.254201082842
14595. the knowledge that	most americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial	propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors	2033.744781217873
14596. the work	done by the analysts the men who really know what folklore is all about	has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort	and reaches a limited learned audience	5673.173908758019
14597. publishers want books that	will sell recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to	ears used to hillbilly and jazz music grade and high schools want quaint	but moral material	3434.4047214453394
14598. the analyst is apt to be too honest to fit	in	752.6898699853128

14606. is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an america that was	1179.6771856991354

14608. when he gets the answers to his questions he will be	discouraged	961.9219386549805

14612. in the second	place a large number of writers making a more direct claim than frost	to being folk writers of one sort or another clearly make	no distinctions between genuine and bogus material	5485.255677221072
14613. stephen vincent	benet's john brown's body comes immediately to mind in this	connection as does john steinbeck's the grapes of wrath	and carl sandburg's the people yes	2880.4406704729936
14614. the last two writers	introduce strong political bias into their works and not unlike the union	leaders that we will discuss soon see folklore as a reservoir of	protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass	5787.627949512618
14615. folklore as	used by such writers really reflects images engraved into it by the very	person using it	1571.8292671723184

14617. in fact there is much evidence to	indicate they don't care a bit about anything beyond their particular	regional ethnic and occupational limits	2317.747034592435
14618. as part of the same arrangement torrio had in the spirit of peace	and good will and in exchange for armed support in the april election	campaign bestowed upon o'banion a third share in the hawthorne	smoke shop proceeds and a cut in the cicero beer trade	4752.3493394980305

14620. o'banion was a complex and frightening	man whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour	into others'	1889.7537166548104
14621. he had a round frank irish face creased in a	jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets	into someone's body	4096.893981064499

14623. he killed accurately	freely and dispassionately	65.4675076389743
14624. the police credited him with twenty-five	murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them	1569.7398210333922

14632. o'banion	was born in poverty the son of an immigrant irish plasterer	in the north side's little hell close by the sicilian quarter	and death corner	2725.4570972417055

14636. because of this he was known as	gimpy		79.07261143491465
14637. in his teens o'banion was enrolled in the vicious	market street gang and he became a singing waiter in mcgovern's	cafe a notoriously low and rowdy dive in north clark street where	befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing	waiters before being thrown out	7231.075768811985

14641. those were his only	interludes behind bars although he collected four more charges on his	police record in 1921 and 1922 three for burglary and one for robbery	4484.133777540075

14701. a tsunami may be started by a sea bottom slide an earthquake	or a volcanic eruption	1887.4000154286791
14702. the most infamous of all was launched by the	explosion of the island of krakatoa in 1883; it raced across the pacific	at 300 miles an hour devastated the coasts of java and sumatra	with waves 100 to 130 feet high and pounded the shore as far away	as san francisco	5016.870641050934
14703. the ancient greeks recorded several catastrophic	inundations by huge waves	563.9259244749891
14704. whether or not plato's tale of	the lost continent of atlantis is true skeptics concede that the myth	may have some foundation in a great tsunami of ancient times	3098.9011779229977
14705. indeed	a tremendously destructive tsunami that arose in the arabian sea	in 1945 has even revived the interest of geologists and archaeologists	in the biblical story of the flood	4655.403279528707
14706. one of the most damaging	tsunami on record followed the famous lisbon earthquake of november	1 1755; its waves persisted for a week and were felt as far away	as the english coast	3556.8019180802394
14707. tsunami are rare however in the atlantic	ocean; they are far more common in the pacific	1880.6191019454159
14708. japan has had 15	destructive ones since 1596	167.23673493329056
14709. the hawaiian	islands are struck severely an average of once every 25 years	1185.2506468568104
14710. in 1707 an earthquake in japan generated waves so huge that they piled	into the inland sea; one wave swamped more than 1000 ships and	boats in osaka bay	3097.089911493483
14711. a tsunami in the hawaiian islands in 1869	washed away an entire town leaving only two forlorn trees	standing where the community had been	3692.926364247178
14712. in 1896 a japanese tsunami killed	27000 people and swept away 10000 homes	789.6215143877992
14713. the dimensions	of these waves dwarf all our usual standards of measurement	963.7699216377989
14714. an ordinary	sea wave is rarely more than a few hundred feet long from crest to	crest- no longer than 320 feet in the atlantic or 1000 feet in the	pacific	3331.385757312285
14715. but a tsunami often extends more than 100 miles and sometimes	as much as 600 miles from crest to crest	2825.1386905444774
14716. while a wind wave never	travels at more than 60 miles per hour the velocity of a tsunami in	the open sea must be reckoned in hundreds of miles per hour	3348.6994081447883
14717. the greater	the depth of the water the greater is the speed of the wave;	lagrange's law says that its velocity is equal to the square root of	the product of the depth times the acceleration due to gravity	6217.210787835868
14718. in	the deep waters of the pacific these waves reach a speed of 500 miles	per hour	1427.4817920303428
14719. tsunami are so shallow in comparison with their length	that in the open ocean they are hardly detectable	2338.2334739937664
14720. their amplitude	sometimes is as little as two feet from trough to crest	793.1293845452092
14721. usually it	is only when they approach shallow water on the shore that they build	up to their terrifying heights	2797.515995189954
14722. on the fateful day in 1896 when the	great waves approached japan fishermen at sea noticed no unusual swells	1731.4749216253554
14723. not until they sailed home at the end of the day through a sea	strewn with bodies and the wreckage of houses were they aware of what	had happened	4648.783637179435
14724. the seemingly quiet ocean had crashed a wall of water	from 10 to 100 feet high upon beaches crowded with bathers drowning	thousands of them and flattening villages along the shore	3334.809848156652
14725. the	giant waves are more dangerous on flat shores than on steep ones	1181.3547769016504
14726. they	usually range from 20 to 60 feet in height but when they pour into	a v-shaped inlet or harbor they may rise to mountainous proportions	2731.4814623258344
14727. generally the first salvo of a tsunami is a rather sharp swell	not different enough from an ordinary wave to alarm casual observers	3485.178486155814
14728. this is followed by a tremendous suck of water away from the shore	as the first great trough arrives	1745.357130777637
14729. reefs are left high and dry and	the beaches are covered with stranded fish	1426.6607063163153
14730. at hilo large numbers	of people ran out to inspect the amazing spectacle of the denuded beach	1411.2176011541274
14731. many of them paid for their curiosity with their lives for some	minutes later the first giant wave roared over the shore	3270.9200797353906
14732. after an earthquake	in japan in 1793 people on the coast at tugaru were so terrified	by the extraordinary ebbing of the sea that they scurried to higher	ground	3073.323789187606
14733. when a second quake came they dashed back to the beach	fearing that they might be buried under landslides	2582.728021340947
14734. just as they reached	the shore the first huge wave crashed upon them	787.1109242989803
14735. a tsunami	is not a single wave but a series	561.6217662566264
14736. the waves are separated by intervals	of 15 minutes to an hour or more	and this has often lulled people into thinking after the first great	wave has crashed that it is all over	3676.3092458887645
14737. the waves may keep coming for many	hours	251.6811426709165
14738. usually the third to the eighth waves in the series are the	biggest	791.8409484654043
14739. among the observers of the 1946 tsunami at hilo was	francis p shepard of the scripps institution of oceanography	one of the world's foremost marine geologists	4072.224738655567
14740. he was able to make	a detailed inspection of the waves	502.6160657528768
14741. their onrush and retreat he reported	was accompanied by a great hissing roaring and rattling	1646.9171705782733
14742. the	third and fourth waves seemed to be the highest	374.2859888196913
14743. on some of the islands'	beaches the waves came in gently; they were steepest on the	shores facing the direction of the seaquake from which the waves had come	4673.867965523176
14744. in hilo bay they were from 21 to 26 feet high	501.93620584264846
14745. the highest waves	55 feet occurred at pololu valley	391.4179803966671
14746. scientists and fishermen	have occasionally seen strange by-products of the phenomenon	502.8397526972432
14747. during	a 1933 tsunami in japan the sea glowed brilliantly at night	963.2429494538676
14748. the	luminosity of the water is now believed to have been caused by the	stimulation of vast numbers of the luminescent organism noctiluca miliaris	by the turbulence of the sea	3217.4096827034905
14749. japanese fishermen have sometimes	observed that sardines hauled up in their nets during a tsunami have	enormously swollen stomachs; the fish have swallowed vast numbers	of bottom-living diatoms raised to the surface by the disturbance	5627.071048355601
14750. the	waves of a 1923 tsunami in sagami bay brought to the surface and	battered to death huge numbers of fishes that normally live at a depth	of 3000 feet	3229.8860822540028
14751. gratified fishermen hauled them in by the thousands	248.84476304987453
14752. the tsunami-warning system developed since the 1946 disaster in	hawaii relies mainly on a simple and ingenious instrument devised	by commander c k green of the coast and geodetic survey staff	3341.0630952563274
14753. it consists of a series of pipes and a pressure-measuring chamber	which record the rise and fall of the water surface	3049.344960176485
14754. ordinary water	tides are disregarded	14.913313476837615
14755. but when waves with a period of between 10 and	40 minutes begin to roll over the ocean they set in motion a corresponding	oscillation in a column of mercury which closes an electric circuit	5623.360168297516
14756. this in turn sets off an alarm notifying the observers at the	station that a tsunami is in progress	1735.3150013535494
14757. such equipment has been installed	at hilo midway attu and dutch harbor	959.2873367934393
14758. the moment the alarm	goes off information is immediately forwarded to honolulu which	is the center of the warning system	1881.3471751636487
14759. this center also receives	prompt reports on earthquakes from four coast survey stations in the	pacific which are equipped with seismographs	3044.2413546890884
14760. its staff makes a preliminary	determination of the epicenter of the quake and alerts tide	stations near the epicenter for a tsunami	2188.4918836818542
14761. by means of charts showing	wave-travel times and depths in the ocean at various locations it is	possible to estimate the rate of approach and probable time of arrival	at hawaii of a tsunami getting under way at any spot in the pacific	6641.932479961719
14762. the civil and military authorities are then advised of the danger	and they issue warnings and take all necessary protective steps	2035.239909019286
14763. all	of these activities are geared to a top-priority communication system	and practice tests have been held to assure that everything will work	smoothly	3688.2415668192175
14764. since the 1946 disaster there have been 15 tsunami	in the pacific but only one was of any consequence	1728.0402444457195
14765. on november 4	1952 an earthquake occurred under the sea off the kamchatka peninsula	1426.9053937023261
14766. at 17:07 that afternoon the shock was recorded	by the seismograph alarm in honolulu	935.2414534656409
14767. the warning system immediately	went into action	141.58120036892723
14768. within about an hour with the help of reports	from seismic stations in alaska arizona and california the quake's	epicenter was placed at 51 degrees north latitude and 158 degrees	east longitude	3454.7640495943224
14769. while accounts of the progress of the tsunami came	in from various points in the pacific	the hawaiian station made its calculations	and notified the military services and the police that the first big	wave would arrive at honolulu at 23:30 greenwich time	6709.458173231023
14770. it	turned out that the waves were not so high as in 1946	789.4184788488631
14771. they hurled a	cement barge against a freighter in honolulu harbor knocked down telephone	lines marooned automobiles flooded lawns killed six cows	3265.338465117683
14772. but not a single human life was lost and property damage in the hawaiian	islands did not exceed $800000	1715.2494374123646
14773. there is little doubt that the	warning system saved lives and reduced the damage	1414.3867301871137
14774. but it is	plain that a warning system however efficient is not enough	785.948943636152
14775. in the	vulnerable areas of the pacific there should be restrictions against	building homes on exposed coasts or at least a requirement that they	be either raised off the ground or anchored strongly against waves	5638.72321184404
14776. the key to the world of geology is change; nothing remains the	same	791.6566572431743
14777. life has evolved from simple combinations of molecules in the	sea to complex combinations in man	1873.9152575803869
14778. the land too is changing and	earthquakes are daily reminders of this	637.9719307647266
14779. earthquakes result when movements	in the earth twist rocks until they break	955.8840183017546
14780. sometimes this is accompanied	by visible shifts of the ground surface; often the shifts	cannot be seen but they are there; and everywhere can be found scars	of earlier breaks once deeply buried	3554.3130229905264
14781. today's earthquakes are most	numerous in belts where the earth's restlessness is presently concentrated	but scars of the past show that there is no part of the earth	that has not had them	5323.615943484501
14782. the effects of earthquakes on civilization	have been widely publicized even overemphasized	643.1694449235176
14783. the role of	an earthquake in starting the destruction of whole cities is tremendously	frightening but fire may actually be the principal agent in a particular	disaster	4291.231475620385
14784. superstition has often blended with fact to color reports	261.5605275999918
14785. we have learned from earthquakes much of what we now know	about the earth's interior for they send waves through the earth	which emerge with information about the materials through which they	have traveled	5481.966558084713
14786. these waves have shown that 1800 miles below the surface	a liquid core begins and that it in turn has a solid inner core	2474.1207924038026
14787. earthquakes originate as far as 400 miles below the surface	but they do not occur at greater depths	2355.6532724315075
14788. two unsolved mysteries are	based on these facts	168.02460656242232
14789. as far down as 400 miles below the surface	the material should be hot enough to be plastic and adjust itself to	twisting forces by sluggish flow rather than by breaking as rigid surface	rocks do	5775.933084172282
14790. if earthquakes do occur at such depths why not deeper	370.9651534378103
14791. knowledge gained from studying earthquake waves has been	applied in various fields	958.4989051888691
14792. in the search for oil and gas we make	similar waves under controlled conditions with dynamite and learn from	them where there are buried rock structures favorable to the accumulation	of these resources	3555.719998463079
14793. we have also developed techniques for recognizing	and locating underground nuclear tests through the waves in the	ground which they generate	3056.7903436460865
14794. the following discussion of this subject	has been adapted from the book by	l don leet	1261.8895645573352
14795. at twelve	minutes after five on the morning of wednesday april 18 1906	san francisco was shaken by a severe earthquake	3028.7752679337027
14796. a sharp tremor	was followed by a jerky roll	261.31093407715593
14797. ireland's county limerick near the river	shannon there is a quiet little suburb by the name of garryowen which	means garden of owen	3482.6425125737683
14798. undoubtedly none of the residents realize	the influence their town has had on american military history	or the deeds of valor that have been done in its name	2989.019721413676
14799. the cry garryowen!	bursting from the lips of a charging cavalry trooper was	the last sound heard on this earth by untold numbers of cheyennes	sioux and apaches mexican banditos under pancho villa japanese	in the south pacific and chinese and north korean communists	in korea	7043.436105795983
14800. garryowen is the battle cry of the 7th u s cavalry	regiment the fighting seventh	1103.9670269991777
14801. today a battle	cry may seem an anachronism for in the modern army esprit de corps	has been sacrificed to organizational charts and tables	3697.7955599977868
14802. but don't	tell that to a veteran of the fighting seventh especially in a	saloon on saturday night	1578.3050406040852
14803. of all the thousands of men who have	served in the 7th cav perhaps no one knows its spirit better than	lieutenant colonel melbourne c chandler	4078.3200443275555
14804. wiry and burr-headed	with steel blue eyes and a chest splattered with medals chandler	is the epitome of the old-time trooper	2037.8660476653185
14805. the truth is however that	when mel chandler first reported to the regiment the only steed he	had ever ridden	was a swivel chair and the only weapon he had ever wielded	was a pencil	5659.493736269112
14806. chandler had been commissioned in the medical	service corps and was serving as a personnel officer for the kansas	city medical depot when he decided that if he was going to make	the army his career he wanted to be in the fighting part of it	4679.245025686352
14807. though	he knew no more about military science and tactics than any other	desk officer he managed to get transferred to the combat forces	3702.3787279922108
14808. the	next thing he knew he was reporting for duty as commanding officer	of troop h 7th cavalry in the middle of corps maneuvers in japan	2733.7319074387274
14809. outside of combat he couldn't have landed in a tougher	spot	749.8760088059788
14810. first of all no unit likes to have a new co brought in from	the outside especially when he's an armchair trooper	2186.756963865022
14811. second	if there is ever a perfect time to pull the rug out from under him it's	on maneuvers	2576.326093080781
14812. in combat helping your co make a fool of himself	might mean getting yourself killed	1089.7391385675141
14813. but in maneuvers with the top	brass watching him all the time it's easy	1413.18511143832
14814. chandler understood	this and expected the worst	94.31699553715858
14815. but his first few days with troop	h were full of surprises beginning with first sergeant robert	early	2343.569995935824
14816. chandler had expected a tough old trooper with a gravel voice	508.23125713932114
14817. instead sergeant early was quiet sharp and confident	250.05425361251628
14818. he had	enlisted in the army straight out of high school and had immediately	set about learning his new trade	1884.3980859929666
14819. there was no weapon early could not	take apart and reassemble blind-folded	962.5345424514051
14820. he could lead a patrol and	he knew his paper work	505.64298837254074

14830. maneuvers over the 7th returned to garrison	duty in tokyo captain chandler still with them	1097.4295953647897

14832. but still mel chandler was not completely	convinced that men would really die for a four-syllable word garryowen	1579.1874187380902

14835. in the middle of the party chandler looked	up to see four smiling faces bearing down upon him each beaming above	the biggest greenest shamrock he had ever seen	4657.550887673137

14841. and so mel chandler got the spirit of garryowen	395.72900554635197

14848. when the korean war began on june 25	1950 the anniversary of the day custer had gone down fighting at the	little big horn and the day the regiment had assaulted the beachhead	of leyte during world war 2 the 7th cavalry was not in the	best fighting condition	4918.036361249896

14879. marvin goulding saw	what was happening	64.46166034419241

14892. so filled	was mel chandler with the spirit of garryowen that after korea was	over he took on the job of writing the complete history of the regiment	2993.3207293901305
14893. after years of digging nights and weekends he put together the	big profusely illustrated book of garryowen and glory which	is probably the most complete history of any military unit	4836.195872644536
14894. the	battle of the naktong river is just one example of how the battle	cry and the spirit of the fighting seventh have paid off	2613.844891982513
14895. for nearly	a century the cry has never failed to rally the fighting men of the	regiment	2138.472871407944
14896. take the case of major marcus a reno who survived	the battle of the little big horn in 1876	1723.7570109222302

14900. he was a member of the fighting seventh	166.78162010656877
14901. although it was	at	the battle of the little horn about which more words have been	written than any other battle in american history that the 7th cavalry	first made its mark in history the regiment was ten years old by	then	6558.4959116686205
14902. brevet major general george armstrong custer was the regiment's	first permanent commander and like such generals as george	s patton and terry de la mesa allen in their rise to military	prominence	custer was a believer in blood and guts warfare	4292.04255546216
14903. during	the civil war custer who achieved a brilliant record was	made	brigadier general at the age of 23	2588.795690195812
14904. he finished the war as	a major general commanding a full division and at 25 was the youngest	major general in the history of the u s army	2999.831726896088
14905. i do not mean to suggest that these assumptions are self-evident in	the sense that everyone agrees with them	2576.1294410950704
14906. if they were walter lippmann	would be writing the same columns as george sokolsky and herblock	would have nothing to draw cartoons about	2329.057255254568
14907. i do mean however that	i take them for granted and that everything i shall be saying	assumption	the ultimate objective of american policy is to help establish	a world in which there is the largest possible measure of freedom	and justice and peace and material prosperity; and in particular-	since this is our special responsibility- that these conditions	be enjoyed by the people of the united states	8785.889716591615
14908. i speak of the largest	possible measure because any person who supposes that these	conditions can be universally and perfectly achieved- ever- reckons	without the inherent imperfectability of himself and his fellow human	assumption	these conditions are unobtainable- are not even approachable	in the qualified sense i have indicated- without the prior defeat	of world communism	5295.609486657194
14909. this is true for two reasons: because communism	is both doctrinally and in practice antithetical to these conditions;	and because communists have the will and as long as soviet	power remains intact the capacity to prevent their realization	6097.556749536326
14910. moreover	as communist power increases the enjoyment of these conditions	throughout the world diminishes pro rata and the possibility of	their restoration becomes increasingly remote	2615.981326707016
14911. it	follows that victory over communism is the dominant proximate goal	of american policy	1411.3385700621418
14912. proximate in the sense that there are more distant	more positive ends we seek to which victory over communism	is but a means	2323.341269618684
14913. but dominant in the sense that every other objective	no matter how worthy intrinsically must defer to it	2351.1475183025477
14914. peace is a worthy	objective; but if we must choose between peace and keeping the	communists out of berlin then we must fight	2305.5416789225774
14915. freedom in the sense	of self-determination is a worthy objective; but if granting self-determination	to the algerian rebels entails sweeping that area into	the sino-soviet orbit then algerian freedom must be postponed	5157.221743312996
14916. justice	is a worthy objective; but if justice for bantus entails driving	the government of the union of south africa away from the west	then the bantus must be prepared to carry their identification cards	yet a while longer	4130.3257540931845
14917. prosperity is a worthy objective; but if providing	higher standards of living gets in the way of producing sufficient	guns to resist communist aggression then material sacrifices and	denials will have to be made	5467.590345632838
14918. it may be of course that such objectives	can be pursued consisently with a policy designed to overthrow communism;	my point is that where conflicts arise they must always be	resolved in favor of achieving the indispensable condition for a tolerant	world- the absence of soviet communist power	4805.461698930516
14919. power	this much having been said the question remains whether we	have the resources for the job we have to do- defeat communism-	and if so how those resources ought to be used	5320.438014146853
14920. this brings us squarely	to the problem of power and the uses a nation makes of power	1421.7668933494074
14921. i submit that this is the key problem of international relations that	it always has been that it always will be	3039.3883987376453
14922. and i suggest further	that the main cause of the trouble we are in has been the failure of	american policy-makers ever since we assumed free world leadership	in 1945 to deal with this problem realistically and seriously	4036.6147076310262
14923. in the recent political campaign two charges were leveled affecting	the question of power and i think we might begin by trying to put them	into proper focus	4444.405671331822
14924. one was demonstrably false; the other for the	most part true	501.49911206958257
14925. the first was that america had become- or	was in danger of becoming- a second-rate military power	2132.3278723139365
14926. i know i	do not have to dwell here on the absurdity of that contention	1095.7332470121391
14927. you	may have misgivings about certain aspects of our military establishment-	i certainly do- but you know any comparison of over-all american	strength with over-all soviet strength finds the united states	not only superior but so superior both in present weapons and in the	development of new ones that our advantage promises to be a permanent	feature of us-soviet relations for the foreseeable future	8539.140110092627
14928. i have often searched for a graphic way of impressing our superiority	on those americans who have doubts and i think mr jameson	campaigne has done it well in his new book american might and soviet	myth	3934.5280782170585
14929. suppose he says that the tables were turned and we	were in the soviets' position: there would be more than 2000	modern soviet fighters all better than ours stationed at 250 bases	in mexico and the caribbean	5918.08570324593
14930. overwhelming russian naval power would	always be within a few hundred miles of our coast	1098.0781339286639
14931. half of the population	of the us would be needed to work on arms just to feed	the people	2596.60608807404
14932. add this to the unrest in the countries around us where	oppressed peoples would be ready to turn on us at the first opportunity	2460.7065219202273
14933. add also a comparatively primitive industrial plant which would	severely limit our capacity to keep abreast of the soviets even in the	missile field which is reputed to be our main strength	5168.118149399415
14934. if	we look at the situation this way we can get an idea of khrushchev's	nightmarish worries- or at least of the worries he might have if	his enemies were disposed to exploit their advantage	3737.4758882037145
14935. the other charge was that america's political position	in the world has progressively deteriorated in recent years	2114.781047006626
14936. the	contention needs to be formulated with much greater precision than it	ever was during the campaign but once that has been done i fail to	see how any serious student of world affairs can quarrel with it	4011.392774731676
14937. the argument was typically advanced in terms of us prestige	552.4588778643049
14938. prestige however is only a minor part of the problem; and	even then it is a concept that can be highly misleading	2183.8178799841457
14939. prestige	is a measure of how other people think of you well or ill	1409.6351058518683
14940. but contrary	to what was implied during the campaign prestige is surely not important	for its own sake	1565.8659140257218
14941. only the vain and incurably sentimental among	us will lose sleep simply because foreign peoples are not as impressed	by our strength as they ought to be	4287.714511897567
14942. the thing to lose sleep over	is what people having concluded that we are weaker than we are are	likely to do about it	2459.015472988681
14943. the evidence suggests that foreign peoples	believe the united states is weaker than the soviet union and	is bound to fall still further behind in the years ahead	4480.649327049919
14944. this ignorant	estimate i repeat is not of any interest in itself; but it becomes	very important if foreign peoples react the way human beings typically	do- namely by taking steps to end up on what appears to be	the winning side	4358.379552609827
14945. to the extent then that declining us prestige	means that other nations will be tempted to place their bets on	an ultimate american defeat and will thus be more vulnerable to soviet	intimidation there is reason for concern	6044.9219806248275
14946. still these guesses	about the outcome of the struggle cannot be as important as the	actual power relationship between the soviet union and ourselves	2474.8164422446825
14947. here	i do not speak of military power where our advantage is obvious and	overwhelming but of political power- of influence if you will-	about which the relevant questions are: is soviet influence throughout	the world greater or less than it was ten years ago	6936.5832693592865
14948. and is western	influence greater or less than it used to be	639.826517588471
14949. in answering these questions we need to ask not merely whether	communist troops have crossed over into territories they did not occupy	before and not merely whether disciplined agents of the cominform	are in control of governments from which they were formerly excluded:	the success of communism's war against the west does not depend	on such spectacular and definitive conquests	8241.796832434999
14950. success may mean merely	the displacement of western influence	262.53806353519667
14951. communist political	warfare we must remember is waged insidiously and in deliberate stages	1179.5497455331438
14952. fearful of inviting a military showdown with the west which they	could not win the communists seek to undermine western power where	the nuclear might of the west is irrelevant- in backwoods guerrilla	skirmishes	in mob uprisings in the streets in parliaments in clandestine	meetings of undercover conspirators at the united nations	on the propaganda front at diplomatic conferences- preferably at	the highest level	5710.048343026812
14953. the soviets understand moreover that the	first step in turning a country toward communism is to turn it against	the west	3049.213231816561
14954. thus typically the first stage of a communist takeover	is to neutralize a country	942.3393260195078
14955. the second stage is to retain the	nominal classification of neutralist while in fact turning the	country into an active advocate and adherent of soviet policy	4093.157981826253
14956. and	this may be as far as the process will go	507.1264442928149
14957. the kremlin's goal is	the isolation and capture not of ghana but of the united states-	and this purpose may be served very well by countries that masquerade	under a neutralist mask yet in fact are dependable auxiliaries	of the soviet foreign office	6673.187100095771
14958. to recite the particulars of	recent soviet successes is hardly reassuring	502.8103962324104
14959. six years ago	french indochina though in troubie was in the western camp	1182.996929766784
14960. today	northern vietnam is overtly communist; laos is teetering between	communism and pro-communist neutralism; cambodia is for all	practical purposes neutralist	2036.6123851454718
14961. indonesia in the early days of	the republic leaned toward the west	965.9208851308664
14962. today sukarno's government	is heavily besieged by avowed communists and for all of its neutralist	pretensions it is a firm ally of soviet policy	2446.1715154314384
14963. ceylon	has moved from a pro-western orientation to a neutralism openly	hostile to the west	1656.7377851380224
14964. in the middle east iraq syria and	egypt were a short while ago in the western camp	1416.433104250276
14965. today the nasser	and kassem governments are adamantly hostile to the west are dependent	for their military power on soviet equipment and personnel;	in almost every particular follow the kremlin's foreign policy line	5322.867395486424
14966. a short time ago all africa was a western preserve	373.4015039513307
14967. never	mind whether the kikiyus and the bantus enjoyed wilsonian self-determination:	the point is that in the struggle for the world that	vast land mass was under the domination and influence of the west	5500.236794481739
14968. today	africa is swerving violently away from the west and plunging	it would seem into the soviet orbit	1591.1463686796574
14969. latin america was once	an area as safe for the west as nebraska was for nixon	1891.6859583003716
