14971. one latin american country cuba has become	a soviet bridgehead ninety miles off our coast	1660.5213033387924
14972. in some countries	the trend has gone further than others: mexico panama and venezuela	are displaying open sympathy for castroism and there is no country-	save the dominican republic whose funeral services we recently	arranged- where castroism and anti-americanism does not prevent	the government from unqualifiedly espousing the american cause	4974.386546786786
14973. only in europe have our lines remained firm- and there only on the	surface	1415.72857757293

15207. in	general however the timetable of travel lags considerably behind that	of the student at harvard or smith	2347.84128428796

15212. almost	everybody in the senior class is married students say dogmatically	503.52192573537104

15223. this should be used frequently	22.37875702579661
15224. for galled	breasts the mother should shave into half a cup of fresh unsalted lard	enough white chalk to make a paste	2178.553287909915
15225. this could also be used for any	other skin irritation	558.8814814574182

15227. female	troubles of various kinds do not seem to have been common on the	frontier; at least i have only one remedy for anything of this kind	in my collection one for hastening delayed menstruation	5601.669780707374
15228. the sufferer	drinks tansy tea	14.729117445815977
15229. bruises burns cuts etc occurred frequently	on the frontier and folk medicine gave the answers to these	problems too	2609.6433670540414
15230. bruises and black eyes were relieved by application of	raw beefsteak	496.63868140498363
15231. salted butter was	another	cure for bruises	140.51517476898843
15232. many people agreed that burns should be treated	with bland oily salves or unsalted butter or lard but one informant	told me that a burn should be bathed in salt water; the burn oozed	watery fluid for many days and finally the healing was completed by	bathing it with epsom salts	5003.480984680019
15233. another swore by vinegar baths for burns	and still another recommended salted butter	1181.4292125726165
15234. butter salve or	butter ointment was used for burns and for bruises as well	941.7365863358318
15235. this	was made by putting butter in a pan of water and allowing it to boil;	when it was cool the fat was skimmed off and bottled	4264.949174905038
15236. cow's	milk was another cure for burns and burns covered with gum arabic or	plain mucilage healed quickly	1572.0964737926502
15237. one man badly burned about the face and	eyes by an arc welding torch was blinded and could not find a doctor	at the time	3903.6927667085547
15238. a sympathetic friend made poultices of raw potato parings	which she said was the best and quickest way to draw out the heat	2322.2136728297373
15239. later the doctor used mineral oil on the burns	395.5469122938273
15240. the results	were good but which treatment helped is still not known	635.6024030329338
15241. to	stop bleeding cobwebs were applied to cuts and wounds	557.6965425075297
15242. one old-timer	said to sprinkle sugar on a bleeding cut even when on a knuckle if it	was made by a rusty tool; this would stop the flow and also prevent	infection	3458.8431764263005
15243. my lawyer told me that his mother used a similar remedy	for cuts and wounds; she sprinkled common sugar directly on the injury	and then bound it loosely with cotton cloth over which she poured	turpentine	5768.842102275134
15244. he showed me one of his fingers which had been practically	amputated and which his mother had treated; there is scarcely a scar	showing	2472.948822660116
15245. tobacco was common first aid	22.247956874493266
15246. a chaw of tobacco put	on an open wound was both antiseptic and healing	948.533420466505
15247. or a thin slice	of plug tobacco might be laid on the open wound without chewing	1874.8580315085794
15248. one	old man told me that when he was a boy he was kicked in the head by a	fractious mule and had his scalp laid back from the entire front of his	head	3671.8000601056838
15249. his brother ran a mile to get the father; when they reached	the boy the father sliced a new plug of tobacco put the scalp back	in place and covered the raw edges with the slices	5787.40684463409
15250. then he put a rag	around the dressing to keep it in place	790.80481256877
15251. there was no cleaning or further	care but the wound healed in less than two weeks and showed no	scar	2829.436646802571
15252. veronica from the herb garden was also used to stop bleeding	and rue was an antiseptic	1263.8735598027624
15253. until quite recently sterile maggots	could be bought to apply to a wound; they would feed on its surface	leaving it clean so that it could be medically treated	4652.840440149549
15254. tetanus	could be avoided by pouring warm turpentine over a wound	502.11599939183253
15255. one family	bound wounds with bacon or salt pork strips or if these were not	handy plain lard	2355.523456547232
15256. another sprinkled sugar on hot coals and held the	wounded foot or hand in the smoke	1260.5240810902187
15257. rabies were cured or prevented	by madstones which the pioneer wore or carried	1190.5004286962983
15258. in 1872 there were	known to be twenty-two in norton county and one had been in the	family for 200 years	2029.7624763680506
15259. another cure for hydrophobia was to suck the wounds	then cauterize them with a hot knife or poker	2367.411177389982
15260. while nowadays	we recognize the fact that there are many causes for bleeding at	the nose not long ago a nosebleed was simply that and treatment had	little	variation	3101.428030928072
15261. since a fall or blow might have caused it a cold pack	was usually first aid	1875.5051295735666
15262. this might be applied to the top of the nose	or the back of the neck pressed on the upper lip or inserted into the	nostril	2745.270405635562
15263. nosebleed could be	stopped by wrapping a red woolen string about the patient's neck and	tying in it a knot for each year of his life	4092.0062259266283
15264. or the victim could chew	hard on a piece of paper meanwhile pressing his fingers tight in	his ears	1726.1624429487347
15265. old sores could be healed by the constant application	of a wash made of equal parts vinegar and water	2587.5896462960527
15266. blood blisters could	be prevented from forming by rubbing a work blister immediately with	any hard nonpoisonous substance	1561.6694772605363
15267. felons were cured by taking common	salt and drying it in the oven pounding it fine and mixing it with equal	parts of spirits of turpentine; this mixture was then spread on	a cloth and wrapped around the affected part	6309.623205452296
15268. as the cloth dried more	of the mixture was applied and after twenty-four hours the felon was	supposed to be killed	2024.4366889655134
15269. insect bites were cured in many	ways	141.0210240576544
15270. many an old-timer swore by the saliva method; get a bite	spit on it was a proverb	1411.4737044769156
15271. this was used also for bruises	65.53462992943913
15272. yellow	clay was used as a poultice for insect bites and also for swellings;	not long ago denver mud was most popular	2183.6908245409363
15273. chiggers were a	common pest along streams and where gardens and berries thrived; so	small as to be scarcely visible to the eye they buried themselves in	the victim's flesh	4841.259248948688
15274. bathing the itching parts with kerosene gave relief	and also killed the pests	794.5624650414496
15275. ant bites were eased by applying liquid	bluing	250.62993775242703
15276. for mosquito bites a paste of half a glass of salt and half	a glass of soda was made	1722.3289817517445
15277. for wasp stings onion juice obtained by	scraping an onion gave quick relief	1184.5009175715732
15278. a handier remedy was to bathe the	painful part in strong soapy water; mud was sometimes used as well	as soap	2021.0338818394034
15279. just plain old black dirt was also used as a pack to relieve	wasp or bee stings	2125.626591957793
15280. bedbugs were a common pest in pioneer days;	to keep them out of homes even in the 1900's was a chore	2015.8604116442452
15281. bed	slats were washed in alum water legs of beds were placed in cups	of kerosene and all woodwork was treated liberally with corrosive sublimate	applied with a feather	4630.814457775916
15282. kerosene was very effective in ridding	pioneer homes of the pests	501.83971486139336
15283. at times pioneer children got lice in their	hair	392.85590966327476
15284. a kerosene shampoo seems a heroic treatment but it did the	job	635.9930628256657
15285. to remove an insect from one's ear warm water should	be inserted	963.0928977600357
15286. a cinder or other small object could be removed from the	eye by placing a flaxseed in the eye	1731.0054636861926
15287. as the seed swelled its glutinous	covering protected the eyeball from irritation and both the cinder	and the seed could soon be washed out	3696.219488555399
15288. another way to remove small	objects from the eye was to have the person look cross-eyed; the particle	would then move toward the nose where it could be wiped out with	a wisp of cotton	3762.930175370013
15289. shingles were cured by gentian an old drug	used in combinations	754.5401866441293
15290. for erysipelas a mixture of one dram borax and	one	ounce glycerine was applied to the afflicted part on linen cloth	2043.7190654806795
15291. itching	skin considered just nerves was eased by treating with	whiskey and salt	1187.749873498463
15292. winter itch was treated by applying strong apple cider	in which pulverized bloodroot had been steeped	1258.4100763946067
15293. to cure fungus growths	on mouth or hands people made a strong tea by using a handful of	sassafras bark in a quart of water	3892.0826445227417
15294. they drank half a cup of this morning	and night and they also washed and soaked their hands in the same	solution	2178.2306452380317
15295. six treatments cured one case which lasted a month and	had defied other remedies	1419.2430716526235
15296. frostbite was treated by putting the feet	and hands in ice water or by rubbing them with snow	1564.94635433999
15297. now one hears that	heat and hot water are used instead	755.4382198956012
15298. another remedy was oil of eucalyptus	used as well for chilblains	501.13927198217027
15299. chilblains were also treated with	tincture of capsicum or cabbage leaves	751.5131300980844
15300. boils have always been	a source of much trouble	260.9856281470454
15301. a german informant gave me a sure cure	made by combining rye flour and molasses into a poultice	2349.026264036761
15302. another poultice	was made from the inner bark of the elm tree steeped in water	until it formed a sticky gummy solution	2183.216562137296
15303. this was also used for sores	65.28555914364937
15304. another frequent pioneer difficulty caused by wearing rough and heavy	shoes and boots was corns	1098.901194737118
15305. one veracious woman tells me she has	used thin potato parings for both corns and calluses on her feet and they	remove the pain or fire	4096.449131719684
15306. another common cure was to soak the	feet five or ten minutes in warm water then to apply a solution of	equal parts of soda and common brown soap on a kid bandage overnight	3649.216395348843
15307. this softened the skin so that in the morning when the bandage was removed	the corn could be scraped off and a bit of corn plaster put on	4485.735622781385
15308. there were many cures for warts	43.152552717740406
15309. one young girl told me how her	mother removed a wart from her finger by soaking a copper penny in	vinegar for three days and then painting the finger with the liquid several	times	5440.873717089153
15310. another wart removal method was to rub each wart with a	bean split open and then to bury the bean halves under the drip of the	house for seven days	3218.2031480310825
15311. saliva gathered in the mouth after a night's	sleep was considered poisonous; wetting a wart with this saliva on	wakening the first thing in the morning was supposed to cause it to disappear	after only a few treatments and strangely enough many warts did	just that	7001.921589851101
15312. one wart cure was to wrap it in a hair from a blonde gypsy	941.0463985194638
15313. another was to soak raw beef in vinegar for twenty-four hours tie	it on the wart and wear it for a week	3260.9297441269364
15314. a simpler method was to tie	a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way	1876.9086289226404
15315. one person recommended to me washing the wart with	sulphur water; another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato	three times daily	3656.722454142714
15316. another common method was to cut an onion in two and	place each half on the wart for a moment; the onion was then fastened	together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave	3651.1092303600417
15317. as the	onion decayed so did the wart	248.99208664477297
15318. sore muscles were relieved by	an arnica rub; sore feet by calf's-foot an herb from the pioneer's	ubiquitous herb garden or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water	in which two cups of salt had been dissolved	4225.355660403133
15319. leg cramps one person	tells me were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the	body on the heel and pressing down hard	3682.020639702915
15320. this does give relief as i	can testify	168.28846708667126
15321. one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy	before each meal for leg cramps	1646.1068156293818
15322. pains in the back of the leg and in	the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope	about the patient's waist	2747.399541231406
15323. for sprains and swellings one	pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added	to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief	4656.181489488872
15324. except for the wine waiter in a restaurant- always an inscrutable	plenipotentiary unto himself the genii with the keys to unlock	the gates of the wine world are one's dealer and the foreign shipper	or negociant who in turn supplies him	4310.8135045084655
15325. in instances where	both of these are persons or firms with integrity the situation is ideal	1894.687209234262
15326. it may on occasion be anything but that	166.16084780591027
15327. however by cultivating	a wine dealer and accepting his advice one will soon enough ascertain	whether he has any knowledge of wines	and better yet whether he	has a taste for wine	5172.839104616909
15328. again by spreading one's purchases over several	wine dealers one becomes familiar with the names and specialties	of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad	2460.12453903901
15329. this is important because	despite all the efforts of the french government an appreciable	segment of france's export trade in wines is still tainted with a	misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty and there are many	too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a	creditable reputation overseas	7342.715381302523
15330. a good negociant or shipper	will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from	the best vineyards or the best parts of them; he may also be the	one who makes and bottles the best blends- sound wines from vineyards	generally in his own district	5050.686845661314
15331. these are the wines the french themselves	use for everyday drinking for even in france virtually no one	drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis	4095.886065406981
15332. the grands	crus are expensive and even doting palates tire of them	636.1795304288165
15333. and certainly	in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine	drinker the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready	for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse	to crus of less renown	6453.086574358854
15334. there is nothing infra dig about a	good blend from a good shipper	798.4147658056552
15335. some of them are very delicious indeed	and there are many good ones exported- unfortunately along with	others not so good and worse	3496.104921083236
15336. consultation with a reputable wine dealer	and constant experimentation- steering ever from the known to	the unknown- are the requisites	1888.6784221052883
15337. wine waiters are something	else again; especially if one is travelling or dining out a great	deal their importance mounts	2828.5955397658026
15338. most of them the world over operate	on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and	some other latin countries: the customer is to be considered guilty	of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise with the burden of proof	on the customer himself	4608.23915430084
15339. now the drinking of wine	is for the most part a recondite affair for manifestly if everyone	in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them the	supply would dry up in no time at all	6217.646679567795
15340. this is the only valid and extenuating	argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible	attitude of the common wine waiter	2306.274142935809
15341. a really good wine waiter is	paradoxically the guardian of his cellar against	the visigoths	1653.1320013936443
15342. faced on the one hand with an always exhaustible	supply of his best wines and on the other by a clientele usually equipped	with inexhaustible pocketbooks it is a wonder indeed that all wine	waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence	4300.009125887131
15343. the one way to	get around them- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking	to it- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter	is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending	money	6652.969089351798
15344. only then perhaps will he reveal his jewels and his bargains	501.35241398741647
15345. wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest	for several weeks before it is served	2356.6635105738137
15346. this is especially true of	red wines and a practice which though not always practicable is well	worth the effort	1887.1975614138519
15347. it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter	of days but in terms of months and years it is fatal	3870.338292385998
15348. wine stored	for a long time should be on its side; otherwise the cork dries	and air enters to spoil it	2018.2033852170177
15349. when stacking wine on its side in a bin	care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next	to the cork	4270.755014231057
15350. fat bottles such as burgundies have a way of rolling	around in the bin and often need little props such as a bit of cardboard	or a chip of wood to hold them in the proper reclining posture	4045.6266056516906
15351. too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks again with ill effects	1181.1133091392005
15352. the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine	is to smell the wet end of the cork after	pulling it: if it smells of wine the bottle is probably all right;	if it smells of cork one has grounds for suspicion	4379.789404879772
15353. seasonal	rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine: they age it prematurely	1404.2483933581148
15354. the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five	degrees with an allowable range of five degrees above or below	this provided there are no sudden or frequent changes	3198.883572008269
15355. prolonged vibration	is also undesirable; consequently one's wine closet or cellar	should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces	2838.9482162936865
15356. if	one lives near a subway or an express parkway the solution is to have	one's wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time	3120.5713909520045
15357. light especially daylight is always bad for wine	251.0605962762882
15358. all in	all though there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations	thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking; many people go	to extreme lengths in decanting chilling or warming or banishing without	further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious	cork	4778.565444023252
15359. a white wine already at cool	cellar temperature may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and	water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator	in about fifteen minutes; for those who live in a winter	climate there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow	4902.452305971366
15360. though	by no means an ideal procedure a red wine may similarly be brought	from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so	before serving time	4860.836749587308
15361. it may be a bit cold when poured; but again	as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt wine should	be served in a large tulip-shaped glass which is never filled more	than half full	4038.8263698336887
15362. in this way red wine warms of itself quite rapidly-	and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste	and fragrance until after the middle of the meal in	the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting	stages	7220.854090183767
15363. the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming	a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an	open fire	3214.2810146545385
15364. this invariably effaces any wine's character and drives	its fragrance underground	752.6411792100955
15365. it should not be forgotten that	wines mature fastest in half-bottles less fast in full bottles slowly	in magnums- and slower yet in tregnums double magnums jeroboams	methuselahs and imperiales respectively	3319.279345833449
15366. very old red wines	often require several hours of aeration and any red wine brought from	the cellar within half an hour of mealtime should be uncorked and allowed	some air	5029.365938498374
15367. but white wines never! white wines should be opened	when served having been previously chilled in proportion to their	sweetness	1869.964531435761
15368. thus sauternes or barsacs should be very cold; a pouilly-fuisse	or a chablis somewhat less cold	1890.356792951178
15369. over-chilling is an accepted	method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white	wine especially a dry wine- and certainly less of a crime than serving	a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive	4231.625633943273
15370. the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death	when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air	4279.320271628001
15371. if	this must be done they should always be corked and kept in a cool place;	it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably	shorter than those of milk	5010.39378758977
15372. a few red wines notably those	of the beaujolais are better consumed at cellar temperature	1093.4832511238858
15373. by	tradition a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature-	if anything a little cooler- and be aged enough for the tannin	and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well	5765.360710439033
15374. thus	red wine must if possible never be disturbed or shaken; very old	red wine is often decanted so that the puckering bitter elements which	have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself	4044.8775327028025
15375. a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may	do as much harm as a week at sea	2831.690554619016
15376. the cork should be pulled gradually	and smoothly and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward	1260.459270239228
15377. many	people use wicker cradles for old red wine lifting the bottle carefully	from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table without	disturbing the sediment	4509.288628076502
15378. another school frowns on such a shortcut and	insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand	on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom	after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position	on its side in the cradle	5205.2575590581455
15379. in france when one wishes to entertain	at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines one visits the	restaurant well ahead of time chooses the wines and with the advice	of the manager and his chef builds the menu around them	6699.012118358131
15380. the wine	waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened	at least in time to warm and aerate preferably allowed to stand on	end for as long as possible and perhaps in the case of very old wines	be decanted	4733.386555971847
15381. decanting old wine aerates it fully; it may also be-	practically speaking- a matter of good economy	2115.8662265352054
15382. for in the process	of decanting the bottle is only tilted once instead of several	or more times at the table: hence a minimum of the undesirable mixture	of wine and dregs	3454.2619759800773
15383. though there are many exceptions which	we have noted in preceding pages white wine is as a rule best consumed	between two and six years old and red wines nowadays between three	and ten	5486.22933946508
15384. red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep	longer; the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite	number red burgundy	2579.9847045006222
15385. some clarets do not come into their own until	they are ten or fifteen years of age or even more	2842.882189359046
15386. if a red bordeaux	of a good name and year is bitter or acid or cloying and muddy-tasting	leave it alone for a while	2467.9375293438543
15387. most of the wines of beaujolais on	the other hand should be drunk while very young; and alsatians	may be	2806.8193985684215
15388. giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically: rest assured that	your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter	and spirit strictly complied with h and most particularly in regard	to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane	views	4515.716666643601
15389. giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation	249.77014623054907
15390. the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey's	overseer	1100.2813913419043
15391. an excellent crop was expected that year	139.8546732739889
15392. william	who lived in neighboring st mary's parish had taken charge and	decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated	for another year	2980.47689980004

15394. if sold then the land and improvements might	bring only $5000	506.4116228706157
15395. early in january 1844 he had a conference with	henry and william in new orleans and upon learning of gorham's	intention henry remonstrated calmly but firmly with his brother	4686.132024745853

15789. winslow upton after graduation from brown	university and two years of graduate study accepted a position	at the harvard observatory	1893.7229573814147
15790. for three years he was connected with	the us naval observatory and with the us signal corps;	and after 1883 was professor of astronomy at brown university	4289.859436698442

15792. after her father's death lucy	and her youngest sister lived for a few years with winslow in washington	dc	2578.690525081787
15793. their house writes albert s flint	was always a haven of hospitality and good cheer especially grateful	to one like myself far from home	2477.2189779037385
15794. lucy was a lively part of the	household	251.1949164469751

15796. winslow	as his daughters eleanor and margaret recall used to characterize	her as our iron sister	1885.013563387669

15799. while in washington	dc lucy upton held positions in the us census	office and in the pension bureau	1567.825383511736
15800. they were not sufficiently challenging	however and she resigned in 1887 to go to germany with her	brother winslow and his family while he was there on study	4446.148896787008
15801. after the	months in europe she returned to boston and became active in church	and community life	1408.1589972898923
15802. what was called an accidental meeting	with miss packard in washington turned her attention to spelman	1867.477249299101
15803. here was a cause she believed in	93.68907756284311
15804. after correspondence with miss	packard and to the joy of miss packard and miss giles she came	to atlanta in the fall of 1888 to help wherever needed although	there was then no money available to pay her a salary	6277.897483227573
15805. she served for	a number of years without pay beyond her travel and maintenance	938.2497675798625
15806. her students have spoken of the exacting standards of scholarship	and of manners and conduct she expected and achieved from the students;	of her great power of discernment; of her exquisiteness	of dress her well-modulated voice that went straight to the hearts	of the hearers; her great love of flowers and plants and birds;	and her close knowledge of individual students	8336.953270703994
15807. she drew	on all her resources of mind and heart to help them- to make them	at home in the world; and as graduates gratefully recall she drew on	her purse as well	3533.3748889166736
15808. many a student was able to remain at spelman only	because of her unobtrusive help	1631.9828830139459
15809. under miss upton the work	of the year 1909-10 went forward without interruption	787.6980684716207
15810. after all	she had come to spelman seminary in 1888 and had been since 1891 except	for one year associate principal or dean	3492.827742608649
15811. she had taught classes	in botany astronomy geometry	and	psychology	377.159152338082
15812. miss upton and miss packard as a matter of fact	had many tastes in common	1648.1522888486384

15818. at the fifteenth	anniversary as already quoted miss	upton projected with force and eloquence the spelman of the future	as a college of first rank with expanding and unlimited horizons	4861.993629148059

15823. she noted that no student had been withdrawn	through loss of confidence; that the enrollment showed an increase	of boarding students as was desired; and that the year's work	had gone forward smoothly	3562.774672113285

15825. the raising of the $25000 improvement	fund two days before the time limit expired and the spontaneous praise	demonstration held afterward on the campus were reported as	events which had brought happiness to miss giles	3758.987391211117

15846. mary j packard states a messenger editorial was efficient	pains-taking self-effacing loving radiating the spirit of her	master	2361.723648377731
15847. with infinite patience she responded to every call no matter	at what cost to herself and to her all went for she was sure to	have the needed information or word of cheer	3539.5160663385004
15848. in a few school districts one finds a link between school and	job	1181.3567498481166
15849. in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money	there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer	on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other	3565.3214095071407
15850. in these cases	a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program saving	a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12	3907.7962005441987
15851. the apprentice	program will involve further education on a part-time basis usually	at night perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high	school	2603.1586131856343
15852. these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such	crafts as auto mechanics carpentry drafting electrical work tool-and-die	work and sheet-metal work	3722.7663008109676
15853. formally organized vocational	programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to	gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time	job on graduation	3335.229962493515
15854. the diversified occupations program is a	part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on	a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business	employers	4311.198922286193
15855. the distributive education program operates in	a similar way with arrangements between the school and employers in	merchandising	fields	1724.154597167989
15856. in both cases the student attends school half-time	and works in a regular job the other half	2121.9543686061756
15857. he receives remuneration	for his work	43.58890709577055
15858. in a few places cooperative programs between schools	and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing	the student while still in school to develop skills which are	immediately marketable upon graduation	5625.481158872968
15859. adult education courses	work-study programs of various sorts- these are all evidence of	a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities	for out-of-school youth	2712.7717522427183
15860. in general however it may be said	that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school the school authorities	play little or no part in the decision of what happens next	5311.201893904892
15861. if the	student drops out of high school the break with the school is even	more complete	1415.4356141898552
15862. when there is employment opportunity for youth this	arrangement- or lack of arrangement- works out quite well	2096.305164727951
15863. indeed	in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities	have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were	potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and	went to work	4293.801365885067
15864. statistically this has represented a loss to the nation	although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in	retrospect may have been a wise one	4479.7311266769
15865. i make no attempt to measure the	enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work	on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business	which he entered	3677.6426215453625
15866. he may or may not be better off than his	classmate who went on to a college and professional school	2811.1174306487815
15867. but in	the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all	the potential professional talent	1577.1059251401862
15868. in a later chapter dealing	with the suburban school i shall discuss the importance of arranging	a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any	high school where he is found	5483.986713427363
15869. in the negro neighborhoods and also	to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of	identification and motivation	2184.2169888704384
15870. high motivation towards higher education	must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches	grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are	essential for academic work	5934.357876950622
15871. undoubtedly far more can be done in the	lower grades in this regard in the negro schools	1418.5272930503918
15872. however the teacher	can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family	is anti-intellectual	2612.5728034365084
15873. and the fact remains that there are today few	shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership	1558.5390411564538
15874. this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern	universities	1874.8270456388564
15875. quite the contrary as i can testify from personal	experience as a former university president	1108.1695904951107
15876. rather we see here	another vicious circle	140.42487837280925
15877. the absence of successful negroes in the world	of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among	negro youth for academic careers	2455.6447832482504
15878. i believe the situation is improving	but the success stories need to be heavily publicized	1638.9019368142733
15879. here again	we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated	as negroes in the press	1891.0491924884252
15880. how can the vicious circle be broken	140.45975231310416
15881. this	is a problem to which leaders of opinion both negro and white	should devote far more attention	1578.1567905117315
15882. it is at least as important as the	more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south	2828.021549416316
15883. i should like to underline four points	i made in my first report with respect to vocational education	1567.7404394895057
15884. first	and foremost vocational courses should not replace courses which	are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation	2830.4361181814984
15885. second	vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and	not require more than half the student's time in those years; however	for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to	begin earlier	3859.2826618563768
15886. third the significance of the vocational courses is	that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work; they realize	the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers and this	sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they	are studying at the same time	7403.528491964285
15887. fourth the type of vocational training	programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the	general locality	1567.8055434531284
15888. this last point is important because if high school	pupils are aware that few if any graduates who have chosen a certain	vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training	the whole idea of relevance disappears	6335.25447835139
15889. vocational training which	holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable	skill becomes just another school chore for those whose interest	in their studies has begun to falter	3551.130974303755
15890. those who because of population	mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees	would limit vocational education to general rather than specific	skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind	of school experience	6534.052817281436
15891. i have been using the word vocational	as a layman would at first sight think it should be used	1743.6278503915923
15892. i intend	to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys	and girls	1896.5781395426936
15893. these courses develop skills other than those we think of	when we use the adjective academic	1252.1487146043748
15894. practically all of these practical	skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained	in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at	once on the basis of the skill	6202.482839218477
15895. they are in this sense skills marketable	immediately on graduation from high school	792.1980062100645
15896. to be sure in tool-and-die	work and in the building trades the first job must be often	on an apprentice basis but two years of half-time vocational training	enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status	6345.552315983177
15897. similarly a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography	and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job	at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two	of further study in a community college or secretarial school	5019.062767980952
15898. of course	it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and	with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill	3484.5628781513783
15899. so too is the	mathematical	competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics	1101.54790704975
15900. in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be	considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student	in his vocation will be called upon to use	some of the skills developed and the competence obtained	6566.23218682185
15901. in spite	of the shading of one type of course into another i believe it is useful	to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses	2876.711508628342
15902. perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which	proves the rule	1654.1251462989057
15903. today many college bound students try to take a	course in personal typing as they feel a certain degree of mastery of	this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work	in college and a professional school	4313.166855045802
15904. most of our largest	cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools	1670.6297485116968
15905. in this respect public education in the large cities differs from education	in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts	1881.910790675298
15906. the	neighborhood high schools are not strictly speaking comprehensive schools	because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational	or technical high school instead of the local school	5014.608929354542
15907. indeed one	school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term	comprehensive	high school for the senior high schools in his city because	these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs	3761.131395149639
15908. he prefers	to designate such schools as general high schools	566.0457964948497
15909. the suburban	high school it is worth noting also is not a widely comprehensive	high school because of the absence of vocational programs	2313.160920866298
15910. the reason	is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community	1874.3266813485175
15911. therefore	employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan	area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic	of the comprehensive high school described in my first report	3442.4066912957737
15912. the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities	must be reckoned as permanent institutions	2121.974525469413
15913. by and large their programs	are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and	to the realities of the apprentice system	2031.4152074126844
15914. it is not often realized	to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of	employment except for a lucky few	3482.663382684771
15915. one has to talk confidentially with	some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a	boy cannot just say i want to be a plumber and then by doing	good work find a job	3950.0259282721263
15916. it is far more difficult in many communities	to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval	than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation	5011.553969268893
15917. two stories will illustrate what i have in mind	261.78938252680507
15918. one vocational instructor	in a city vocational school speaking of his course in a certain	field said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside	of the city	4825.219956824882
15919. in the city he said the waiting list for those	who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside	track he can't get in	3324.625433945906
15920. in a far distant part of the united states	i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade	was doing special work	4287.57473497507
15921. what does he have in mind to do when he	graduates	503.2399185043517
15922. oh he'll be a plumber came the answer	252.33773991995068
15923. but	isn't it almost impossible to get into the union	374.5813917509326
15924. i asked	0.30041514999999996
15925. he'll have no difficulty i was told	92.83943712799399
15926. he has very good	connections	22.18411061819603
15927. in my view there should be a school which offers	significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every	family in a city	2460.453581931264
15928. ideally these schools should be so located that	one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is	at the highest	3910.188258403404
15929. an excellent example of a successful location	of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school	in chicago	2031.049987399479

15934. the physical facilities at dunbar are	impressive but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils	1881.5097376479698
15935. the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the	world	642.9378577486051
15936. in the united states where half of the world crop is grown	soybeans are processed for their edible oil	2585.553815341107
15937. the residue from soybean	processing goes mainly into animal feeds	377.72273905087434
15938. soybeans are extensively	processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient	1414.6240060320865
15939. american chemists seeking to increase exports of soybeans have	adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their	use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh	of indonesia	3533.84656071782
15940. soybean flour grits flakes milk and curd can	be bought in the united states	1420.1549319237824
15941. peanuts are the world's	second most important legume	165.16656558924265
15942. they are used mainly for their oil	141.79044912662522
15943. we	produce peanut oil but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed	1096.4106752563234
15944. blanched peanuts as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating	as nuts are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off	3273.83059862367
15945. cereal grains supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans	comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of	asia and africa	2604.8976732775427
15946. in western europe and north america where	the level of economic development is higher grains and other seed	products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed	4286.880822207499
15947. rather	meat and potatoes sugar and dairy products are the main sources of	carbohydrate	protein oils and fats	1572.4249237824583
15948. people depend less on seeds for	foods in australia new zealand and argentina where extensive grazing	lands support sheep or cattle and the consumption of meat is high	4487.3025687626005
15949. feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world's	cereal crop in 1957-1958	788.0800791501279
15950. most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy	cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry	2594.3425448800454
15951. about 90 percent	of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals	1105.2825429920968
15952. the rest	is used for human food and industrial products	559.8016663169178
15953. more than half of the	sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the	milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock	3216.8955674473987
15954. more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed	to livestock annually in the united states	2597.898063084055
15955. the efficiency	with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily	in the united states since the 1930's and has paralleled the increased	feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds	are processed for oil	4390.704678130566
15956. the demand for food is so great in	the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood	crops	3494.0143334401255
15957. seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor	position	375.98878299031713
15958. chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial	uses are the oil-bearing seeds- flax castor tung	perilla and oiticica		1827.6482683488885
15959. oils or liquid fats from the	seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints	and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood	and metal	3337.4178631493705
15960. these oils develop hard smooth films when they dry and form	resinlike substances	1180.9577766726215
15961. the artist who paints in oil uses drying	oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the	ages	2191.9593901403264
15962. one of the finest of artists' oils comes from poppy seeds	757.8409225565681
15963. seeds of soybean cotton corn sesame and rape yield semidrying	oils	506.58831216139185
15964. some are used in paints along with drying oils	391.1837865742425
15965. palm oil	protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin	937.7326706752534
15966. castor oil made from castorbeans has gone out of style as a	medicine	1186.9612568746402
15967. this nondrying oil however is now more in demand than ever	before as a fine lubricant as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically	operated equipment and as a source of chemicals to make plastics	3660.7723807317534
15968. almond oil another nondrying oil was once used extensively	in perfumery to extract flower fragrances	1658.5421507869974
15969. it is still used in drugs	and cosmetics but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with	oils from peach and plum seeds	2465.1868465617035
15970. liquid fats from all these	oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household	and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives	4293.0249570639135
15971. sizable amounts of soybean coconut and palm kernel oil- seed	oils that are produced primarily for food purposes- also are used	to make soaps detergents and paint resins	2988.006488452937
15972. solid fats from	the seeds of the mahua tree the shea tree and the coconut palm are used	to make candles in tropical countries	3703.4250665275226
15973. seeds are a main source	of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world	1571.417009435884
15974. corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states canada	and australia	1648.4900989542523
15975. in other countries where cereal grains are not	among the principal crops of a region starchy tubers or roots are processed	for starch	2325.2755787325827
15976. starch is used in the paper textile and food-processing	industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations	2363.583277731928
15977. gums were extracted from quince psyllium flax	and locust seeds in ancient times	787.4993764489395
15978. today the yearly import	into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds;	of psyllium seed more than 2	3690.263617529964
15979. the discovery during	the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust	gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the	united states	3094.817887502925
15980. water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs	and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners stabilizers	or dispersing agents	3273.2241685068047
15981. guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes	ice cream	261.4694944188872
15982. quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting	lotions	563.6561052064967
15983. once regarded as an agricultural nuisance psyllium was sold	in the 1930's as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands	1891.288120489497
15984. locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers	in making paper	2114.4225395483304
15985. the seeds of hard fibrous stony fruits	called nuts provide highly concentrated foods oils and other materials	of value	1731.8766058984068

16374. radio however so increased the interest of women in the game	that it was hardly necessary even to have ladies' days any longer	to enable men to get to the ball park without interference at home	3827.8823950861515
16375. women actually began to appear unaccompanied in the stands where	they still occasionally ran the risk of coming home with a tobacco-juice	stain on a clean skirt or a new curse word tingling their ears	5656.710669673013
16376. the radio broadcasts themselves were often so patiently informative	despite the baseball jargon that girls and women could begin to	store up in their minds the same sort of random and meaningless statistics	that small boys had long learned better than they ever did their	lessons in school	4817.821595334781
16377. this conclusion is dependent on the assumption that traditional sex mores	will continue to sanction both premarital chastity as the ideal	and the double standard holding females primarily responsible for	preserving the ideal	5354.618372684876
16378. our discussion of this involves using	erik erikson's schema of identity vs identity diffusion	as a conceptual tool in superimposing a few common denominators onto	the diverse personality and family configurations of the unwed mothers	from whose case histories we quoted earlier	4403.609749242286
16379. our discussion does not	utilize all the identity crises postulated by erikson but is intended	to demonstrate the utility of his theoretical schema for studying	unwed mothers	4286.600916924302
16380. we hope thereby to emphasize that from a psychological	standpoint the effectual prevention of illegitimacy is a continuous	long-term process involving the socialization of the female from infancy	through adolescence	3209.333633292179
16381. hypothesizing a series of developmental	stages that begin in the individual's infancy and end in his old	age erikson has indicated that the adolescent is faced with a series	of identity crises	5169.871804870105
16382. the successful and positive resolution of these	crises during adolescence involves an epigenetic principle- during	adolescence the individual's positive resolutions in each area of identity	crisis depend to a considerable degree on his already having	resolved preliminary and preparatory identity crises during his infancy	childhood and early adolescence	4828.41737791639
16383. within erikson's schema the	adolescent's delinquent behavior- in this case her unwed motherhood-	reflects her identity diffusion or her inability to resolve	these various identity crises positively	4285.819673154798
16384. the adolescent	experiences identity crises in terms of time perspective vs time diffusion	785.6059490955408
16385. time perspective- the ability to plan for the future and	to postpone gratifying immediate wants in order to achieve long-range	objectives- is more easily developed if from infancy on the individual	has been able to rely on and trust people and the world in which	she lives	7157.079297958209
16386. erikson has noted that unless this trust developed early	the time ambivalence experienced in varying degree and temporarily	by all adolescents	gratification of wants during childhood while not yet having fully	may develop	into a more permanent sense of time diffusion	4273.491083595114
16387. experience of this time	diffusion ranges from a sense of utter apathy to a feeling of desperate	urgency to act immediately	3062.35572342443
16388. these polar extremes in time	diffusion were indicated in some of the comments by unwed mothers reported	in earlier chapters	1876.2124725882618
16389. some of these mothers apparently feeling a	desperate urgency made on the spur of the moment commitments in love	and sex that would have life-long consequences	4117.6373188442
16390. others displayed	utter apathy and indifference to any decision about the past or the future	1100.1766282213061
16391. for many of these unwed mothers the data on their family life	and early childhood experiences revealed several indications and sources	of their	basic mistrust of their parents in particular and of the world in	general	5822.492891502121
16392. however as erickson has noted the individual's	failure to develop preliminary identities during infancy and childhood	need not be irreversibly deterministic with respect to a given area of	identity diffusion in his adolescence	3547.021711577603
16393. and as shown in chapter	6 some snp females originally developed such trust only	during their adolescence through the aid of and their identification	with alter-parents	4108.087790553676
16394. in the specific case of time diffusion we	must emphasize the significance of the earlier development of mistrust	when it is combined with the inevitable time crisis experienced by	most adolescents in our society and with the failure of	the adolescent period to provide opportunities for developing trust	4819.723907569256
16395. the adolescent experiences two closely related crises: self-certainty	vs an identity consciousness; and role-experimentation	vs negative identity	2143.965566794932
16396. a sense of self-certainty and the freedom	to experiment with different roles or confidence in one's own unique	behavior as an alternative to peer-group conformity is more easily	developed during adolescence if during early childhood the individual	was permitted to exercise initiative and encouraged to develop some	autonomy	4825.588310087634
16397. however if the child has been constantly surrounded	during nursery and early school age by peer groups; inculcated	with the primacy of group acceptance and group standards; and allowed	little initiative in early play and work patterns- then in adolescence	her normal degree of vanity sensitivity and preoccupation with	whether others find her appearance and behavior acceptable will be compounded	8254.277817388398
16398. her ostensible indifference to and rebellion against suggestions	and criticisms by anyone except peer friends during adolescence	are the manifestations in her adolescence of her having been indoctrinated	in childhood to feel shame if not guilt for failing to behave	in a manner acceptable to and judged by the performance of her nursery-	and elementary-school peer friends	5346.014600516694
16399. to be different is to invite	shame and doubt; and it is better to be shamed and criticized by one's	parents who already consider one different and difficult to understand	than by one's peers who are also experiencing a similar groping	for and denial of adult status	7116.319392039851
16400. the attitudes of some unwed	mothers quoted in chapter 2 revealed both considerable preoccupation	with being accepted by others and a marked absence of self-certainty	2610.7395043494175
16401. many appeared to regard their sexual behavior as a justifiable	means of gaining acceptance from and identification with others; but	very few seemed aware that such acceptance and identification need	to be supplemented with more enduring and stable identification of and	with one's self	6834.927040824409
16402. another identity crisis confronting the	adolescent involves anticipation of achievement vs work-paralysis	643.9949615336369
16403. the adolescent's capacity to anticipate achievement and to exercise	the self-discipline necessary to complete tasks successfully depends	on the degree to which he or she developed autonomy initiative and	self-discipline during childhood	5176.920105658843
16404. the developmental process involves	the individual's progressively experiencing a sense of dignity and achievement	resulting from having completed tasks having kept commitments	and having created something	dress of one's own design rather than in the design it ought		3133.9879584996606
16405. these childhood experiences are sources of the self-certainty	that the adolescent needs for experimenting with many roles and	for the freedom to fail sometimes in the process of exploring and	discovering her skills and abilities	5620.035424331674
16406. if she has not had such	experiences the female's normal adolescent degree of indecision will	be compounded	1418.0706939578868
16407. erikson has noted that as	this indecision mounts it may result in a paralysis of workmanship	1249.9680747376567
16408. this paralysis may be expressed in the female's starting- and	never completing- many jobs tasks and courses of study; and in	the fact that she bases her decisions about work college carreer and	studies on what others are doing rather than on her own sense of identity	with given skills abilities likes and dislikes	7819.899370310649
16409. the absence	during her childhood and early adolescence of experiences in developing	the self-discipline to complete tasks within her ability- experiences	that would have been subsequent sources of anticipation of achievement-	and her lack of childhood opportunities to practice autonomy	and initiative in play and expression both tend in her adolescence	to deprive her of the freedoms to role-experiment and to fail occasionally	in experimenting	5717.63044409094
16410. the comments made by some unwed mothers	reflect this paralysis of workmanship	963.3816725901228
16411. they	attended school and selected courses primarily on the basis of decisions	others made; they accepted a job primarily because it was available	convenient and paid reasonably	2872.838259599492
16412. these things both express and	at the same time continue contributing to their identity diffusion	in an area that could have become a source of developing dignity and	self-certainty	4658.697382617201
16413. as their identity diffusion increased they became more	susceptible to sporadic diversions in love and sexual affairs	1420.020242472125
16414. these	affairs temporarily relieved the monotony of school or work activities	containing no anticipation of achievement and joy of craftsmanship	no sense of dignity derived from a job well done	4839.124563223223
16415. childhood	experiences in learning work and self-discipline habits within a context	of developing autonomy and initiative have considerable significance	for the prevention of illegitimacy	2472.364700028163
16416. the excerpts from case histories	presented above confirm this significance though through different	facets of experience	1867.4013456894104
16417. for example some unwed mothers had had no work	experiences household chores and responsibilities during childhood	and early adolescence; they subsequently occupied their leisure hours	in searching for something exciting and diverting	3461.656893637115
16418. on	the other hand some unwed mothers had had so much work and responsibility	imposed on them at an early age and had thus had so little freedom	or opportunity to develop autonomy and initiative that their work	and responsibilities became dull and unrewarding burdens- to be escaped	and rebelled against through fun and experimentation with forbidden	sexual behavior	8221.373273654859
16419. the adolescent also faces the identity	crisis that erikson has termed ideological polarization vs diffusion	of ideals	1420.380936944563
16420. in discussing the ways this crisis is germane to consderations	for the prevention of illegitimacy we shall again superimpose	erikson's concept on our data	3676.381463403228
16421. adolescents have a much-discussed	tendency to polarize ideas and values to perceive things as	either-or black or white- nuances of meaning are relatively	unimportant	2451.926323051751
16422. this tendency is perhaps most clearly revealed in the	literature on religious conversions and experiences of adolescents	2118.42625779987
16423. erikson	has postulated that such ideological polarization temporarily	resolves their search for something stable and definite in the rapidly	changing and fluctuating no-man's-land between childhood and adulthood	2856.5801571338043
16424. it provides identification- with an idea a value a cause that	cuts through or even transcends the multiple and ambivalent identities	of their passage from child to adult and permits their forceful	and overt expression of emotion	5948.329464334293
16425. the positive development during	adolescence of this capacity to think and to feel strongly and with	increasing independence and to identify overtly either with or against	given ideas values and practices depends to a considerable degree	on both previous and present opportunities for developing autonomy	initiative and self-certainty	4831.8729760451715
16426. most adolescents have some ideological	diffusion at various developmental stages as they experience a proliferation	of ideas and values	2599.820432024185
16427. the diffusion is most pronounced and	most likely to become fixed however in those who have had no or very	minimal opportunities to develop the autonomy and initiative that could	have been directed into constructive expression and so served as sources	of developing self-certainty	4540.248353390445
16428. a pronounced ideological	diffusion- ie inability to identify independently with given	ideas and value systems- is reflected in many ways	2832.4973693603883
16429. for example	it is evinced by the adolescent whose beliefs and actions	represent primarily his rebellion and reaction again the ideas and behavior	patterns of others rather than his inner conviction and choice	3561.2836495709935
16430. it is mirrored by the individual willie lohmans whose ideas and	behavior patterns are so dependent and relativistic that they always coincide	with those of the individual or group present and most important	at the moment	5773.582378407895
16431. in another sense it is represented in the arguments	of the true believers who seek to disprove the validity of all	other beliefs and ideas in order to retain confidence in theirs	3431.6993053276265
16432. the case histories provide some interesting illustrations of ideological	diffusion embodied in the unwed mother's inability to identify	independently with a given value system or behavior pattern and	her subsequent disinclination to assume any individual responsibility	for her sexual behavior	6334.657066012671
16433. for example the unwed mothers expressed	their frustration with males who did not indicate more explicitly what	it is they really want from a girl so one can act accordingly	3240.3330418752785
16434. they were disappointed by the physical and emotional hurt of premarital	sexual intercourse	1185.9170389608407
16435. they condemned the movie script writers for implying	that sex was enjoyable and exhilarating	940.970367651782
16436. they criticized parents	for never having emphasized traditional concepts of right and wrong;	and they censured parents who never disciplined and were too permissive	or who never explained how easy it was to get pregnant	5613.433410091392
16437. in the adult world there are a number of rather general and	diffuse sources of ideological diffusion that further compound the	adolescent's search for meaning during this particular identity crisis	3228.9402076845863
16438. for example some contemporary writing tends to fuse the good	guys and the bad guys to portray the weak people as heroes and	weakness as a virtue and to explain asocial behavior	by attributing it to deterministic psychological familial and social	experiences	6574.163931251935
16439. in the final accounting these would have augmented the bill for both	sides	790.7884779432154
16440. an estimate of one million dollars is probably not excessive	565.3224598084664
16441. yet the huge amount of money consumed by the selden litigation	which many regarded as wasteful indirectly contributed to constructive	changes in legal procedure	2456.4677618226488
16442. the duration and other circumstances	of the selden case made it a flagrant example of the gross abuses of	patent infringement actions	3258.392629895584
16443. the suit as we have seen came before	the courts when patent attorneys inventors and laymen were making mounting	demands for reforms in the american patent system	2852.5002518559636
16444. chief among	the defects they singled out were the complicated and wearisome procedures	in equity	1637.464841495719
16445. in a long and angry footnote to his opinion	judge hough had lent the weight of judicial condemnation to such criticism	2027.1458676789825
16446. it is a duty said hough not to let pass this opportunity	of protesting against the methods of taking and printing testimony	in equity current in this circuit excused	if not justified by the rules of the supreme court especially to	be found in patent causes and flagrantly exemplified in this litigation	7583.175390516035
16447. as long as the bar prefers to adduce evidence by written deposition	rather than viva voce before an authoritative judicial officer	i fear that the antiquated rules will remain unchanged and expensive	prolixity remain the best known characteristic of equity	4206.908905616175
16448. observing	that reforms sometimes begin with the contemplation of horrible	examples hough catalogued the many abuses encouraged by existing	procedures	2822.1121916952848
16449. he cited the elephantine dimensions of the selden case	record; the duplication of testimony and exhibits; the numerous	squabbles over minor matters; the objections stated at outrageous	length; and the frequent and rancorous verbal bouts uncalled	for and	unjustifiable from the retort discourteous to the lie direct	4757.644674758102
16450. the fundamental difficulty of which the selden case was	a striking example concluded hough will	remain as long as testimony is taken without any authoritative judicial	officer present and responsible for the maintenance of discipline	and the reception or exclusion of testimony	6573.509088698435
16451. not least	among the members of the patent bar who echoed this powerful indictment	were those who had participated in the selden suit	2315.195524667142
16452. william a	redding asserted that if the case had been heard in open court under	rules of evidence the testimony would have been completed in sixty	days instead of five years	5003.508240490516
16453. inventors joined lawyers in the clamor for	reform inevitably centering upon the selden litigation as a horrible	example	1573.4155348406216
16454. its costive deliberations were likened to those of	the british courts of chancery mercilessly caricatured by dickens in	bleak house	2810.853499690258
16455. parker who agreed with much of this criticism	did not conceal his dissatisfaction with procedural defects	1246.410397898917
16456. but	he felt that the selden case was being unfairly pilloried	748.8185310860899
16457. in a detailed	letter published in the scientific american in 1912 he	remarked that loose statements about the case showed scant understanding	of the facts	2594.7751158847736
16458. the suit although commonly designated as a single	action actually embraced five cases	1188.1509574949143
16459. parker insisted that the size	of the record would have been drastically reduced but for an unavoidable	duplication of testimony	1885.9038406733446
16460. in a private communication written	in 1911 parker had been more to the point	1410.3309190309983
16461. noting the complaints	of inventors and members of the patent bar he admitted that some	of the strictures were fairly well founded but he added that under	existing rules the courts could not consolidate testimony in a group	of suits involving separate infringements of the same patent	4746.634992235611
16462. the	vast industrial interests caught up in the selden suit as well as the	complex character of the automotive art encouraged both sides to exploit	every possible chance for or against the patent said parker	5634.463339687609
16463. this very seldom happens in this class or in other cases and	of course all of these matters led to a volume and an expense of the	record beyond what ordinarily would occur	3547.9717724020275
16464. parker listed the	remedies he deemed essential for reducing the cost and mass of testimony	1642.5823200841041
16465. the most important of these found him in agreement with hough's	plea for reform	945.3035303609593
16466. parker called for abolition of the indiscriminate	or uncontrolled right of taking depositions before officers of the court	who had no authority to limit testimony	3912.1153776745546
16467. the taking of depositions	he suggested should be placed under a special court examiner empowered	to compel responsive and relevant answers and to exclude immaterial	testimony	2738.5972565426023
16468. i am satisfied that in the selden case had this power	existed and this course been pursued it would have shortened	the depositions of some of the experts nearly one-half and of some of	the other witnesses thereto more than that	6448.078146400154
16469. in the end hough's	acidulous protest which parker called the now somewhat famous	note on this 'selden' case did not go unheeded	2166.0963014142244
16470. in 1912	the united states supreme court adopted a new set of rules of equity	which became effective on february 1 1913	3250.1535110789487
16471. the revised procedure	was acclaimed as a long-overdue reform	263.6805918466242
16472. under the new rules testimony	is taken orally in open court in all cases except those of an extraordinary	character	2812.0271640320043
16473. other expeditious methods are designed to prevent	prolixity limit delays and reduce the expense of infringement suits	1405.515750804371
16474. one of the alam lawyers observed that if the selden	case had been tried under this simplified procedure the testimony	which filled more than a score of volumes at a minimum cost of $1	a page for publication alone could have been contained in one volume	7033.638419342841
16475. while patent suits are still among the most complex and expensive	forms of litigation these rules have saved litigants uncounted sums	of money	2310.774883977342
16476. there is little doubt that they were promulgated by the supreme	court as a direct result of the selden patent suit	3041.8879876505616
16477. even	before it was formally dissolved in 1912 the alam	was succeeded by the automobile board of trade the direct lineal	ancestor of the present-day automobile manufacturers association	2968.5548770484957
16478. the trade bodies which came in the wake of the alam	were more representative for they never adopted a policy of exclusion	3246.6275337534307
16479. nevertheless it is from the selden organization that the industry	inherited its institutional machinery for furthering the broader interests	of the trade	2188.5750679213597
16480. one of the chief features of this community of interest	is the automotive patents cross-licensing agreement a milestone	in the development of american industrial cooperation	3879.424043011396
16481. its origin	lies in the selden patent controversy and its aftermath	501.31469763927646
16482. from	the earliest days of the motor car industry before the alam	was established patent infringement loomed as a serious and	vexing problem	3483.4584384341288
16483. many patent contests were waged over automobile components	and accessories among them tires detachable rims ball bearings	license brackets and electric horns	2171.1677415431764
16484. the fluidity and momentum of	the young industry abetted a general disregard of patent claims	1643.3622520610454
16485. as	early as 1900 a wall street combination acquired detail patents with	the intention of exacting heavy tribute from automobile manufacturers	2050.871660264903
16486. this scheme failed and the following decade brought a deluge of infringement	suits among individual manufacturers that reached its crest	in 1912	3254.7350717788327
16487. in this tangle of conflicting claims the patent-sharing	scheme adopted by the alam at its founding proved	to be the best device for avoiding or mitigating the burdens of incessant	litigation	3336.2202926082987
16488. the interchange of shop licenses for a nominal royalty	eliminated infringement suits among the members of the alam	patent pool	and kept open channels for the cross-fertilization of automotive	technology	4828.6414014788525
16489. one of the conditions of the pool was a prohibition	upon the withholding of patent rights among alam members	1724.0538086717079

16491. its positive features	outweighed the fact that the pool was an adjunct of a wouldbe monopoly	1264.0711412060414
16492. since the alam holdings embraced only about twenty-five	per cent of motor vehicle patents the denial of rights to independent	companies did not retard technical progress in unlicensed sectors	of the industry	5153.427714295493

16501. the prevailing view in the industry was	summed up in 1912 by a group of auto makers who told a senate committee:	the exceedingly unsatisfactory and uselessly expensive conditions	including delays surrounding legal disputes particularly in patent	litigation are items of industrial burden which must be written	large in figures of many millions of dollars of industrial waste	5362.389686841032
