16728. overnight for one thing porter's	film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten	1643.8289987258704
16729. the	great train robbery is a one-reel film	169.01793440861974
16730. one reel- from eight to	twelve minutes- became the standard length from the year of robbery	1903 until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of	a nation in 1915	4810.570189069066
16731. the reel itself became and still is the standard	of measure for the movies	944.1703921904793
16732. the material of the porter film	is simplicity itself; much of it has continued to be used over the	years and the heart of it- good guys and bad guys in the old west-	pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950's	6823.19428824949
16733. a	band of robbers enters a railroad station overpowers and ties up the	telegraph operator holds up the train and escapes	2028.4667977058034
16734. a posse is formed	and pursues the robbers who having made their escape are whooping	it up with some wild wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out	4081.986965610232
16735. the robbers	run from the hide-out take cover in a wooded declivity and are shot	dead by the posse	1739.8950661023282
16736. as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the	band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience	3268.4192142661623
16737. all this is simple enough but in telling the story porter did	two important things that had not been done before	2027.7881609741107
16738. each scene is shot	straight through as had been the universal custom from a camera fixed	in a single position but in the outdoor scenes especially in the	capture and destruction of the outlaws porter's camera position	breaks necessarily with the camera position standard until then which	had been roughly that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at	a play	8440.54207125308
16739. the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the	plane of the film in the camera or on the screen	2477.110606262281
16740. if the change at	first sight seems minor we may recall that it took the italian painters	about two hundred years to make an analogous change and the italian	painters by universal consent were the most brilliant group of	geniuses any art has seen	6766.449952295554
16741. in that apparently simple shift porter	opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of	art as well as a mechanical recording device	3002.9071351090506
16742. he did more than	that	22.10060894283544
16743. he revealed the potential value of the cut as the basic	technique in the art of the film	1575.0018965936272
16744. cutting of course takes place automatically	in the creation of a film	963.4220685639169
16745. the meaning of the word is quite	physical to begin with	504.87267952395985
16746. the physical film is cut with a knife at the	end of one complete sequence and the cut edge is joined physically	by cement to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence	5638.277142835002
16747. if	as a home movie maker you shoot the inevitable footage of your child	taking its first steps you have merely recorded an historical event	2614.372184806988
16748. if in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends	you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child's	grandmother watching this event you have begun to be an artist in	film; you are employing the basic technique of film; you are cutting	7344.31295630687
16749. this is what porter did	14.826508421179264
16750. as the robbers leave the looted	train the film suddenly cuts back to the station where the telegrapher's	little daughter arrives with her father's dinner pail only	to find him bound on the floor	5496.672481083078
16751. she dashes around in alarm	14.750160309997133
16752. the two	events are taking place at the same time	563.4887267575276
16753. time and space have both become	cinematic	94.50135012520667
16754. we leap from event to event- including the formation	of the posse- even though the events in reality are taking	place not in sequence but simultaneously and not near each other but	at a considerable distance	5783.968713263445
16755. the chase as a standard film	device probably dates from the great train robbery and there	is a reason for the continued popularity of the device	2744.9178332126285
16756. the chase in	itself is a narrative; it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands	cutting- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage	of the journey of both	5195.303350667193
16757. the simple naked idea of one man chasing another	is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other	form of fiction	2851.042235682401
16758. the cowboy films the cops and robbers films and	the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not	only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence;	these films and these sequences are also seeking out- instinctively	or by design- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative	7736.523659387795
16759. there	still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full	potential of the new form and to make it an art	2603.230876633198
16760. the man was dw	griffith	22.340084278954997
16761. when he came to the movies- more or less by accident-	they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking	for an idle few minutes	2716.926159792437
16762. in about seven years griffith either	invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource	at the disposal of the film maker	3512.4077887037465
16763. before he was forty griffith	had created the art of the film	643.6557639587415
16764. not that there had not been	attempts mostly european to do exactly that	1178.4400529507825
16765. but in general the european	efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly	emerging language of the film itself	2326.603965118688
16766. staggeringly condensed versions	of famous novels and famous plays were presented	746.4801327894661
16767. great actors	and actresses- the most notable being sarah bernhardt- were hired	to repeat their stage performances before the camera	1876.160501616816
16768. in all of this	extensive and expensive effort the camera was downgraded to the status	of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor	or by the author	4847.473674844003
16769. the phonograph today for all its high fidelity	and stereophonic sound is precisely what the early art purveyors in	the movies wished to make of the camera	2869.1064325071393
16770. not surprisingly this approach	did not work	140.521324408398
16771. the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques	in the early years of the century and some interesting records	of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names	3239.0581470957522
16772. but no art	at all was born of the art effort in the early movies	1646.5430518221795
16773. in general religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis;	congregational membership however is another thing	1714.212628069284
16774. a congregation	survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership;	that is when it can preserve economic integration	2829.2217438047214
16775. religious	faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in	a congregation since the decision to join a worshiping group requires	some motive force but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining;	the presence of other members of similar social and economic	level is the sufficient condition	4898.14612705836
16776. the breakdown of social	homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account	for the decline of central city churches	3680.5782283283324
16777. central cities reveal	two adverse features for the major denominations: central cities	tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes; central	cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition	3433.084489954154
16778. the central	city areas in other words exhibit the two characteristics which	violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations:	they have too few middle-class people; they mix middle-class people	with lower-class residents	5619.358515627855
16779. central city areas have become progressively	poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus	of middle-class people from most central cities	2186.1959596266297
16780. with few exceptions	the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central	city	1655.1389766933873
16781. the key to protestant development therefore is economic	integration of the nucleus of the congregation	1101.703609389921
16782. members of higher	and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus so that protestant	figures on social class give the impression of spread over all	social classes; but this is deceptive for the core of membership	is	concentrated in a single social and economic stratum	7028.868324036981
16783. the congregation	perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the	neighborhood; moreover residential mobility is so high in metropolitan	areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum	in order to survive; they can lose higher- and lower-status members	from the church without collapsing but they need adequate recruits	for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration	5786.342152365186
16784. the	congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group; it is	secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship	2372.0593160036597
16785. if it were primarily	a believing fellowship it would recruit believers from all social	and economic ranks something which most congregations of the new protestantism	have not been able to do	3337.843160594938
16786. they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers	753.0216449136525
16787. the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences	has often been attributed to the folksy spirit of protestant	religious life; in fact a contrast is often drawn in this regard	with the impersonal roman catholic parish	3858.749998803368
16788. we have seen that	the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers; consequently the	vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress	on personal community in protestant congregations; actually there	is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations	as we shall see in another connection	7391.006699190012
16789. the vulnerability of	protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of	the new religious style in middle-class life where the congregation is	a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform therefore	to the principle of economic integration	4390.630343136892
16790. this fact is evident	in the recruitment of new members	557.5674663258683
16791. the	rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the	missionary outreach of the major denominations	1736.9612319151718
16792. there is much talk	in theological circles about the church as mission and the church's	mission; theologians have been stressing the fact that	the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in	the world for the healing of the world	6965.535445658186
16793. a crucial question therefore	is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism	943.2683693248111
16794. if economic integration really shapes congregational life then	evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration	2122.51621470799
16795. the task of a congregation would be defined according to economic integration	as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar	social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation	3674.59812874875
16796. fill a vacancy; it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power	in a	mobile society congregational health depends on a constant process of	recruitment; this recruitment however must follow the pattern of	economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation; therefore	the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation	rather than proclamation- like elements will have to be assimilated	8550.521252848343
16797. evangelism and congregational outreach have not been	carefully studied in the churches; one study in pittsburgh however	has illuminated the situation	2033.1156371904417
16798. in a sample of new members of pittsburgh	churches almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial contacts	with friendly members	3017.46863782498
16799. if we add to these contacts with friendly	members the contacts with an organization of the church	then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment	is through friendly contact	3116.7461053856505
16800. on the surface this seems a sound	approach to christian mission: members of the congregation show by	their friendly attitudes that they care for new people; the new people	respond in kind by joining the church	5767.681044479892
16801. missionary outreach	by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what	is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods; the majority	of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic	position; association by level of achievement is the dominant principle	of informal relations	4755.047988232933
16802. this means that the antennae of the congregation	are extended into the community picking up the wave lengths	of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation;	the mission of the church is actually a process of informal	co-optation; the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people	who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation	8576.212673632424
16803. churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long	as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people	who can fit the pattern of economic integration; once the pool of recruits	diminishes the congregation is helpless- friendly contacts no	longer keep it going	4844.25267996983
16804. the transmutation of mission to co-optation	is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities	worship preaching and publicity in reaching new members	3483.627240722879
16805. the	proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts	by the clergy and friendly contacts	by members	1890.3586563472006
16806. 1 per cent of the initial contacts with	new members	560.6304080669981
16807. in general friendly contact with a member followed by	contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment	by the churches making it quite evident that the extension of economic	integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission	in the contemporary church; economic integration and co-optation are	the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from	the neighborhood	5729.7683009795865
16808. the inner life of congregations will prosper so long	as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize	together; the outer life of congregations- the suitability	of the environment to their survival- will be propitious so long as	the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the	membership	7972.0244360202
16809. economic integration ceases when the social and economic	statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of	the congregation	2331.220757461004
16810. in a rapidly changing society congregations will run	into difficulties repeatedly since such nice balances of economic integration	are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single	generation	5002.013689855647
16811. the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations	have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred	years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle	to maintain economic balance	3550.490012330881
16812. the expense of this type of organization	in religious life when one recalls the number of city churches which	deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned raises fundamental	questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile	society; nonetheless the prevalence of economic integration in congregations	illumines the nature of the protestant development	7693.175633620085
16813. it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had	split into two trends- expanding interdependence on an impersonal	basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings	2973.1710067924096
16814. these trends	seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis	750.8588023067022
16815. residential	associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions	166.7239319434649
16816. the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential	communities have polarized; the schism between central city and suburb	negro and white blue collar and white collar can be viewed as	symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis	6432.397005936641
16817. it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved	with the economy of middle-class culture for it serves to crystallize	the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings	3227.6279009474033
16818. the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the	drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations	2358.2164908550135
16819. this	conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable	environment	647.3704723175974
16820. more than creatures of metropolitan forces the	churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan	life crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of	peoples giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world	of heterogeneous peoples	6334.513751179442
16821. since american life is committed	above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life the	countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have	fought a desperate rearguard action against the expanding interdependence	of the metropolis	3954.6359526598803
16822. consumer communities have suffered at the hands	of the productive interests	753.5965466869877
16823. negroes puerto ricans and rural	newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities	949.8482239413248
16824. soon they will	fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs and the churches	will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized	their history for a century	4856.99696745867
16825. the identification of the basic unit	of religious organization- the parish or congregation- with a	residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis for it simply	means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian	fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation	4776.577110926798
16826. mission	to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential	community because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan	interdependence with residential exclusion	3692.6423943295777
16827. this interpretation	of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could	lead to various projections for the churches	2024.306082876834
16828. it could be argued	that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed	to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the	middle classes	4466.970055052456
16829. it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain	religious activity since worship presupposes some local stabilities	1573.93863723917
16830. whatever projection one makes the striking fact about congregational	and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the	social identity of middle-class people	4483.351563574672
16831. attention will be given	in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational	churches; this style is characteristically an expression of the	communal style of the middle classes	3332.359932589403
16832. the keynotes of this style are	activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem	1403.0839129988258
16833. these	values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman dictating	the methods of child rearing determining the pattern of community	participation setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of	middle-class illness and informing the congregational life of the major	denominations	4536.379534116941
16834. fellowship by likeness and mission by friendly	contact form the iron cage of denominational religion	1662.4791564269588
16835. its contents	are another matter for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued	by the congregation	1251.8690618467892
16836. what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention	under the rubric of the organization church	2130.5530749765303
16837. an understanding	of the new role of residential association in an industrial society	serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of	conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity	3646.772206235009
16838. the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes	turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs	and charities should fill the same need	5013.922035702644
16839. with capital largely squandered there seemed to them no other course	to pursue	787.6972100671763
16840. the directors sold directly to concessionaires who	had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company	2809.614242806184
16841. these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt	with the indians through engages who might be habitants voyageurs	or even soldiers	2180.8182153413622
16842. the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of	one-tenth on the goods they traded and all pelts were to be taken to	company stores and shipped to france in company ships	5147.368416030995
16843. the company	disposed of the pelts but with what profit the records do not show	1099.3480185939575
16844. in accord with its penurious policy the company failed to furnish	presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians	2819.862852153944
16845. the lavish	use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade	of new france and louisiana in the previous century and the change	in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men	3848.376209311997
16846. traders	from the english colonies were far more generous and indian loyalty	turned to them	1642.565032633983
16847. protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded	and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian	insurrections that brought ruin to the company	2582.059285276664
16848. in 1721	the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do	all that was necessary to protect the colony	3257.135815894556
16849. they ordered the raising	of troops and obtained 75000 livres with which to build forts	1090.4344107228296
16850. they	adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts	959.111007590893
16851. in each of these there was to be a strong military post and a trading	depot to supply the smaller trading houses	2186.1856061045173
16852. for southeastern	louisiana	mobile was the principal post and it was to furnish supplies	for trade to the north and east in the region threatened by british	traders	4468.322296959235
16853. mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending	northward to the sources of the tennessee river	1870.712531028255
16854. fort toulouse	on the alabama river had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas	and choctaws but money was available for only one other new	post near the present nashville tennessee and this was soon abandoned	6058.833365125962
16855. west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi	district of which new orleans was headquarters	1245.6126012953814
16856. dependent upon it	were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers	of new spain	2587.92306250095
16857. on the middle mississippi a principal	post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas	1418.623724597271
16858. it was hoped	that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west	principally down the arkansas river	3260.9823776285666
16859. on the ohio or wabash was to	be built another post at the fork of two great rivers	1563.8683133280006
16860. other	posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication	with canada	1657.9291412207635
16861. on the upper mississippi the illinois post was	to be established near kaskaskia and dependent posts were to be built	on the missouri where there are mines in abundance	3098.252133494069
16862. each of the five principal posts was to have a director responsible	to a director-general at new orleans	2354.7818568970206
16863. an elaborate system of accounting	and reports was worked out and the trade was to be managed in the	most scientific way	2172.7588417738384
16864. concessionaires were to be under the supervision	of the directors	560.191204573088
16865. engages must be loyal to the concessionaires	and must serve until the term provided in the engagement was ended	1724.5253310576973
16866. the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose	of their pelts to the concessionaires	2337.1237734631936
16867. only two principal storehouses	were actually established- one at mobile the other at new	orleans	1095.40664319772
16868. new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi	and west of that river and on the ohio and wabash	3289.181493307634
16869. mobile	was also supplied by new orleans with goods for the mobile district	791.1507177737184
16870. the power that bienville exercised during his first administration	cannot be determined	961.6892187533106
16871. regulations for the indian trade were	made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane and bienville	apparently did not have control of that body	2447.436247969706
16872. the conseil even	treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and	on its own authority sent to disaffected savages merchandise suitable	for the peltry trade	4480.847316047795
16873. it decided also that the purely secular	efforts of bienville were insufficient and sent missionaries to	win the savages from the heathen carolinians	2323.1219491192796
16874. during the first	administration of bienville the peltry trade of the mobile district	was a lucrative source of revenue	2592.9971524450348
16875. the alabamas brought in annually	15000 to 20000 deerskins and the choctaws and chickasaws brought	the total up to 50000 pelts	2035.3175383308076
16876. these deerskins were the raw material	for the manufacture of leather and were the only articles which the	tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods	4473.771606485729
16877. during his first administration bienville succeeded in keeping carolina	traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country	1715.132874091006
16878. the	director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french	goods of a kind to which they were accustomed to supply the indian	needs	4282.507368555969
16879. the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which	goods could be moved quickly and cheaply	1421.9361248207256
16880. de la laude commander	of the alabama post had the friendship of the natives and was able	to make them look upon the british as poor competitors	4282.743932030958
16881. diron d'artaguette	the most prominent trader in the district was energetic and	resourceful but his methods often aroused the ire of the french governors	2467.8666191153043
16882. he became after a time commander of a post on the alabama	river but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district	and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade	5179.040022350737
16883. the	chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district	641.7345454302761
16884. their territory lay to the north near the sources of the alabama	the tombigbee the tennessee and cumberland rivers and was	easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees	4640.988192033606
16885. in 1720 some	chickasaws massacred the french traders among them and did not	make peace for four years	1570.1282596719232
16886. venturesome traders however continued to	come to them from mobile and to obtain a considerable number of pelts	for the french markets	3261.9422730591045
16887. british traders from south carolina incited	the indians against the french and there developed french and	british factions in the tribe	2049.381976860255
16888. the chickasaws finally were the occasion	for the most disastrous wars during the french control of louisiana	2120.052631780404
16889. to hold them was an essential part of french policy for they	controlled the upper termini of the routes from the north to mobile	2450.8712854679825
16890. they threatened constantly to give the british a hold on this region	from whence they could move easily down the rivers to the french	settlements near the gulf	4488.847538827639
16891. bienville realized that if the french	were to hold the southeastern tribes against the enticements of british	goods french traders must be able to offer a supply as abundant	as the carolinians and at reasonable prices	3877.2939614128277
16892. his urgings brought	some results	22.416695833364308
16893. the company of the indies promised to send over a supply	of indian trading goods and to price them more cheaply in terms	of deerskins	2597.213911451615
16894. but it coupled with this a requirement that indians	must bring their pelts to mobile and thus save all costs of transportation	into and out of the indian country	4625.658445492633
16895. the insistence of bienville	upon giving liberal prices to the indians in order to drive	back the carolina traders was probably a factor that led to his recall	in 1724	3217.9980801038437
16896. for two years his friend and cousin boisbriant remained	as acting governor and could do little to stem the anglican advance	3060.9922438972562
16897. although he incited a few friendly indians to pillage the invaders	and even kill some of them the carolina advance continued	2044.4368060648353
16898. the company was impressed with some ideas of the danger from carolina	and when perier came over as governor in 1727 he was given special	instructions regarding the trade of the mobile district	5348.637477970298
16899. but the	company of the indies holding to its program of economy made no arrangements	to furnish better goods at attractive prices	2183.6700412454807
16900. to the directors	the problem appeared a matter of intrigue or diplomacy	970.8407887265436
16901. perier	attempted to understand the problem by sending agents to inquire among	the indians	944.4787826242178
16902. these agents were to ascertain the difference between	english and french goods and the prices charged the indians	2376.74778761157
16903. they	were to conciliate the unfriendly savages and wherever possible to	incite the natives to pillage the traders from carolina	1883.5403658587002
16904. they were	to promise fine presents to the loyal red men as well as an abundant	supply of trading goods at better prices than the opposition was offering	4473.841963783262
16905. perier's intrigues gained some successes	14.890298082856898
16906. the savages divided	into two factions; one was british and the other french	1196.5410179920177
16907. so hostile	did these factions become that among the choctaws civil war broke	out	944.1624392209806
16908. perier's efforts however were on the whole ineffective	in winning back the tribes of the mobile district and he decided	to send troops into the troubled country	4284.775345942855
16909. he asked the government	for two hundred soldiers who were to be specifically assigned to arrest	english traders and disloyal indians	2017.8800220840299

17140. the achievement of the desegregation of certain lunch counters not only	by wise action by local community leaders but by voluntary action following	consultation between attorney general rogers and the heads	of certain national chain stores should of course be applauded	6468.000921652283

17155. the language used	itself often makes very clear that this is only another form of struggle	for victory	1572.7692899958015

17162. r b gregg has written that non-violence and good will of	the victim act like the lack of physical opposition by the user of physical	jiu-jitsu to cause the attacker to lose his moral balance	5628.986874616776
17163. he	suddenly and unexpectedly loses the moral support which the usual violent	resistance of most victims would render him; and again that	the object of non-violent resistance is partly analogous to this object	of war- namely to demoralize the opponent to break his will	to destroy his confidence enthusiasm and hope	5020.186495792641
17164. in another respect	it is dissimilar for non-violent resistance demoralizes the opponent	only to re-establish in him a new morale that is firmer because it is	based on sounder values	4820.376505656941
17165. a trial of strength however is made	quite inevitable by virtue of the fact that anyone engaging in non-violent	resistance will be convinced that his action is based on sounder	values than those of his opponent; and in warfare with any means	men commonly disagree over the justice of the cause	4994.695193200307

17290. however in recent decades for what doubtless are multiple	reasons an unannounced but nonetheless readily observable shift has	occurred in both facets of national activity	2604.525803960781
17291. a concept of responsibility	is in process of articulation and establishment	750.3240297789523
17292. already firmly	implanted internally it is a growing factor in external matters	641.4483997241065
17293. a little more than twenty years ago the american people turned	an important corner	1421.111989903191
17294. in what has aptly been called a constitutional	revolution the basic nature of government was transformed from	one essentially negative in nature to	one with affirmative duties to perform	3110.2796717083656
17295. the positive state came	into existence	65.36556389666123
17296. for lawyers reflecting perhaps their parochial preferences	there has been a special fascination since then in the role	played by the supreme court in that transformation- the manner in	which its decisions altered in the switch in time that saved nine	president roosevelt's ill-starred but in effect victorious court-packing	plan the imprimatur of judicial approval that was	finally placed upon social legislation	5593.793964301485
17297. of greater importance however	is the content of those programs which have had and are having enormous	consequences for the american people	3259.87990234066
17298. labor relations have been	transformed income security has become a standardized feature of political	platforms and all the many facets of the american version of	the welfare state have become part of the conventional wisdom	3771.8882883179817
17299. a national	consensus of near unanimity exists that these governmental efforts	are desirable as well as necessary	2132.5738745403332
17300. ratified in the republican party	victory in 1952 the positive state is now evidenced by political	campaigns being waged not on whether but on how much social	legislation there should be	3326.521074065581
17301. the general acceptance of the idea	of governmental responsibility for the economic	well-being of the american people is surely one of the two most significant	watersheds in american constitutional history	4797.721976553199
17302. the other of	course was the civil war the conflict which a century ago insured	national unity over fragmentation	1738.454236622798
17303. a third one of at least equal and	perhaps even greater importance is now being traversed: american	immersion and involvement in world affairs	3474.046106204777
17304. internal national	responsibility now a truism need not be documented	374.86768925552144
17305. nevertheless	it may be helpful to cite one example- that of employment- for as	will be shown below it cuts across both facets of the new concept	4269.32815561622
17306. thirty	years ago while the nation was wallowing in economic depression	the prevailing philosophy of government was to stand aside and allow	natural forces to operate and cure the distress	3227.9065293504227
17307. that guiding	principle of the hoover administration fell to the siege guns of the	new deal; less than a score of years later congress enacted the	employment act of 1946 by which the national government assumed the	responsibility of taking action to insure conditions of maximum employment	7125.583116044018
17308. hands-off the economy was replaced by conscious guidance through	planning- the economic side of the constitutional revolution	1408.3810735071922
17309. in	1961 the first important legislative victory of the kennedy administration	came when the principle of national responsibility for local	economic distress won out over a state's-responsibility	proposal- provision was made for payment for unemployment relief	by nation-wide taxation rather than by a levy only on those states afflicted	with manpower surplus	7623.335593985185
17310. the american people have indeed come	a long way in the brief interval between 1930 and 1961	1413.267275113747
17311. internal	national responsibility is a societal response to the impact of the	industrial revolution	1414.511359262986
17312. reduced to its simplest terms it is an assumption	of a collective duty to compensate for the inability of individuals	to cope with the rigors of the era	2976.9535773443813
17313. national responsibility for	individual welfare is a concept not limited to the united states or	even to the western nations	2839.8387938800834
17314. a measure of its widespread acceptance	may be derived from a statement of the international congress of jurists	in 1959	1875.253124470709
17315. meeting in new delhi under the auspices of the international	commission of jurists a body of lawyers from the free world	the congress redefined and expanded the traditional rule of law	to include affirmative governmental duties	5802.046648964962
17316. it is noteworthy that	the majority of the delegates to the congress were from the less developed	former colonial nations	1880.7972262353655
17317. the rule of law historically a principle	according everyone his day in court before an impartial tribunal	was broadened substantively by making it a responsibility of	government to promote individual welfare	5005.93380845678
17318. recognizing that the rule	of law is a dynamic concept h which should be employed not only	to safeguard the civil and political rights of the individual in a free	society the congress asserted that it also included the responsibility	to establish social economic educational and cultural conditions	under which his legitimate aspirations and dignity may be realized	5422.355519528711
17319. the idea of national responsibility thus has become a common	feature of the nations of the non-soviet world	2371.0312706100367
17320. for better or for worse	we all now live in welfare states the organizing principle of which	is collective responsibility for individual well-being	2322.6347939950692
17321. whether	a concept analogous to the principle of internal responsibility	operates in a nation's external relations is less obvious and more	difficult to establish	3683.872315789997
17322. the hypothesis ventured here is that it does	and that evidence is accumulating validating that proposition	1252.7502207436464
17323. the content	is not the same however: rather than individual security it	is the security and continuing existence of an ideological group-	those in the free world- that is basic	4827.025357602697
17324. external national	responsibility involves a burgeoning requirement that the leaders of	the western nations so guide their decisions as to further the viability	of other friendly nations	2878.9581308031948
17325. if internal responsibility suggests acceptance	of the socialist ideal of equality then external responsibility	implies adherence to principles of ideological supranationalism	3043.680717229042
17326. reference to two other concepts- nationalism and sovereignty-	may help to reveal the contours of the new principle	1563.4746793226973
17327. in its beginnings	the nation-state had to struggle to assert itself- internally	against feudal groups and externally against the power and influence	of such other claimants for loyalty as the church	5009.959149182399
17328. the breakup of	the holy roman empire and the downfall of feudalism led not more	than two centuries ago to the surge of nationalism	2457.6159446296715
17329. of the nation-state coincides roughly with the separate existence	of the united states as an independent entity it is perhaps natural	for americans to think of the nation as representative of the highest	the concept of	nationalism is the political principle that epitomizes and glorifies	the territorial state as the characteristic type of socal structure	7886.799973780282
17330. but	it is more than that	43.43815757217439
17331. for it includes the emotional ties that bind	men to their homeland and the complex motivations that hold a large	group of people together as a unit	4290.867832292607
17332. today as new nations rise from	the former colonial empires nationalism is one of the hurricane forces	loose in the world	2041.3762073108112
17333. almost febrile in intensity the principle has	become worldwide in application- unfortunately at the very time that	nationalist fervors can wreak greatest harm	3488.71072954988
17334. historically however	the concept is one that has been of marked benefit to the people of the	western civilizational group	1876.5873374695152
17335. by subduing disparate lesser groups	the nation has to some degree at least broadened the capacity for individual	liberty	2605.2731918947547
17336. within their confines moreover technological and	industrial growth has proceeded at an accelerated pace thus increasing	the cornucopia from which material wants can be satisfied	2608.7974271715934
17337. while the	pattern is uneven some having gained more than others nationalism	has in fact served the western peoples well	2828.661598243075
17338. helped the peoples of the remainder of the world and whether	today's nationalism in the former colonial areas has equally beneficial	it is one of the ironic quirks	of history that the viability and usefulness of nationalism and the	territorial state are rapidly dissipating at precisely the time that	the nation-state attained its highest number	5235.323034889662
17339. but	it is more than irony: one of the main reasons why nationalism is	no longer a tenable concept is because it has spread throughout the	planet	4303.053621224435
17340. in other words nationalism worked well enough when it had	limited application both as to geography and as to population; it	becomes a perilous anachronism when adopted on a world-wide basis	3336.907891231274
17341. complementing the political principle of nationalism is the legal	principle of sovereignty	955.6937075628751
17342. the former receives its legitimacy from the	latter	167.156243109172
17343. operating side by side together they helped shore up the nation-state	747.4719118210188
17344. while sovereignty has roots in antiquity in its present	usage it is essentially modern	937.3317099724578
17345. jean bodin writing in the sixteenth	century may have been the seminal thinker but it was the vastly influential	john austin who set out the main lines of the concept as now	understood	5334.967021940749
17346. austin's nineteenth-century view of law and sovereignty	still dominates much of today's legal and political thinking	1246.2095523907697
17347. to	him law is the command of the sovereign who	personifies the power of the nation while sovereignty is the power to	make law- ie to prevail over internal groups and to be free	from the commands of other sovereigns in other nations	6690.557330169353
17348. these fundamental	ideas- the indivisibility of sovereignty and its dual	aspects- still remain the core of that concept of ultimate	political power	2162.9031866383793
17349. the nation-state then exemplifies the principle	of nationalism and exercises sovereignty: supreme power over	domestic affairs and independence from outside control	3046.0002504374906
17350. in fact however	both principles have always been nebulous and loosely defined	643.6093590400521
17351. high-level	abstractions are always difficult to pin down with precision	558.9561468237259
17352. that is particularly true of sovereignty when it is applied to democratic	societies in which popular sovereignty is said to exist	and in federal nations in which the jobs of government are split	3532.044738134731
17353. nevertheless	nationalism and sovereignty are reputed in the accepted	wisdom to describe the modern world	1656.3520634460147
17354. is there a different reality behind	the facade	167.13288873826585
17355. does the surface hide a quite different picture	249.92809075344448
17356. the short answer to those questions is yes	167.57871277919634
17357. both concepts	are undergoing alteration; to some degree they are being supplanted	by a concept of national responsibility	2353.4643635251414
17358. as evidence to support	that view consider the following illustrative instances	506.38356510579143
17359. can thermonuclear war be set off by accident	250.90387721169455
17360. what steps have been	taken to guard against the one sort of mishap that could trigger the	destruction of continents	1876.2386776074861

17377. as an air force psychiatrist put it: you can't have	dry runs on this one	1665.6602341347086

17380. already accidental	war is a silent guest at the discussions within the kennedy administration	about the urgency of disarmament and nearly all other questions	of national security	2880.058094225499
17381. only recently new holes were	discovered in our safety measures and a search is now on for more	2360.9671356747867

17384. they inhabit a secret world centered on go codes and gold	phones	644.4491535736213

17394. in recent weeks as a result of a sweeping defense policy reappraisal	by the kennedy administration basic united states strategy	has been modified- and large new sums allocated- to meet the accidental-war	danger and to reduce it as quickly as possible	4321.262803802935
17395. the	chain starts at bmews	in thule greenland	249.7535998843467
17396. its radar screens would register soviet	missiles shortly after they are launched against the united states	1259.6129860085211
17397. bmews intelligence is simultaneously flashed to norad	in colorado springs	colorado for interpretation; to the sac command and control	post forty-five feet below the ground at offutt air force base near	omaha nebraska; to the joint war room of the joint chiefs	of staff in the pentagon and to the president	7541.182403666229
17398. telephones	teletypes several kinds of radio systems and in some cases television	link all vital points	1248.9852039281643
17399. alternate locations exist for all key command	centers	250.49048960112705
17400. for last-ditch emergencies sac has alternate command	posts on kc-135 jet tankers	643.8585098667775
17401. multiple circuits routings and	frequencies make the chain as unbreakable as possible	964.029766285745
17402. the	same principle of redundancy applies to all communications on these	special networks	786.33532004522
17403. and no messages can be transmitted on these circuits	until senders and receivers authenticate in advance by special	codes	that the messages actually come from their purported sources	4486.008262933321
17404. additional	codes can be used to challenge and counterchallenge the authentications	502.5423098241037
17405. only the president is permitted to authorize the	use of nuclear weapons	963.6841625089795
17406. but what if somebody decides	to break it	165.29126183068803
17407. the president cannot personally remove the safety	devices from every nuclear trigger	968.0169133108327

17409. hundreds of men are required to pass the word to the button pushers	and to push the buttons	2363.1602424614016
17410. what if one or more of them turn irrational	or suddenly coolly decide to clobber the russians	1419.9012943380017
17411. what if the president	himself in the language of the military goes ape	1182.529257229751
17412. or singlehandedly decided to reverse national policy and hit the soviets	without provocation	786.8045903723615
17413. nobody can be absolutely certain of	the answers	250.61594868467006
17414. however the system is designed ingeniously and hopefully	so that no one man could initiate a thermonuclear war	1578.0086222976272
17415. even	the president cannot pick up his telephone and give a go order	1190.7370065410155

17417. in an emergency he would receive available intelligence	on the gold-phone circuit	966.639673651766

17419. all can be connected with the gold circuit	from their homes	752.2388544926969

17441. general power would participate in the decision	making	250.0503288585456

17898. the negro faces as much if not more difficulty in fitting	himself into an urban economy as he did in an agrarian one	2327.8889892029283
