17900. but there	have been abrupt changes as well: the sit-ins the picket lines	the bus strikes- all of these were unheard-of even ten years ago	2607.4849177777623
17901. today's evidence such as the fact that only three southern states	still openly defy integration	would have astounded many of yesterday's southerners into speechlessness	3685.908219578694
17902. other examples of gradual changes that have	affected the negro have been his moving up row by row in the busses;	his requesting and often getting higher wages better working conditions	better schools- changes that were slowly emerging even before	the supreme court decision of 1954	4673.158660473178
17903. then came this decision which	sped the process of gaining equality	: an abrupt change	798.4380738263296
17904. since 1954 the negro's desire for social justice has led	to an ironically anarchical rebellion	1094.3472340920534
17905. he has frequently refused to move	from white lunch counters refused to obey local laws which he	considers unjust while in other cases he has appealed to federal	laws	4642.4664436286275
17906. this bold self-assertion after decades of humble subservience	is indeed a twentieth-century phenomenon an abrupt change in the southern	way of existence	2180.19739143853
17907. a new order is thrusting itself into being	252.17212844012596
17908. a new south is emerging after the post-bellum years of hesitation	uncertainty and lack of action from the negro in defining his new role	in the amorphously defined socio-political organizations of the white	man	3664.6284825178204
17909. the modern negro has not made a decisive debut into southern	fiction	962.5706077285435
17910. it is clear that while most writers enjoy picturing	the negro as a woolly-headed humble old agrarian who mutters yassuhs	and sho' nufs with blissful deference to his white employer	this stereotype is doomed	to become in reality as obsolete as caldwell's lester	4455.965507066295
17911. while	there may still be many faulknerian lucas beauchamps scattered through	the rural south such men appear to be a vanishing breed	3261.4438939880624
17912. writers	openly admit that the negro is easier to write than the white man;	but they obviously mean by this not a negro personality but a negro	type	2984.741357282769
17913. presenting an individualized negro character it would	seem is one of the most difficult assignments a southern writer could	tackle; and the success of such an endeavor is as suggested above	glaringly rare	5345.8655865985
17914. just as the negro situation points up the	gradual and abrupt changes affecting southern life it also points up	the non-representation of urbanism in southern literature	2726.8734358314055
17915. the book	concerned with the negro's role in an urban society is rare indeed;	recently only keith wheeler's novel peaceable lane has	openly faced the problem	4119.732239819574
17916. all but the most rabid of confederate	flag wavers admit that the old southern tradition is defunct in	actuality and sigh that its passing was accompanied by the disappearance	of many genteel and aristocratic traditions of the reputedly languid	ante-bellum way of life	4441.26917094157
17917. many earlier writers mourning the demise	of the old order tended to romanticize and exaggerate this gracious	old south imagery creating such lasting impressions as margaret	mitchell's	tara plantation	4647.924221722879
17918. modern writers who are supposed	to keep their fingers firmly upon the pulse of their subjects insist	upon drawing out this legend prolonging its burial when it well deserves	a rest after the overexploitation of the past century	4032.5468961105676
17919. perhaps	these writers have been too deeply moved by this romanticizing; but	they can hardly deny that exaggerated or not the old panorama is dead	3888.84971366831
17920. as john t westbrook says in his article twilight of southern	regionalism: h	the miasmal mausoleum where an old south already too minutely	autopsied in prose and poetry should be left to rest in peace forever	dead and forever done with	4299.350009020685
17921. westbrook	further bemoans the southern writers' creation of an unreal image	of their homeland which is too readily assimilated by both foreign	readers and visiting yankees: our northerner is suspicious of	all this crass evidence of urbanization presented to his senses	6418.830483330959
17922. it bewilders and befuddles him	14.877122239090326
17923. he is too deeply steeped in william	faulkner and robert penn warren	962.9042066894324
17924. the fumes of progress are in his	nose and the bright steel of industry towers before his eyes but his	heart is away in yoknapatawpha county with razorback hogs and night	riders	3448.638749209441
17925. on this trip to the south he wants above all else to sniff	the effluvium of backwoods-and-sand-hill subhumanity and to see at	least one barn burn at midnight	4466.090089717327
17926. obviously such a northern tourist's	purpose is somewhat akin to a child's experience with disneyland:	he wants to see a world of make-believe	2317.8744787996366
17927. in the	meantime while the south has been undergoing this phenomenal modernization	that is so disappointing to the curious yankee southern writers	have certainly done little to reflect and promote their region's	progress	5323.266706566999
17928. willard thorp in his new book american writing in	the twentieth century observes quite validly it seems: h	certain subjects are conspicuously absent or have been only lightly touched	3107.3625938136033
17929. no southern novelist has done for atlanta or birmingham what	herrick dreiser and farrell did for chicago or dos passos did	for new york h there are almost no fictional treatments of the	industrialized south	5630.647053976165
17930. not a single southern author major or minor	has made the urban problems of an urban south his primary source material	2042.0504774951398
17931. faulkner for one appears to be safe from the accusing	fingers of all assailants in this regard	2112.4386971068443
17932. faulkner culminates the	southern legend perhaps more masterfully than it has ever been or could	ever be done	1570.125391340625
17933. he has made it his and his it remains irrevocably	558.3903090166529
17934. he treats it with a mythological universal application	167.01337268375968
17935. as	his disciples boast even though his emphasis is elsewhere faulkner	does show his awareness of the changing order of the south quite keenly	as can be proven by a quick recalling of his sartoris and snopes	families	6087.607643376229
17936. even two decades ago in go down moses faulkner	was looking to the more urban future with a glimmer of hope that through	its youth and its new way of life the south might be reborn and the	curse of slavery erased from its soil	4609.175470700977
17937. yet his concern even here is	with a slowly changing socio-economic order in general and he never	deals with such specific aspects of this change as the urban and industrial	impact	5012.993101317348
17938. faulkner traces in his vast and overpowering saga	of yoknapatawpha county the gradual changes which seep into the	south building layer upon layer of minute subtle innovation which eventually	tend largely to hide the old way	3852.7461992610297
17939. thus faulkner reminds	us and wisely that the new south has gradually evolved out of	the old south and consequently its agrarian roots persist	3691.0574995844545
17940. yet he	presents a realm of source material which may well serve other writers	if not himself: the problems with which a new south must grapple	in groping through a blind adolescence into the maturity of urbanization	3949.828724768183
17941. with new mechanization the modern farmer must perform the work of	six men: a machine stands between the agrarian and his soil	3272.2686201256033
17942. the	thousands of city migrants who desert the farms yearly must readjust with	even greater stress and tension: the sacred wilderness is gradually	surrendering to suburbs and research parks and industrial areas	3458.7630479001064
17943. another element to concern the choreographer is that of the visual	devices of the theatre	1647.6536517674845
17944. most avant-garde creators true to their	interest in the self-sufficiency of pure movement have tended to dress	their dancers in simple lines and solid colors and to	give them a bare cyclorama for a setting	3756.108633180266
17945. but robert rauschenberg	the neo-dadaist artist has collaborated with several of them	963.1715466294254
17946. he has	designed a matching backdrop and costumes of points of color on white	for mr cunningham's summerspace so that dancers and background	merge into a shimmering unity	2988.126757965806
17947. for mr taylor's images	and reflections he made some diaphanous tents that alternately	hide and reveal the performer and a girl's cape lined with grass	3902.969466488748
17948. mr	nikolais has made a distinctive contribution to the arts of costume	and decor	942.5804872105355
17949. in fact he calls his productions dance-theatre works	of motion shape light and sound	1417.3649050375327
17950. to raise the dancer out of his personal	pedestrian self mr nikolais has experimented with relating	him to a larger environmental orbit	2179.827722400515
17951. he began with masks to make	the dancer identify himself with the creature he appeared to be	2111.0607561024117
17952. he	went on to use objects- hoops poles capes- which he employed as	extensions of the body of the dancer who moved with them	2439.9349384202246
17953. the depersonalization	continued as the dancer was further metamorphosed by the play	of lights upon his figure	2121.637554404656
17954. in each case the object the color even	the percussive sounds of the electronic score were designed to become	part of the theatrical being of the performer	2864.0122012009106
17955. the dancer who never	loosens her hold on a parasol begins to feel that it is part of herself	2585.8336837990837
17956. or clad from head to toe in fabric stretched over a series of	hoops the performer may well lose his sense of self in being a finial	2867.486609043617
17957. as the dancer is depersonalized his accouterments are animized	and the combined elements give birth to a new being	2597.6279229743054
17958. from this being	come new movement ideas that utilize dancer and property as a single	unit	1261.6392265064978
17959. thus the avant-garde choreographers have extended the	scope of materials available for dance composition	1408.7311448385358
17960. but since they	have rejected both narrative and emotional continuity how are they	to unify the impressive array of materials at their disposal	2324.2668420605505
17961. some	look deliberately to devices used by creators in the other arts and apply	corresponding methods to their own work	2819.2227405843832
17962. others less consciously	but quite probably influenced by the trends of the times experiment	with approaches that parallel those of the contemporary poet painter	and musician	2726.5254787870736
17963. an approach that has appealed to some choreographers	is reminiscent of charles olson's statement of the process	of projective verse: one perception must immediately and directly	lead to a further perception	5001.211742177299
17964. the creator trusts his intuition to	lead him along a path that has internal validity because it mirrors	the reality of his experience	2317.7365384604554
17965. he disdains external restrictions- conventional	syntax traditional metre	251.42374472912144
17966. the unit of form is determined	subjectively: the heart by the way of the breath to the line	1574.9783732336998
17967. the test of form is fidelity to the experience a gauge also accepted	by the abstract expressionist painters	2381.8434651829257
17968. an earlier but	still influential school of painting surrealism had suggested the way	of dealing with the dream experience that event in which seemingly	incongruous objects are linked together through the curious associations	of the subconscious	3849.0801076268203
17969. the resulting picture might appear a maze of	restless confusions and contradictions but it is more true to life than	a portrait of an artificially contrived order	4294.110041086829
17970. the contemporary painter	tends to depict not the concrete objects of his experience but	their essences as revealed in abstractions of their lines colors masses	and energies	2853.4903301662443
17971. he is still concerned however with a personal event	393.54626574052406
17972. he accepts the accidents of his brushwork because they provide evidence	of the vitality of the experience of creation	1711.3961627416297
17973. the work must	be true to both the physical and the spiritual character of the experience	1896.2764456175119
17974. some painters have less interest in the experience of the	moment with its attendant urgencies and ambiguities than in looking	beyond the flux of particular impressions to a higher more serene level	of truth	3650.7669166788864
17975. rather than putting their trust in ephemeral sensations	they seek form in the stable relationships of pure design which symbolize	an order more real than the disorder of the perceptual world	5009.133083124273
17976. but in this approach it is the artist's	ultimate insight rather than his immediate impressions that gives	form to the work	2036.4131930310516
17977. others look to more objective devices of	order	251.36443055420932
17978. the musician employing the serial technique of composition establishes	a mathematical system of rotations that once set in motion	determines the sequence of pitches and even of rhythms and intensities	3223.8781028272706
17979. the composer may reverse or invert the order of his original set of	intervals	1407.9647510036598
17980. he may even alter the pattern	by applying a scheme of random numbers	788.7873369547087
17981. but he cannot order his	elements by will either rational or inspired	962.745397436632
17982. the system works as an	impersonal mechanism	94.11090460151091
17983. musicians who use the chance method also exclude	subjective control of formal development	1178.65397265112
17984. again the composer must	select his own materials	168.2716434828068
17985. but a tossing of coins with perhaps the added	safeguard of reference to the oracles of the i ching the chinese	book of changes dictates the handling of the chosen materials	5002.93635744135
17986. avant-garde choreographers seeking new forms of continuity	for their new vocabulary of movements have turned to similar approaches	1564.7057611217097
17987. some let dances take their form from the experience of creation	753.5230147527283
17988. according to katherine litz the becoming the process of realization	is the dance	795.7241319848983
17989. the process stipulates that the choreographer	sense the quality of the initial movement he has discovered and that	he feel the rightness of the quality that is to follow it	4807.78308648979
17990. the sequence	may involve a sharp contrast: for example a quiet meditative sway	of the body succeeded by a violent leap; or it may involve more subtle	distinctions: the sway may be gradually minimized or enlarged	its rhythmic emphasis may be slightly modified or it may be transferred	to become a movement of only the arms or the head	5469.319582679507
17991. even the least	alteration will change the quality	250.21588700710527
17992. an exploration of these possible	relationships constitutes the process of creation and thereby gives form	to the dance	1578.8252674709604
17993. the approach to the depiction of the experience	of creation may be analytic as it is for miss litz or spontaneous	as it is for merle marsicano	4280.791749496651
17994. she too is concerned with the	becoming the process of realization but she does not think in	terms of subtle variations of spatial or temporal patterns	2715.997650101423
17995. the design	is determined emotionally: i must reach into myself for the spring	that will send me catapulting recklessly into the chaos of event	with which the dance confronts me	4825.981809258977
17996. looking back miss marsicano	feels that her ideas may have been influenced by those of jackson pollock	1402.8967776708328
17997. at one time she felt impelled to make dances that moved all	over the stage much as pollock's paintings move violently over	the full extent of the canvas	4467.389628896685
17998. but her conscious need was to break away	from constricting patterns of form a need to let the experience shape	itself	2027.1324509071505
17999. midi garth also believes in subjective continuity	that begins with the feeling engendered by an initial movement	2125.850934411815
18000. it	may be a free front-back swing of the leg leading to a sideways swing	of the arm that develops into a turn and the sensation of taking off	from the ground	3473.641754139888
18001. this became a dance called prelude to flight	248.66329662890553
18002. a pervading quality of free lyricism and a building from turns close	to the ground towards jumps into the air gives the work its central focus	2750.7860525903734
18003. alwin nikolais objects to art as an outpouring of personal	emotion	751.1865111037389
18004. he seeks to make his dancers more godlike by relating	them to the impersonal elements of shape light color and sound	2029.2756299275297
18005. if	his dancers are sometimes made to look as if they might be creatures	from mars this is consistent with his intention of placing them in	the orbit of another world a world in which they are freed of their	pedestrian identities	6581.336582361177
18006. it is through the metamorphosed dancer that the	germ of form is discovered	792.1026661271155
18007. in his recognition of his impersonal self	the dancer moves and this self in the first revealed stroke of	its existence states the theme from which all else must follow	4820.481790802859
18008. the	theme may be the formation of a shape from which other shapes evolve	942.2083003802891
18009. it may be a reaction to a percussive sound the following movements	constituting further reactions	1667.1879156756204
18010. it may establish the relation of the	figure of the dancer to light and color in which case changes in the	light or color will set off a kaleidescope of visual designs	3447.6172454018224
18011. unconcerned	with the practical function of his actions the dancer is engrossed	exclusively in their motional content	2117.6047252831386
18012. movements unfold freely	because they are uninhibited by emotional bias or purposive drive	792.0908724912807
18013. but the metamorphosis must come first	65.1694787882827
18014. though he is also concerned	with freeing dance from pedestrian modes of activity merce	cunningham has selected a very different method for achieving his aim	2606.646627736488
18015. he rejects all subjectively motivated continuity any line of action	related to the concept of cause and effect	2346.144334165365
18016. he bases his approach	on the belief that anything can follow anything	640.5552687830597
18017. an order can be chanced	rather than chosen and this approach produces an experience that	is free and discovered rather than bound and remembered	3683.1812330187195
18018. thus	there is freshness not only in the individual movements of the dance	but in the shape of their continuity as well	2183.1300797810695
18019. chance he finds enables	him to create a world beyond imagination	755.6407007054029
18020. he cites with pleasure	the comment of a lady who exclaimed after a concert: why	it's extremely interesting	1580.4071932871852
18021. but i would never have thought of it myself	389.8831792853015
18022. the sequence of movements in a cunningham dance is	unlike any sequence to be seen in life	1414.8997753592155
18023. at one side of the stage a dancer	jumps excitedly; nearby another sits motionless while still another	is twirling an umbrella	3034.8605212162283
18024. a man and a girl happen to meet; they	look straight at the audience not at each other	1580.5695252125565
18025. he lifts her puts	her down and walks off neither pleased nor disturbed as if nothing	had happened	2363.1432100490374
18026. if one dancer slaps another the victim may do a pirouette	sit down or offer his assailant a fork and spoon	2053.3128678853213
18027. events occur	without apparent reason	22.024630256061176
18028. their consequences are irrelevant- or there	are no consequences at all	502.4714419850701
18029. the sequence is determined by	chance and mr cunningham makes use of any one of several chance	devices	2345.7860752920596
18030. he may toss coins; he may take slips of paper from a grab	bag	945.5591075850995
18031. the answers derived by these means may determine not only the temporal	organization of the dance but also its spatial design special	slips designating the location on the stage where the movement is to be	performed	5788.221128751397
18032. the other variables include the dancer who is to perform	the movement and the length of time he is to take in its performance	2452.247119010406
18033. the only factors that are personally set by the choreographer are the	movements themselves the number of the dancers and the approximate	total duration of the dance	4287.937894982357
18034. the approximate is important because	even after the order of the work has been established by the chance	method the result is not inviolable	2474.804513630509
18035. each performance may be different	22.11418985509143
18036. if a work is divided into several large segments a last-minute	drawing of random numbers may determine the order of the segments for	any particular performance	2729.5217313912567
18037. and any sequence can not only change its	positions in the work but can even be eliminated from it altogether	2822.7746603044643
18038. mr cunningham tries not to cheat the chance method; he	adheres to its dictates as faithfully as he can	1729.1550412563633
18039. however there is always	the possibility that chance will make demands the dancers find impossible	to execute	2106.9464734364656
18040. then the choreographer must arbitrate	14.759289828250342
18041. he must	rearrange matters so that two performers do not bump into each other	1413.038615344981
18042. he must construct transitions so that a dancer who is told to lie prone	one second and to leap wildly the next will have some physical preparation	for the leap	3228.3766617429337
18043. the north and the south were in greater agreement on sovereignty	through all their dispute about it than were the founding fathers	3262.9481432272273
18044. the truth in their conflicting concepts was expounded by statesmen	of the calibre of webster and calhoun and defended in the end	by leaders of the nobility of lincoln and lee	3332.962873020331
18045. the people everywhere	had grown meanwhile in devotion to basic democratic principles in	understanding of and belief in the federal balance and in love of their	union	4279.68313558834
18046. repeated efforts- beginning with the missouri compromise	of 1821- were made by such master moderates as clay and douglas	to resolve the difference peacefully by compromise rather than clear	thought and timely action	3548.554796078238
18047. even so confusion in this period gained	such strength that it led to the	bloodiest war of the nineteenth century	2805.616811181021
18048. nothing can show more than	this the immensity of the danger to democratic peoples that lies in	even relatively slight deviation from their true concept of sovereignty	2858.2167802773383
18049. the present issue in atlantica- whether to transform an	alliance of sovereign nations into a federal union of sovereign citizens-	resembles the american one of 1787-89 rather than the one that	was resolved by civil war	5782.700948499119
18050. and so i would only touch upon it now		128.1042216462419
18051. i think it is	essential however to pinpoint here the difference between the two concepts	of sovereignty that went to war in 1861- if only to see better	how imperative is our need today to clarify completely our far worse	confusion on this subject	6790.145737708985
18052. the difference came down to this:	the southern states insisted that the united states was in last	analysis what its name implied- a union of states	2719.022572227786
18053. to their leaders	the constitution was a compact made by the people of sovereign	states who therefore retained the right to secede from it	3695.00517863176
18054. this right	of the state its upholders contended was essential to maintain	the federal balance and protect the liberty of the people from the danger	of centralizing power in the union government	3465.8518163907647
18055. the champions of	the union maintained that the constitution had formed fundamentally	the united people of america that it was a compact among sovereign	citizens rather than states and that therefore the states had no right	to secede though the citizens could	6588.254787187038
18056. writing to speed on august	24 1855 lincoln made the latter point clear	792.1888501675581
18057. in homely terms whose	timeliness is startling today he thus declared his own right to secede	1895.8512651055105
18058. we began by declaring that all men are created equal	373.4562279525238
18059. we now practically read it all men are created equal except negroes	958.4040144269532
18060. when the know-nothings get control it will read all	men	are created equal except negroes and foreigners and catholics	1723.532123646442
18061. when	it comes to this i shall prefer emigrating to some country where	they make no pretence of loving liberty- to russia for instance where	despotism can be taken pure without the base alloy of hypocrisy	5766.764009499874
18062. his emphasis   when the southern states exercised	their right to secede they formed what they officially styled the	confederate states of america	2160.9379293203265
18063. dictionaries as we have	seen still cite this government along with the articles of confederation	of 1781 as an example of a confederacy	3481.2645708976206
18064. the fact is that the	southern confederacy differed from the earlier one almost as much as	the federal constitution did	1888.362771612484
18065. the confederate constitution copied	much of the federal constitution verbatim and most of the rest in	substance	2119.3647992947035
18066. it operated on by and for the people individually just as	did the federal constitution	1107.9252400390762
18067. it made substantially the same division	of power between the central and state governments and among the	executive legislative and judicial branches	3282.1806319904426
18068. confederacy and federal union in 1861	many believe- and understandably-	that the great difference between the constitution of	the southern confederacy and the federal constitution was that the	former recognized the right of each state to secede	3950.2943670690374
18069. but though each	of its members had asserted this right against the union the final	constitution which the confederacy signed on march 11- nearly a month	before hostilities began- included no explicit provision authorizing	a state to secede	6078.177722773331
18070. its drafters discussed this vital point but	left it out of their constitution	779.6242184268414
18071. their president jefferson davis	interpreted their constitution to mean that it admits of no coerced	association but this reremained so doubtful that there were	frequent demands that the right to secede be put into the constitution	5756.722549979548
18072. the constitution of the southern confederation	differed from that of the federal union only in two important respects:	it openly defiantly recognized slavery- an institution	which the southerners of 1787 even though they continued it found so	impossible to reconcile with freedom that they carefully avoided mentioning	the word in the federal constitution	5154.067944921343
18073. the	other important difference between the two constitutions was that the	president of the confederacy held office for six	years and was limited to one term	2734.3985589142276
18074. these are not however differences	in federal structure	249.52383532964967
18075. the only important differences from that	standpoint between the two constitutions lies in their preambles	1094.4935798770587
18076. we	the people of the confederate states each state acting in its	sovereign and independent character in order to form a permanent federal	government establish justice insure domestic tranquility and secure	the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity- invoking	the favor and the guidance of almighty god- do ordain and establish	this constitution for the confederate states of america	5578.003595025905
18077. one is tempted to say that on the difference between the concepts	of sovereignty in these two preambles the worst war of the nineteenth	century was fought	4277.384358270583
18078. but though the southern states when drafting	a constitution to unite themselves narrowed the difference to this	fine point by omitting to assert the right to secede the fact remained	that by seceding from the union they had already acted on the concept	that it was composed primarily of sovereign states	4985.146349699167
18079. if the union	conceded this to them the same right must be conceded to each remaining	state whenever it saw fit to secede: this would destroy the federal	balance between it and the states and in the end sacrifice to	the sovereignty of the states all the liberty the citizens had gained	by their union	7883.231827546575
18080. lincoln saw that the act of secession made the	issue for the union a vital one: whether it was a union of sovereign	citizens that should continue to live or an association of sovereign	states that must fall prey either to anarchy or despotism	4552.2240237602
18081. much as he abhorred slavery lincoln was always willing to	concede to each slave state the right to decide independently whether	to continue or end it	4097.402258345882
18082. though his election was interpreted by	many southerners as the forerunner of a dangerous shift in the federal	balance in favor of the union lincoln himself proposed no such change	in the rights the constitution gave the states	4050.7087309710623
18083. after the war began	he long refused to permit emancipation of the slaves by union action	even in the border states that stayed with the union	4102.852597649928
18084. he issued	his emancipation proclamation only when he felt that necessity left	him no other way to save the union	1880.2432495552475
18085. in his message of december	2 1862 he put his purpose and his policy in these words- which i	would call the lincoln law of liberty-and-union: in giving	freedom to the slave we assure freedom to the free	6071.041991966535
18086. what	lincoln could not concede was that the states rather than the people	were sovereign in the union	1563.4090501972123

18492. his appearance as	lizzy evokes not amusement but horror in the audience; it is a spectacle	absolutely painful an epiphany of the suffering flesh unredeemed	by spirit untouched by any spirit other than abasement and humiliation	5782.766297351393
18493. at the same time the multiple transvestitism involved- the fat	man as girl and as baby as coquette pretending to be a baby- touches	for a moment horrifyingly upon the secret sources of a life like jacoby's	upon the sinister dreams which form the sources of any human	life	4895.591524874765
18494. the music which la^utner has composed for this episode	is for the most part rather pretty and perfectly banal	2597.0900614945303
18495. but	it is characteristic of him we are told his little artifice	to be able to introduce into a fairly vulgar and humorous piece of	hackwork a sudden phrase of genuine creative art	3547.1552796370115
18496. and this occurs	now at the refrain of jacoby's song- at the point in fact of	the name lizzy-; a modulation described as almost a stroke	of genius	4479.500238076428
18497. a miracle a revelation it was like a curtain suddenly	torn away to reveal something nude	1252.776979132641
18498. it is this modulation	which reveals to jacoby his own frightful abjection and simultaneously	his wife's infidelity	2128.354754315214
18499. by the same means he perceives this fact	as having communicated itself to the audience; he collapses and dies	1738.3409833524008
18500. in the work of every artist i suppose there may be found	one or more moments which strike the student as absolutely decisive	ultimately emblematic of what it is all about; not less strikingly	so for being mysterious as though some deeply hidden constatation of	thoughts were enciphered in a single image a single moment	7874.659962479421
18501. when i try to work out my reasons for feeling that	this passage is of critical significance i come up with the following	ideas which i shall express very briefly here and revert to in	a later essay	6058.240405802722
18502. love is the crucial dilemma of experience for mann's	heroes	371.38410108540376
18503. the dramatic construction of his stories characteristically	turns on a situation in which someone is simultaneously compelled	and forbidden to love	3040.7962749702997
18504. the release the freedom involved in loving	another is either terribly difficult or else absolutely impossible;	and the motion toward it brings disaster	2321.4046725365224
18505. this prohibition	on love has an especially poignant relation to art; it is particularly	the artist who suffers	from it	2826.878914879253
18506. the specific analogy to the dilemma of love is the problem	of the breakthrough in the realm of art	1731.7568242272177
18507. again the sufferings	and disasters produced by any transgression against the commandment	not to love are almost invariably associated in one way or another	with childhood with the figure of a child	5156.461482094486
18508. finally the	theatrical notions of dressing up cosmetics	disguise and especially change of costume	are characteristically associated with the catastrophes	of mann's stories	2320.065977512978
18509. we shall return to these statements	and deal with them more fully as the evidence for them accumulates	2366.161792847076
18510. for the present it is enough to note that in the grotesque figure of	jacoby at the moment of his collapse all these elements come together	in prophetic parody	3092.6372964646034
18511. professionally a lawyer that is to say associated	with dignity reserve discipline with much that is essentially	middle-class he is compelled by an impossible love to exhibit himself	dressed up disguised- that is paradoxically revealed- as a	child and worse as a whore masquerading as a child	7152.715526542079
18512. it appears that the dominant tendency of	mann's early tales however pictorial or even picturesque the surface	is already toward the symbolic the emblematic the expressionistic	4103.905361725998
18513. in a certain perfectly definite way the method and the theme of his	stories are one and the same	1738.5478975533802
18514. something of this can be learned	from the way to the churchyard an anecdote about	an old failure whose fit of anger at a passing cyclist causes him to die	of a stroke or seizure	5683.906385481624
18515. there is no more plot than that; only	slightly more perhaps than a newspaper account of such an incident	would give	2034.5498125928461
18516. the artistic interest then lies in what the encounter	may be made to represent in the power of some central significance	to draw the details into relevance and meaningfulness	4638.344246578239
18517. the first	sentence with its platitudinous irony announces an emblematic intent:	the way to the churchyard ran along beside the highroad ran	beside it all the way to the end; that is to say to the churchyard	3957.042941003575
18518. and the action is consistently presented with regard for this distinction	753.2319263316471
18519. the highroad one might say at first belongs to life while	the way to the churchyard belongs to death	1722.2260415154128
18520. but that is too simple	and won't hold up	394.67127000556945
18521. as the first sentence suggests both roads belong	to death in the end	787.9666769778039
18522. but the highroad according to the description	of its traffic belongs to life as it is lived in unawareness of death	while the way to the churchyard belongs to some other sort of life:	a suffering form an existence wholly comprised in the awareness	of death	7010.897421119875
18523. thus on the highroad a troop of soldiers marched in their	own dust and sang while on the footpath one man walks alone	2321.980480070079
18524. this man's isolation is not merely momentary it is permanent	561.8765337899873
18525. he is a widower his three children are dead he has no one left on	earth; also he is a drunk and has lost his job on that account	3116.4259245384887
18526. his	name is praisegod piepsam and he is rather fully described as to	his clothing and physiognomy in a way which relates him to a sinister	type in the author's repertory- he is a forerunner of those enigmatic	strangers in death in venice for example who represent	some combination of cadaver exotic and psychopomp	7774.689741566561
18527. this strange	person quarrels with a cyclist because the latter is using the path	rather than the highroad	1584.604499969044
18528. the cyclist a sufficiently commonplace	young fellow is not named but identified simply as life- that	and a license number which piepsam uses in addressing him	4112.4854332270925
18529. life	points out that everybody uses this path and starts to ride	on	787.1016912756388
18530. piepsam tries to stop him by force receives a push in the chest	from life and is left standing in impotent and growing rage	while a crowd begins to gather	4841.017857204045
18531. his rage assumes a religious form;	that is on the basis of his own sinfulness and abject wretchedness	piepsam becomes a prophet who in his ecstasy and in the name of god	imprecates doom on life- not only the cyclist now but the audience	the world as well: all you light-headed breed	5111.709436429405
18532. this passion	brings on a fit which proves fatal	394.1692970297085
18533. then an ambulance comes along	and they drive praisegod piepsam away	504.8844252021169
18534. this is simple enough	but several more points of interest may be mentioned as relevant	1647.5600969459088
18535. the	season between spring and summer belongs to life in its carefree	aspect	788.2819378047064
18536. piepsam's fatal rage arises not only because he cannot	stop the cyclist but also because god will not stop him; as piepsam	says to the crowd in his last moments: his justice is not of	this world	5942.997885290865
18537. life is further characterized in antithesis to	piepsam as animal: the image of a dog which appears at several	places is first given as the criterion of amiable irrelevant interest	aroused by life considered simply as a spectacle: a dog in a wagon	is admirable a pleasure to contemplate; another wagon	has no dog and therefore is devoid of interest	5541.057009981052
18538. piepsam calls	the cyclist cur and puppy among other things and at the crisis	of his fit a little fox-terrier stands before him and howls into	his face	4487.062001780063
18539. the ambulance is drawn by two charming little horses	262.0946252550489
18540. piepsam is not certainly religious in any conventional sense	391.78729586624775
18541. his religiousness is intimately or dialectically connected with	his sinfulness; the two may in fact be identical	1408.0448463492341
18542. his unsuccessful	strivings to give up drink are represented as religious strivings;	he keeps a bottle in a wardrobe at home and before this wardrobe praisegod	piepsam had before now gone literally on his knees and in	his wrestlings had bitten his tongue- and still in the end capitulated	7331.919426706341
18543. the cyclist by contrast blond and blue-eyed is simply	unreflective unproblematic life blithe and carefree	1106.0864341127992
18544. he	made no claims to belong to the great and mighty of this earth	1405.7543448213748
18545. piepsam is grotesque a disturbing parody; his end is ridiculous	and trivial	642.453384229016
18546. he is a man raving mad on the way to the churchyard	961.5206923830896
18547. but he is more interesting than the others the ones who come from	the highroad to watch him more interesting than life considered	as a cyclist	2758.619560928347
18548. and if i have gone into so much detail about so small	a work that is because it is also so typical a work representing the	germinal form of a conflict which remains essential in mann's writing:	the crude sketch of piepsam contains in its critical destructive	and self-destructive tendencies much that is enlarged and illuminated	in the figures of for instance naphta and leverku^hn	8626.144630211216
18549. in method as well as in theme this little anecdote with its details	selected as much for expressiveness and allegory as for realism	anticipates a kind of musical composition as well as a kind of fictional	composition in which as leverku^hn says there shall be	nothing unthematic	4748.44021953446
18550. it resembles too pictures such as du^rer	and bruegel did in which all that looks at first to be solely pictorial	proves on inspection to be also literary the representation of a	proverb for example or a deadly sin	6180.258914414531
18551. gladius dei	resembles the way to the churchyard in its representation	of a conflict between light and dark between life and a spirit	of criticism negation melancholy but it goes considerably further	in characterizing the elements of this conflict	4137.977962848808
18552. the monk savonarola	brought over from the renaissance and placed against the background	of munich at the turn of the century protests against the luxurious	works displayed in the art-shop of m bluthenzweig; in	particular against a madonna portrayed in a voluptuous style and modeled	according to gossip upon the painter's mistress	7653.528374141752
18553. hieronymus	like piepsam makes his protest quite in vain and his rejection though	not fatal is ridiculous and humiliating; he is simply thrown out	of the shop by the porter	3231.6237631792096
18554. on the street outside hieronymus envisions	a holocaust of the vanities of this world such a burning of artistic	and erotic productions as his namesake actually brought to pass in	florence and prophetically he issues his curse: gladius dei	super terram cito et velociter	6795.298803882533
18555. the reality to which they respond is rationally empty and their	art is an imitation of the inescapable powerfulness of this unknown and	empty world	2618.6666142599083
18556. their artistic rationale is given to the witness of unreason	563.6499225932148
18557. these polar concerns reflect	a philosophical and religious situation which has been developing	over a long period of time	1727.8036242939083
18558. the breakdown of classical structures of	meaning in all realms of western culture has given rise to several generations	of artists who have documented the disintegrative processes	4253.294962192163
18559. thus the image of man has suffered complete fragmentation in personal	and spiritual qualities and complete objectification in sub-human and	quasi-mechanistic powers	2170.1883975701826
18560. the image of the world tends to reflect the	hostility and indifference of man or else to dissolve into empty spaces	and overwhelming mystery	3690.2829524842664
18561. the image of god has simply disappeared	94.6652359562063
18562. all such imitations of negative quality have given rise to a compensatory	response in the form of a heroic and highly individualistic humanism:	if man can neither know nor love reality as it is he can at	least invent an artistic reality which is its own world and which	can speak to man of purely personal and subjective qualities capable	of being known and worthy of being loved	8825.555783377686
18563. the person of the artist	becomes a final bastion of meaning in a world rendered meaningless by	the march of events and the decay of classical religious and philosophical	systems	3223.2088990937136
18564. whatever pole of this contrast one emphasizes and	whatever the tension between these two approaches to understanding	the artistic imagination it will be readily seen that they are not mutually	exclusive that they belong together	5617.534414874797
18565. without the decay of a	sense of objective reference the	stress on subjective invention would never have been stimulated into	being	2037.5010571714422
18566. and although these insights into the nature of art may be in themselves	insufficient for a thoroughgoing philosophy of art their peculiar	authenticity in this day and age requires that they be taken seriously	and gives promise that from their very substance new and valid	chapters in the philosophy of art may be written	7750.067482961873
18567. for better or worse	we cannot regard imitation in the arts in the simple mode of	classical rationalism or detached realism	2036.3248240820626
18568. a broader concept of imitation	is needed one which acknowledges that true invention is important	that the artist's creativity in part transcends the non-artistic	causal factors out of which it arises	4984.777077779467
18569. on the other hand we cannot regard	artistic invention as pure uncaused and unrelated to the times	in which it occurs	2027.3752331772946
18570. we need a doctrine of imitation to save us from	the solipsism and futility of pure formalism	2122.022242155964
18571. accordingly it is the	aim of this essay to advance a new theory of imitation	call mimesis in order to distinguish it from earlier theories of	and a new theory of invention		2562.6906474979905
18572. the arts	the word mimesis is usually associated	with plato and aristotle	960.3346203548608
18573. for plato imitation is twice	removed from reality being a poor copy of physical appearance which	in itself is a poor copy of ideal essence	2595.3666804387244
18574. all artistic and mythological	representations therefore are imitations of imitations and	are completely superseded by the truth value of dialectic the	proper use of the inquiring intellect	4289.346281775141
18575. in plato's judgment the	arts play a meaningful role in society only in the education of the young	prior to the full development of their intellectual powers	2843.6352154465358
18576. presupposed	in plato's system is a doctrine of levels of insight in which	a certain kind of detached understanding is alone capable of penetrating	to the most sublime wisdom	4678.734556482096
18577. aristotle also tended to stratify all	aspects of human nature and activity into levels of excellence and	like plato he put the pure and unimpassioned intellect on the top level	3230.236931690772
18578. the poetics in affirming that all human arts are modes	of imitation gives a more serious role to artistic mimesis than	did plato	3450.457041131519
18579. but aristotle kept the principle of levels and even augmented	it by describing in the poetics what kinds of character and	action must be imitated if the play is to be a vehicle of serious and	important human truths	4127.972679553081
18580. for both plato and aristotle artistic mimesis	in contrast to the power of dialectic is relatively incapable of	expressing the character of fundamental reality	3689.5124807958114
18581. the central	concern of erich auerbach's impressive volume called mimesis	is to describe the shift from a classic theory of imitation	to a christian theory of imitation	in which the levels are dissolved	3571.406115443003
18582. following the theme of incarnation	in the gospels the christian artist and critic sees in the most	commonplace and ordinary events figures of divine power and reality	4291.72610049035
18583. here artistic realism involves the audience in an impassioned participation	in events whose overtones and implications are transcendent	1577.9678655382609
18584. artistic mimesis under christian influence records the involvement	of all persons however humble in a divine drama	2112.779206513661
18585. the artist unlike	the philosopher is not a removed observer aiming at neutral and rarified	high levels of abstraction	1737.8096553672701
18586. he is the conveyor of a sacred reality	by which he has been grasped	1415.1750861530581
18587. i have chosen to use the word mimesis	in its christian rather than its classic implications and	to discover in the concrete forms of both art and myth powers of theological	expression which as in the christian mind are the direct consequence	of involvement in historical experience which are not reserved	as in the greek mind only to moments of theoretical reflection	5613.9701530087395
18588. in the first instance mimesis is here used to mean the	recalling of experience in terms of vivid images rather than in terms	of abstract ideas or conventional designations	4636.568546168547
18589. by image is meant	not only a visual presentation but also remembered sensations of any	of the five senses plus the feelings which are immediately conjoined	therewith	2866.0290207043968
18590. this is the primary function of the imagination operating	in the absence of the original experiential stimulus by which the images	were first appropriated	3682.5689409195875
18591. mimesis is the nearest possible thing to	the actual re-living of experience in which the imagining person recovers	through images something of the force and depth characteristic	of experience itself	3227.752524773091
18592. the images themselves like their counterparts	in experience are not neutral qualities to be surveyed dispassionately;	they are fields of force exerting a unique influence on the sensibilities	and a unique relatedness to one another	5625.415201322037
18593. they bring an inextricable	component of value within themselves with attractions and repulsions	native to their own quality	1574.4817239804343
18594. as in experience one is seized by	given entities and their interrelations and is forced to respond in	value feelings to them so one is similarly seized in the mimetic presentation	of images	5341.459232690664
18595. mimesis here is not to be confused with literalism	or realism in the conventional sense	1103.6318018085644
18596. a word taken in its dictionary	meaning a photographic image of a recognizable object the mere picturing	of a scene tends to lose experiential vividness and to connote	such conventional abstractions as to invite neutral reception without	the incitement of value feelings	6552.713760182414
18597. similarly experience itself can	be conventionalized so that people react to certain preconceived clues	for behavior without awareness of the vitality of their experiential	field	2594.263746545391
18598. a truly vivid imagination moves beyond the conventional recollection	to a sense of immediacy	1415.2718006942036
18599. the mimetic character of the	imaginative consciousness tends to express itself in the presentation	of artistic forms and materials	1727.46749203843
18600. these	are like the initial ways in which the world forces itself upon the self	and thrusts the self into decision and choice	2339.1310120774842
18601. the presence of genuine	mimesis in art is marked by the persistence with which the work	demands attention and compels valuation even though it is but vaguely	understood	4495.0097340531565
18602. underlying these conceptions of mimesis are certain	presuppositions concerning the nature of primary human experience which	require some exposition before the main argument can proceed	2615.783586568368
18603. experience	is not seen as it is in classical rationalism as presenting	us initially with clear and distinct objects simply located in space	and	registering their character movements and changes on the tabula	rasa of an uninvolved intellect	6078.6575121706555
18604. neither is primary experience understood	according to the attitude of modern empiricism in which nothing	is thought to be received other than signals of sensory qualities producing	their responses in the appropriate sense organs	3651.524064388187
18605. primary feelings	of the world come neither as a collection of clearly known objects	nor a collection of isolated and	neutral sensory qualities	3493.9931693808458
18606. in contrast to all this primary data are	data of a self involved in environing processes and powers	1575.6339678240977
18607. the	most primitive feelings are rudimentary value feelings both positive	and negative: a desire to appropriate this or that part of the environment	into oneself; a desire to avoid and repel this or that other	part	5789.963959998167
18608. these desires presuppose a sense of causally efficacious powers	in which one is involved some working for one's good others threatening	ill	2187.9138652478096
18609. gone is the tabula rasa of the mind	250.016848218327
18610. in its place	is a passionate consciousness grasped and molded to feelings of positive	or negative values even as the actions of one's life are determined	by constellations of process in which one is caught	3768.9993356846508
18611. the principal	defender of this view of primary experience as causal efficacy	is alfred north whitehead	1876.7947939717008
18612. our most elemental and unavoidable	impressions he says are those of being involved in a large arena of	powers which have a longer past than our own which are interrelated	in a vast movement through the present toward the future	4209.833101368335
18613. we feel the	quality of these powers initially as in some degree wholesome or threatening	1659.3881846497636
18614. later abstractive and rational processes may indicate errors	of judgment in these apprehensions of value but the apprehensions themselves	are the primary stuff of experience	2590.980136726118
18615. it takes a great deal	of abstraction to free oneself from the primitive impression of larger	unities of power and influence and to view one's world simply as a	collection of sense data arranged in such and such sequence and pattern	devoid of all power to move the feelings and actions except in so far	as they present themselves for inspection	8348.467711811589
18616. whitehead is here questioning	david hume's understanding of the nature of experience; he	is questioning also every epistemology which stems from hume's	presupposition	that experience is merely sense data in abstraction from	causal efficacy and that causal efficacy is something intellectually	imputed to the world not directly perceived	4830.464108743388
18617. what hume calls sensation	is what whitehead calls perception in the mode of presentational	immediacy which is a sophisticated abstraction from perception	in the mode of causal efficacy	4461.305072580357
18618. as long as perception is seen as	composed only of isolated sense data most of the quality and interconnectedness	of existence loses its objectivity becomes an invention	of consciousness and the result is a philosophical scepticism	3868.523794125541
18619. whitehead	contends that the human way of understanding existence as a unity	of interlocking and interdependent processes which constitute each other	and which cause each other to be and not to be is possible only because	the basic form of such an understanding for all its vagueness and	tendency to mistake the detail is initially given in the way man	feels the world	8473.967782021386
18620. in this respect experience is broader and full of	a richer variety of potential meanings than the mind of man or any of	his arts or culture are capable of making clear and distinct	3654.582196024473
18621. a chief characteristic of experience in the mode of causal efficacy is	one of derivation from the past	2356.183656643485
18622. both i and my feelings come up out	of a chain of events that fan out into the past into sources that are	ultimately very unlike the entity which i now am	3433.997254825321
18623. after only eighteen years of non-interference there were already indications	of melioration though in a slight degree to be sure	2813.7585171548094
18624. there were more indications by the mid-twentieth century	168.4163924883111
18625. i leave	it to the statisticians to say what they were but i noticed several	a few years ago during an automobile ride from memphis to hattiesburg	4271.327087946127
18626. in town after town my companion pointed out the negro school	and the white school and in every instance the former made a better	appearance	2601.4054539283347
18627. it really looked as if a	change of the sort predicted by booker t washington had been going	on	2595.247566033766
18628. but with the renewal of interference in 1954	the improvement was impaired	636.3867938630294
18629. for over a hundred	years southerners have felt that the north was picking on them	1626.5333735215559
18630. it's infuriating this feeling that one is being picked on continually	constantly	645.0870679169369
18631. by what right of superior virtue southerners ask	do the people of the north do this	1875.5534025656968
18632. the traditional strategy of the	south has been to expose the vices of the north to demonstrate that	the north possessed no superior virtue to show the world that	however	bad i may be you're not quite the people to say it	4360.388049508767
18633. in the pre-civil war years the south argued that the slave was	not less humanely treated than the factory worker of the north	3469.0451669046415
18634. at	the present time the counter-attack takes the line that there's no	more of the true spirit of integration in the north than	in the south	2728.191938935124
18635. the line is a pretty good one	142.0165438172241
18636. people talk about	the law of the land	167.89533833234833
18637. the expression has become quite a cliche	140.68613202382636
18638. but people can't be made to integrate socialize	by law	372.7693467532823
18639. i was having lunch not	long ago with three distinguished	historians	and i asked them if they	could name instances where the general mores had been radically changed	with deliberate speed majestic instancy	by judicial fiat	5789.3213098933975

18641. a virginia	judge a while back cited a roman jurist to the effect that ten years	might be a reasonable length of time for such a change	4277.008531454232

18647. the	declaration of independence says that governments derive their	just powers from the consent of the governed	2124.1233343222452
18648. the phrase consent	of the governed needs a hard look	374.02068189052704

18650. is the	consent of the governed a numerical majority	261.9458209830625

18660. i murmured something about a possible difference between	new mexico's history and mississippi's	790.8219115454515
18661. one can meet	with aloofness almost anywhere: the thank-heaven-we're-not-involved	viewpoint it doesn't affect us! southern liberals	- especially if they're rich- often exhibit	blithe insouciance	2519.347927416684

18720. among the recipients of the nobel prize for literature	more than half are practically unknown to readers of english	2584.4935691923156
18721. of these	there are surely few that would be more rewarding discoveries than	verner von heidenstam the swedish poet and novelist who received	the award in 1916 and whose centennial was celebrated two years ago	3765.9310322902006
18722. equally a master of prose and verse he recreates the glory of sweden	in the past and continues it into the present	3279.058521168182
18723. in the following sketch	we shall present a brief outline of his life and let him as much as	possible speak for himself	2324.362012157616
18724. heidenstam was born in 1859 of	a prosperous family	392.42235714405564
18725. on his father's side he was of german descent	on his mother's he came of the old swedish nobility	1732.7402793015626
18726. the family	estate was situated near vadstena on lake va^ttern in south central	sweden	1412.6041335253153

18823. today the private detective will also investigate insurance claims or	handle divorce cases but his primary function remains what it has always	been to assist those who have money in their unending struggle with	those who have not	4031.813370451388
18824. it is from this unpromising background that the	fictional private detective was recruited	1178.6883931212183
18825. the mythological	private eye differs from his counterpart in real life in two essential	ways	1101.3714520360274
18826. on the one hand he does not work for a large agency but	is almost always self-employed	2112.441121453185
18827. as a free-lance investigator the fictional	detective is responsible to no one but himself and his client	1423.5981600291657
18828. for this reason he appears as an independent and self-reliant figure	whose rugged individualism need not be pressed into the mold of a	9 to 5 routine	4303.393506399371
18829. on the other hand the fictional detective does not	break strikes or handle divorce cases; no client would ever think of	asking him to do such things	2858.3937984193226
18830. whatever his original assignment the	fictional private eye ends up by investigating and solving a crime usually	a murder	2609.2008283316545
18831. operating as a one man police force in fact if not in	name he is at once more independent and more dedicated than the police	themselves	2750.6736977606947
18832. he catches criminals not merely because he is paid to	do so but because he enjoys	his work because he firmly believes that murder must be punished	4293.341890963869
18833. thus the fictional detective is much more than a simple businessman	504.4694746921047
18834. he is first and foremost a defender of public morals a servant of	society	1416.0339956008552
18835. it is this curious blend of rugged individualism and	public service which accounts for the great appeal of the mythological	detective	2041.4051808259399
18836. by virtue of his self-reliance his individualism and	his freedom from external restraint the private eye is a perfect embodiment	of the middle class conception of liberty which amounts to doing	what you please and let the devil take the hindmost	6462.256366950192
18837. at the same time	because the personal code of the detective coincides with the legal	dictates of his society because he likes to catch criminals he is	in middle class eyes a virtuous man	3654.6639762653344
18838. in this way the private detective	gets the best of two possible worlds	1189.0522771837454
18839. he is an individualist but	not an anarchist; he is a public servant but not a cop	1422.75623535852
18840. in short the	fictional private eye is a specialized version of adam smith's	ideal entrepreneur the man whose private ambitions must always and everywhere	promote the public welfare	4514.584084255999
18841. in the mystery story as in the	wealth of nations individualism and the social good are two sides	of the same benevolent coin	2331.316622514701
18842. there is only one	catch to this idyllic arrangement: adam smith was wrong	1180.9176558085378
18843. not only	did the ideal entrepreneur not produce the greatest good for the greatest	number he ended by destroying himself by giving birth to monopoly	capitalism	2728.7127854978075
18844. the rise of the giant corporations in western europe	and the united states dates from the period 1880-1900	2355.922745806177
18845. now although	the roots of the mystery story in serious literature go back as far	as balzac dickens and poe it was not until the closing decades	of the 19th century that the private detective became an established	figure in popular fiction	4388.083071758299
18846. sherlock holmes the ancestor of all private	eyes was born during the 1890s	1184.0425851949929
